Title: KVM avct_server : Avocent server certificate expired since 2010
RNE: Symptom: The KVM Java client may pop up an error/warning message stating that the KVM certificate to the blade has expired.   Conditions: When opening a KVM session to a UCS blade server, the KVM java client will announce that the certificate has either expired and/or is untrusted.   Workaround: The proposed workaround is to trust the certificate until Cisco releases a new firmware with update certificates. The Java client will state that the  certificate is untrusted and allow you to make the decision on trust. You can trust the certificate. If you do not, the KVM session will not establish.  PSIRT Evaluation: The Cisco PSIRT has assigned this bug the following CVSS version 2 score. The Base and Temporal CVSS scores as of the time of evaluation are  2.7/2.1: http://tools.cisco.com/security/center/cvssCalculator.x?vector=&version=2.0 dispatch=1&version=2&vector=AV:L/AC:M/Au:M/C:P/I:P/A:N/E:POC/RL:OF/RC:C No CVE ID has been assigned to this issue. Additional information on Cisco's security vulnerability policy can be found at the following URL: http://www.cisco.com/en/US/products/products_security_vulnerability_policy.html

Title: Cisco NX-OS Arbitrary File Read Vulnerability
RNE: Summary Cisco NX-OS software contains a directory traversal vulnerability within the command line interface that could allow a local, authenticated attacker to disclose the contents of arbitrary files on the affected device.  An attacker could leverage the NX-OS ''copy'' command to duplicate the contents of arbitrary files on the device to a user writable area of the filesystem.  As the new file will be owned by the authenticated user, the attacker will be able to view the contents.  This vulnerability affects the following platforms which are based on Cisco NX-OS: Cisco Nexus 7000 Cisco MDS 9000 Cisco Nexus 6000 Cisco Nexus 5500 Cisco Nexus 5000 Cisco Nexus 4000 Cisco Nexus 3500 Cisco Nexus 3000 Cisco Nexus 1000V Cisco Connected Grid Router 1000 Series Cisco Unified Computing System Fabric Interconnect 6200 Cisco Unified Computing System Fabric Interconnect 6100  Conditions Device is running an affected version of Cisco NX-OS software; An authenticated user with the privileges to run the copy command.  Further Problem Description: This issue was discovered during internal testing by Cisco.  PSIRT Evaluation:  The Cisco PSIRT has assigned this bug the following CVSS version 2 score. The Base and Temporal CVSS scores as of the time of evaluation are : 4.6/4.4 http://tools.cisco.com/security/center/cvssCalculator.x?vector=AV:L/AC:L/Au:S/C:C/I:N/A:N/E:F/RL:U/RC:C&version=2.0 CVE ID CVE-2013-6975 has been assigned to document this issue.  Additional details about the vulnerability described here can be found at: http://tools.cisco.com/security/center/content/CiscoSecurityNotice/CVE-2013-6975  Additional information on Cisco's security vulnerability policy can be found at the following URL: http://www.cisco.com/en/US/products/products_security_vulnerability_policy.html
Description: N3K: ;copy; command allow access to arbitrary files & contentsWith N3K, the ;copy; command allow access to arbitrary files (readable by system-user ;svc-isan;) along with the file content as follows:-----------switch# copy volatile: bootflash:Enter source filename: ../etc/passwdCopy progress 100% 495BCopy complete, now saving to disk (please wait)...switch# dir bootflash:passwd        495    Nov 06 02:09:49 2013  passwdUsage for bootflash://sup-local  738312192 bytes used  870965248 bytes free 1609277440 bytes totalswitch# ----------- The complete transcript of the repro session is listed in the ;Debug-output; enclosure. In the above example the contents of the /etc/passwd file can be viewed. The good news is files that are not readable by the system user ;svc-isan; won't be copied over with ;Permission denied; error message. The expectation is ;copy; command must prevent the directory traversal vulnerability and reject ;..; in the filename to reach to the parent directory ;..;Image Used:/auto/n3keagleinteg/daily_build/fiji_ecats/nexus/5/src/build/images/final/n3000-uk9.6.0.2.U2.0.5.bin/auto/n3keagleinteg/daily_build/fiji_ecats/nexus/5/src/build/images/final/n3000-uk9-kickstart.6.0.2.U2.0.5.bin

Title: PSIRT: Hedgehog in the Fog IPv6 data exfiltration
RNE: $$IGNORE-PSIRT  Symptoms:  Conditions:  Workaround:  Further Problem Description:  PSIRT Evaluation: The Cisco PSIRT has evaluated this issue and does not meet the criteria for PSIRT ownership or involvement. This issue will be addressed via normal resolution channels.  If you believe that there is new information that would cause a change in the severity of this issue, please contact psirt@cisco.com for another evaluation.  Additional information on Cisco's security vulnerability policy can be found at the following URL:  http://www.cisco.com/en/US/products/products_security_vulnerability_policy.html
Description: A customer requested Cisco comment on the 'Hedgehog in the Fog' tools and methodology outlined here:Abstract: https://ccdcoe.org/multimedia/hedgehog-fog-creating-and-detecting-ipv6-transition-mechanism-based-information.htmlReport: https://ccdcoe.org/sites/default/files/multimedia/pdf/ip6eva_0.pdfnc64 exfiltration tool: https://github.com/lockout/nc64tun64 tunneling tool: https://github.com/lockout/tun64--nc64 breaks data across multiple sessions using both IPv4 and IPv6 to avoid reassembly and detection--tun64 is used to tunnel IPv6 sessions over dual stack IPv4 networks. --The report gives low marks to Snort, but this appears to be primarily due to a lack of rules that would match the data exfiltration techniques.--The report raises some concerns about session tracking/reassembly and IPv6 inspection that are potentially relevant to the Firepower line-- Top concerns from the report are from a rule perspective. However, it appears that a review of how Snort handles at least the nc64 technique is justifiedPer discussion with PSIRT team, filing a bug is the preferred method to initiate a review.
PSIRT: Closing out investigation per messaging from Firepower TAC Lead:  From: "Adam Kilgore (akilgore)" <akilgore@cisco.com> Date: Wednesday, August 23, 2017 at 05:19 To: "(mgerencs) Wade Gerencser" <mgerencs@cisco.com>, "Jigesh Patel (jigespat)" <jigespat@cisco.com> Cc: "Lokesh Bevinamarad (lbevinam)" <lbevinam@cisco.com>, Terri Grant <tfinn@cisco.com>, "Ashwin Shimoga Nanjunda Rao (ashimoga)" <ashimoga@cisco.com>, "psirt-reply-in@cisco.com" <psirt-reply-in@cisco.com>, "Bhargava Jandhyala (bjandhya)" <bjandhya@cisco.com>, "Cynthia Leonard (cyleonar)" <cyleonar@cisco.com> Subject: Re: CSCve17389 I Comments [PSIRT-1818865758]   Hi Wade,   TALOS completed their review in bug 328305. If you have access to the TALOS bug system, you can review the data here:   https://bugzilla.vrt.sourcefire.com/show_bug.cgi?id=328305   Below is the final summary from the bug:   ?I'm happy to inform you that coverage for the exfiltration techniques that can be covered in this paper has had coverage committed, or exists already.   In addition to the DNS tunneling indicators in Comment #10, we've also got the following rules to detect different types of data exfiltration:   For the SSH tunneling, since its encrypted, we can't detect the traffic, however, for ssh on non-standard ports, we have SID 13586.   For ICMP tunneling, we have a rule to detect ptunnel, SID 21853. Additionally, we have SIDS 384 and 29456 for unusual ICMP traffic.   Like stated in Comment # 9, we cannot provide detection for the NC64 proof of concept tool. Its designed to work over multiple tcp/udp connections and evades the session requirement of snort.   The Tun64 tool does ipv6 in ipv4 by packing an ipv6 connection into an ipv4 packet, and setting the ipv4 protocol to 0x41, which is the ipv6 protocol indicator. We have a rule to detect this, SID 8446. The snort_decoder can also detect these kinds of sessions when encapsulated inside of a GRE packet, which is a feature the tool also provides. However, we can't directly detect TUN64, as all of the data it contains is in plain text.   Finally, for the HTTPtunnel tool, SID 43565 was just committed to detect this proxy tool, and will be available in an upcoming release.   Here's the full list of SIDS we offer to detect data exfiltration using these techniques:   13586 21853 384 29456 8446 43565 21355 30881 19187 27046 ?   The above references comment 9 and comment 10:   Comment 9: ?I took a look at the nc64 tool.   NC64 works by taking the data meant for covert exfiltration and sending it across multiple randomly chosen ipv4/ipv6 connections. This bypasses normal detection because there are multiple sessions.   Unfortunately, because there are multiple random ipv4/ipv6 connections, we cannot write plain-text rule for the nc64 tool.   I will continue investigating the tun64 tool, as well as some of the ipv6 exfiltration mechanisms it uses. ?   Comment 10: ?I've been working on this as I can, we have coverage for a lot of the tools inside the bug, here are a few of the sids and the tools that are covered by them:   dnscat: 30881 Iodine dns tunnel: 27046   Generic dns rules for possible tunneling attempts: 21355 30881 19187     I'm still working on a few of the other tunneling mechanisms like httptunnel and tun64, and once I have some more information regarding those, I will update this bug.?       Thanks, Adam Kilgore Firepower TAC ? Technical Lead Email: akilgore@cisco.com | Phone:  1 919 574 6471 Hours: M-F, 8:00AM ? 4:00PM EDT (GMT ?4) . : | : . : | : .

Title: MSDP-peered Router joined to a multicast group may crash
RNE: Summary A vulnerability in the Multicast Source Discovery Protocol (MSDP) implementation of Cisco IOS Software and Cisco IOS XE Software could allow a  remote, unauthenticated attacker to cause a reload of an affected device. Repeated attempts to exploit this vulnerability could result in a sustained  denial of service (DoS) condition.   Cisco has released free software updates that address this vulnerability. Workarounds that mitigate this vulnerability are available. This advisory is  available at the following link: http://tools.cisco.com/security/center/content/CiscoSecurityAdvisory/cisco-sa-20120328-msdp  Note: The March 28, 2012, Cisco IOS Software Security Advisory bundled publication includes nine Cisco Security Advisories. Each advisory lists the  Cisco IOS Software releases that correct the vulnerability or vulnerabilities detailed in the advisory as well as the Cisco IOS Software releases that  correct all vulnerabilities in the March 2012 bundled publication.   Individual publication links are in ''Cisco Event Response: Semiannual Cisco IOS Software Security Advisory Bundled Publication'' at the following link:  http://www.cisco.com/web/about/security/intelligence/Cisco_ERP_mar12.html   PSIRT Evaluation: The Cisco PSIRT has assigned this bug the following CVSS version 2 score. The Base and Temporal CVSS scores as of the time of evaluation are  7.1/5.9: http://tools.cisco.com/security/center/cvssCalculator.x?vector=AV:N/AC:M/Au:N/C:N/I:N/A:C/E:F/RL:OF/RC:C&version=2.0 CVE ID CVE-2012-0382 has been assigned to document this issue. Additional information on Cisco's security vulnerability policy can be found at the following URL: http://www.cisco.com/en/US/products/products_security_vulnerability_policy.html
Description: We have (4) customers whose ASK1004 routers started crashing yesterday.  Eachdevice has crashed multiple times.  These crashes have been reported on12.2(33)XND1, 12.2(33)XNF2, 15.0(1)S1 and 15.1(2).S1.  The decodes for allversions of IOS have been the same. Common configuration in all setups is MSDP.unconfiguring ;ip sap listen; and ;ip igmp join-group 224.2.127.254; stops thecrashing (and does not alter multicast functionality)

Title: The length of GET requests accepted by IronPort appliances is unlimited
RNE: Symptom: IronPort appliances do not limit the length of GET requests  Conditions: In certain conditions, when a IronPort appliance receives a particularly long GET request, it may cause a high CPU condition and significant amount of disk I/O operations.  Workaround: None PSIRT Evaluation: The Cisco PSIRT has assigned this bug the following CVSS version 2 score. The Base and Temporal CVSS scores as of the time of evaluation are 5/4.8: http://tools.cisco.com/security/center/cvssCalculator.x?vector=AV:N/AC:L/Au:N/C:N/I:N/A:P/E:F/RL:U/RC:C&version=2.0 CVE ID CVE-2012-4626 has been assigned to document this issue. Additional information on Cisco's security vulnerability policy can be found at the following URL: http://www.cisco.com/en/US/products/products_security_vulnerability_policy.html  Further Problem Description:
Description: Actually I think there are several issues here, which maybe should be reported separately.I. The length of GET/POST requests accepted by our appliances is unlimited.II. Online help is accessible by unauthorized users.III. I think that one problematic place is using LDAP/RADIUS/MAILBOX authfor quarantine and LDAP/RADIUS to manage appliance.I. I can send following GET request to the applaince.GET /;A;*100000000 HTTP/1.1An appliance will process such request:-- the whole request is written to logs;-- application error occurs (and remote user gets information about internal error with appfault page);-- significant amount of disk I/O operations;-- logs rollovered;-- high CPU usage by gui process;II. Are there serious reasons why we should keep full online help openedfor unauthenticated sessions?I think that if online help is settled on our appliance then search is doneusing appliance's system resources?In my case I saw how search requests pegs CPU up to 100%.III. Will update results related to external auth soon. Will attach python script written to make repro more simple. Please adjust script for your needs and sorry for hard-coding :))Setup : 1. Image appliance with build 7.5.0-4462. Login with raccount to view top output.3. Tail needed logs.Steps :1. Try to send requests This request will flood gui_logs and force log rolloverself.req_param = ;A;*100000000url = ;/help/wwhelp/wwhimpl/js/html/panelnav.htm?WWHSearchWordsText=%s&WWHSearchScope=All+Available+Books; % self.req_paramThis request will flood gui_logs and force log rollover + causes appfaultself.req_param = ;A;*100000000url = ;/%s; % self.req_paramThis request will flood auth_logs and force log rolloverurl = ;/login?action=Login&referrer=&screen=login&password=%s&username=admin ;% self.req_paramYou can experiment with different requests, try several threads at once and so on.Please refer Bug: 76819 in bugzilla

Title: TFTP Request for Unprovisioned Phone/Config Creates Race in sec_db
RNE: Symptom: Due to a design limitation of the phone proxy feature of the Cisco Adaptive Security Appliance (ASA), it is possible for a race condition to occur for entries in the phone proxy connection database. This could allow a malicious user to pass traffic from an untrusted phone through the ASA.  Conditions: ASA configured for the phone proxy feature.  Workaround: None.  PSIRT Evaluation: The Cisco PSIRT has assigned this bug the following CVSS version 2 score. The Base and Temporal CVSS scores as of the time of evaluation are 4.3/3.9: http://tools.cisco.com/security/center/cvssCalculator.x?vector=AV:N/AC:M/Au:N/C:N/I:P/A:N/E:POC/RL:U/RC:C&version=2.0 CVE ID CVE-2014-0739 has been assigned to document this issue.  Additional details about the vulnerability described here can be found at: http://tools.cisco.com/security/center/content/CiscoSecurityNotice/CVE-2014-0739  Additional information on Cisco's security vulnerability policy can be found at the following URL: http://www.cisco.com/en/US/products/products_security_vulnerability_policy.html  Further Problem Description:
Description: When phone_proxy_process_config_req() code found in Xpix/inspect/phone-proxy/phone_proxy_tftp_client.c handles a TFTP file request, it creates an entry into the security database BEFORE it attempts to receive the file from the call manager. Thus, the MAC address which is mapped to the TFTP request becomes trusted. Only after the request to the call manager for said file fails is the phone/MAC address removed from the security database. This window of time allows an external attacker to use an unprovisioned phone to bypass the security assurances of the ASA.An entry should be created into the security database only AFTER the file is successfully retrieved from the call manager, thus removing the 'trust' race.In code snippet below, pp_find_create_secure_device() ALWAYS creates an entry if one is not found.        /*         * If the request was for a signed file, the phone may have already         * be in secure mode and somehow it lost its TLS connection and         * started to try to retrieve the config file again w/o first         * requesting a CTL file, hence causing the phone to not be in the         * secure database.  We will assume that it is secure capable here         * since it is requesting a signed file and create an entry for it here.         */        if (pp_find_create_secure_device(rt_pp, mac, clientip, client_vpifn)            == NULL) {            DBG_PP_TFTP_ERROR(;PP: Error, unable to create phone entry for ;                              ;%s:%i, %e, file requested: %s\n;,                              getpifname(client_vpifn), clientip, &mac,                              filename);            return IEC_DROP_SILENT;        } A remote unauthenticated attacker can exploit this race condition to connect to the call manager. He can then spoof SIP messages to the call manager, thus being able to impersonate phones, transfer calls, call external toll numbers, etc.

Title: Multicast UDP packet with dst port 68 cause process cmts_dhcp_prepro CPU high
RNE: $$IGNORE-PSIRT  Symptom: CPU high with process  ;cmts_dhcp_prepro ;  Conditions: cBR8 receive multicast UDP paccket with destination port 68  Workaround: ip access-list extended udp permit udp any 224.0.0.0 0.0.0.255 eq bootpc exit class-map match-all udp match access-group name udp exit policy-map udp class udp   police rate 1000 pps conform-action drop exceed-action drop exit exit control-plane service-policy input udp exit  Further Problem Description:
Description: Multicast UDP packet with dst port 68 cause process cmts_dhcp_prepro CPU high.Normally the DHCP packet should only be unicast or broadcast packet. But if a client on Cable side or WAN side send an UDP packet with dst address 224.x.x.x and dst port = 68, this kind of packet will be punted with cause 'Cable DHCP' and cBR8 will treate this packet as a CPU sent packet will not decrease the TTL of the packet. The packet will be also sent back the incoming interface. CPU wiil goes high with process ;cmts_dhcp_prepro; if cBR8 keep receiving this kind of packet.

Title: Cisco Unified MeetingPlace Plain Text Password Vulnerability
RNE: Symptoms: A vulnerability in Cisco Unified MeetingPlace could allow an authenticated, remote attacker to view passwords in plain text.  The vulnerability is due to the inclusion of sensitive information in webpage source code. An attacker could exploit this vulnerability to view passwords in plain text format.  Conditions: Device running with default configuration running an affected version of software.  Workaround: None.  Further Problem Description: None.  PSIRT Evaluation: The Cisco PSIRT has assigned this bug the following CVSS version 2 score. The Base and Temporal CVSS scores as of the time of evaluation are 4/3.3: http://tools.cisco.com/security/center/cvssCalculator.x?vector=AV:N/AC:L/Au:S/C:P/I:N/A:N/E:F/RL:OF/RC:C&version=2.0  CVE ID CVE-2015-4214 has been assigned to document this issue.  Additional information on Cisco's security vulnerability policy can be found at the following URL: http://www.cisco.com/en/US/products/products_security_vulnerability_policy.html
Description: Security Assurance identified pages within the MP Application server Administration web interface that store system passwords in clear-text. These pages disclose passwords for backup, archiving and databases.Nagigate to Maintenance > Backup and Archive Enter the details for Backup and Archive including userid and passwordSAVEIf you look at the source code for this page you are given the username and password in clear text in the page sourcep>Pathname location of archive Remote archive host Remote host username Remote host password Notification email

Title: Nessus scan of UCSM lists- SSL Server Accepts Weak Diffie-Hellman Keys
RNE: Symptoms: Cisco Unified Computing System (UCS) Manager running on the UCS Fabric Interconnect includes a version of OpenSSL that is affected by the vulnerabilities identified by the following Common Vulnerability and Exposures (CVE) IDs:  CVE-2011-5095: The Diffie-Hellman key-exchange implementation in OpenSSL 0.9.8, when FIPS mode is enabled, does not properly validate a public parameter, which makes it easier for man-in-the-middle attackers to obtain the shared secret key by modifying network traffic, a related issue to CVE-2011-1923. This has been classified by the vendor as having a CVSSv2 score of 4.0 (AV:N/AC:H/AU:N/C:P/I:P/A:N)  Cisco has analyzed these vulnerabilities and concluded that the product is not impacted  Conditions: Not applicable  Workaround: Not applicable  Further Problem Description: Additional details about the vulnerabilities listed above can be found at http://cve.mitre.org/cve/cve.html  PSIRT Evaluation: The Cisco PSIRT has evaluated this issue and does not meet the criteria for PSIRT ownership or involvement. This issue will be addressed via normal resolution channels.  If you believe that there is new information that would cause a change in the severity of this issue, please contact psirt@cisco.com for another evaluation.  Additional information on Cisco's security vulnerability policy can be found at the following URL: http://www.cisco.com/en/US/products/products_security_vulnerability_policy.html
Description: Problem Description:--------------------Nessus scan on UCSM lists ;Nessus ID : 53360  SSL Server Accepts Weak Diffie-Hellman Keys Please go through the attached Nessus report, the possible solution will be to upgrade OpenSSL to 1.0.0This defect is filed for tracking purpose since the openSSL upgrade to 1.0.0 is already in the UCSM security road map.

Title: Cisco NX-OS Python Parser Escape Vulnerability
RNE: Symptom: A vulnerability in the Python scripting subsystem of Cisco NX-OS System Software could allow an authenticated, local attacker to escape the python parser and gain unauthorized access to the underlying operating system of the device.  The vulnerability exists due to insufficient sanitization of user supplied parameters passed to certain Python functions within the scripting sandbox of the affected device. An attacker could exploit this vulnerability to escape the scripting sandbox and execute arbitrary commands on the underlying operating system with the privileges of the authenticated user.  This advisory is available at the following link: https://tools.cisco.com/security/center/content/CiscoSecurityAdvisory/cisco-sa-20171018-ppe  Conditions: To exploit this vulnerability, an attacker must have local access and be authenticated to the targeted device with administrative or python execution privileges. These requirements could limit the possibility of a successful exploit.  Workaround: There are no workarounds that address this vulnerability.  A mitigation for this vulnerability is to ensure administrators have restricted python sandbox access to only highly trusted users.  Further Problem Description: For information about vulnerable and not vulnerable software releases, and time frame for fixed software releases, please open a support case with your support organization. PSIRT does not provide or maintain this information for Medium SIR advisories.  Credit: Cisco would like to thank Network Engineer Cody Winkler for finding and reporting this vulnerability.  PSIRT Evaluation: The Cisco PSIRT has assigned this bug the following CVSS version 3 score. The Base CVSS score as of the time of evaluation is 4.2: https://tools.cisco.com/security/center/cvssCalculator.x?version=3.0&vector=CVSS:3.0/AV:L/AC:L/PR:H/UI:N/S:U/C:L/I:L/A:L/E:X/RL:X/RC:X  CVE ID CVE-2017-12301 has been assigned to document this issue.  Additional information on Cisco's security vulnerability policy can be found at the following URL: http://www.cisco.com/en/US/products/products_security_vulnerability_policy.html

Title: Cisco Meshed Wireless LAN Controller Impersonation Vulnerability
RNE: Symptom: A vulnerability in the mesh code of Cisco Wireless LAN Controller (WLC) software could allow an unauthenticated, remote attacker to impersonate a WLC in a meshed topology.  The vulnerability is due to insufficient authentication of the parent access point in a mesh configuration. An attacker could exploit this vulnerability by forcing the target system to disconnect from the correct parent access point and reconnect to a rogue access point owned by the attacker. An exploit could allow the attacker to control the traffic flowing through the impacted access point or take full control of the target system.  Cisco has released software updates that address this vulnerability. Note that additional configuration is needed in addition to upgrading to a fixed release. There are no workarounds that address this vulnerability.  This advisory is available at the following link: https://tools.cisco.com/security/center/content/CiscoSecurityAdvisory/cisco-sa-20170315-wlc-mesh  Conditions: See advisory  Workaround: See advisory  Further Problem Description: PSIRT Evaluation: The Cisco PSIRT has assigned this bug the following CVSS version 3 score. The Base CVSS score as of the time of evaluation is 8.8: https://tools.cisco.com/security/center/cvssCalculator.x?version=3.0&vector=CVSS:3.0/AV:A/AC:L/PR:N/UI:N/S:C/C:H/I:L/A:L/E:X/RL:X/RC:X  CVE ID CVE-2017-3854 has been assigned to document this issue.  Additional information on Cisco's security vulnerability policy can be found at the following URL: http://www.cisco.com/en/US/products/products_security_vulnerability_policy.html
Description: Rogue MAP joining your own RAP.Condition :-If you use Wildcard on AAA to allow any MAC address to connect.and-MAP can reach primary WLC ( on public IP ) via network.Effectively, you can gain access to inside network by creating open ssid and/or plugging a switch to the MAP.Example : TWC's AP (Intruder with Rogue AP ) can mesh to Cable Vision RAP and if TWC WLC ( Intruder with Rogue WLC ) is on public ip, TWC MAP ( Intruder Rogue MAP ) can join TWC (Intruder) WLC and effectively able to gain access.Workaround :-Do not use wildcard on AAA server..But to scale 20,000 APs, it is not possible to manually enter so many devices.-Block Capwap ports going out to Internet.Note: LSC won't prevent as after MAP authentication is done, MAP initiates a capwap discovery to its configured Primary WLC. So AP joins the Intruder's WLC.
PSIRT: PSIRT-owner: trfridle           PSIRT is reviewing this issue for possible inclusion in a Cisco Security  Advisory which could include this DDTs. Title: Cisco Wireless LAN Controller Radius Packet of Disconnect Vulnerability
RNE: Symptom: A vulnerability in the radius implementation of the Cisco Wireless LAN Controller (WLC) could allow an unauthenticated,  remote attacker to cause a partial denial of service (DoS) condition by disconnecting user sessions.  The vulnerability is due to lack of proper input validation of the Radius Disconnect-Request packet. An attacker could  exploit this vulnerability by sending crafted Radius UDP Disconnect-Request packets to the affected device. An exploit  could allow the attacker to cause a partial DoS condition due to the disconnect of random user sessions.  Conditions: Device running with default configuration running an affected version of software.  Workaround: Do not enable CoA/RFC3576 on the radius auth servers Use netwrok ACLs to restrict who can send radius traffic to controller  Further Problem Description: Fixed Versions 8.0.130.0  or higher 8.1.131.0  8.2.102.0 or higher  Credit: Cisco would like to thank security researcher Herwin Weststrate from Quarantainenet BV  for reporting this vulnerability.  PSIRT Evaluation: The Cisco PSIRT has assigned this bug the following CVSS version 2 score. The Base and Temporal CVSS scores as of the time of evaluation are 5/4.3: http://tools.cisco.com/security/center/cvssCalculator.x?vector=AV:N/AC:L/Au:N/C:N/I:N/A:P/E:F/RL:U/RC:UC&version=2.0 CVE ID CVE-2015-6302  has been assigned to document this issue. Additional information on Cisco's security vulnerability policy can be found at the following URL: http://www.cisco.com/en/US/products/products_security_vulnerability_policy.html
Description: This issue was reported to Cisco by an external security researcher:On a WLC-4400 we found behavior that might be classified as a securityrisk or a denial of service.Found on software version 7.0.250.0, reproduced on latest softwareversion: 7.0.252.0. Reproduction:- Configure WLC-4400 setup for mac-authentication- Connect a machine to the mac-portal- Example disconnect, without valid shared secret:echo 'Calling-Station-Id = 0025d329d9e3' | radclient -xcisco-wlc-4400.office.quarantainenet.nl:1700 disconnect foo  Sent Disconnect-Request Id 120 from 0.0.0.0:54717 to 10.101.1.106:1700length 34    Calling-Station-Id = ;0025d329d9e3;  (0) Reply verification failed: Received Disconnect-ACK packet fromhome server 10.101.1.106 port 1700 with invalid Response Authenticator! (Shared secret is incorrect.)The error above is reported by radclient, but the disconnect stillworks!We think this is not right, according to RFC 3576 and its successor RFC5176.https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc3576#section-2.3https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc5176#section-2.3https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc3576#section-5.1https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc5176#section-6.1If you spoof the ip-address of the radius-server (no problem on UDP), itseems you can disconnect every client without knowing the shared secret.

Title: Cisco Content Security Management Appliance Message Tracking XSS Vulnerability
RNE: Symptom: A vulnerability in the web-based management interface of isco Email Security Appliance (ESA)  and Content Security Management Appliance (SMA) could allow an unauthenticated, remote attacker  to conduct a cross-site scripting (XSS) attack against a user of the web-based management interface  of an affected device.  The vulnerability is due to insufficient validation of user-supplied input by the web-based management  interface of an affected device. An attacker could exploit this vulnerability by persuading a user of  the interface to click a crafted link. A successful exploit could allow the attacker to execute arbitrary  script code in the context of the interface or allow the attacker to access sensitive browser-based  information.  Conditions: A device running an affected version of software with message tracking configured.  Workaround: None.  Further Problem Description: Additional information about XSS attacks and potential mitigations can be found at:  http://www.cisco.com/en/US/products/cmb/cisco-amb-20060922-understanding-xss.html https://www.owasp.org/index.php/Cross-site_Scripting_(XSS)  PSIRT Evaluation: The Cisco PSIRT has assigned this bug the following CVSS version 3 score. The Base CVSS score as of the time of evaluation is 6.1: https://tools.cisco.com/security/center/cvssCalculator.x?version=3.0&vector=CVSS:3.0/AV:N/AC:L/PR:N/UI:R/S:C/C:L/I:L/A:N/E:X/RL:X/RC:X  CVE ID CVE-2017-6661 has been assigned to document this issue.  Additional information on Cisco's security vulnerability policy can be found at the following URL: http://www.cisco.com/en/US/products/products_security_vulnerability_policy.html

Title: Cisco WebEx Browser Extension Remote Code Execution Vulnerability
RNE: Symptom: A vulnerability in Cisco WebEx browser extensions for Google Chrome and Mozilla Firefox provided by Cisco WebEx Meeting Center could allow an unauthenticated, remote attacker to execute arbitrary code with the privileges of the affected browser on an affected system. This vulnerability affects the browser extensions for Cisco WebEx Meetings Server, Cisco WebEx Centers (Meeting Center, Event Center, Training Center, and Support Center), and Cisco WebEx Meetings when they are running on Microsoft Windows.  The vulnerability is due to a design defect in the extension. An attacker who can convince an affected user to visit an attacker-controlled web page or follow an attacker-supplied link with an affected browser could exploit the vulnerability. If successful, the attacker could execute arbitrary code with the privileges of the affected browser.  Conditions: This vulnerability affects all current, previous, and deprecated versions of the Cisco WebEx browser extensions for Chrome and Firefox for Windows.  Workaround: None.  Further Problem Description: Cisco has released software updates that address this vulnerability.  This advisory is available at the following link: https://tools.cisco.com/security/center/content/CiscoSecurityAdvisory/cisco-sa-20170717-webex  PSIRT Evaluation: The Cisco PSIRT has assigned this bug the following CVSS version 3 score. The Base CVSS score as of the time of evaluation is 9.6: https://tools.cisco.com/security/center/cvssCalculator.x?version=3.0&vector=CVSS:3.0/AV:N/AC:L/PR:N/UI:R/S:C/C:H/I:H/A:H/E:X/RL:X/RC:X  CVE ID CVE-2017-6753 has been assigned to document this issue.  Additional information on Cisco's security vulnerability policy can be found at the following URL: http://www.cisco.com/en/US/products/products_security_vulnerability_policy.html
Description: EXTERNAL REPORTER:I see several problems with the way sanitization works, and have produced a remote code execution exploit to demonstrate them. This extension has over 20M active Chrome users alone, FireFox and other browsers are likely to be affected as well.1. JSON parsing discrepancies.2. GpcScript verification Regex is incomplete.3. Whitelisted Function Calls are not necessarily safe to call.4. No prevention against downgrade attacks.See BIG DESCRIPTION for more information & examples.90 Disclosure Timer STARTS: JULY 6, 2017

Title: DHCP Denial of Service Vulnerability
RNE: Summary Cisco IOS Software contains a vulnerability that could allow an unauthenticated, remote attacker to cause a denial of service (DoS) condition. An attacker could exploit this vulnerability by sending a single DHCP packet to or through an affected device, causing the device to reload.   Cisco has released free software updates that address this vulnerability. A workaround that mitigates this vulnerability is available. This advisory is available at the following link: http://tools.cisco.com/security/center/content/CiscoSecurityAdvisory/cisco-sa-20120926-dhcp  Note: The September 26, 2012, Cisco IOS Software Security Advisory bundled publication includes nine Cisco Security Advisories. Eight of the advisories address vulnerabilities in Cisco IOS Software, and one advisory addresses a vulnerability in Cisco Unified Communications Manager. Each Cisco IOS Software Security Advisory lists the Cisco IOS Software releases that correct the vulnerability or vulnerabilities detailed in the advisory as well as the Cisco IOS Software releases that correct all Cisco IOS Software vulnerabilities in the September 2012 bundled publication.   Individual publication links are in "Cisco Event Response: Semi-Annual Cisco IOS Software Security Advisory Bundled Publication" at the following link: http://www.cisco.com/web/about/security/intelligence/Cisco_ERP_sep12.html   PSIRT Evaluation: The Cisco PSIRT has assigned this bug the following CVSS version 2 score. The Base and Temporal CVSS scores as of the time of evaluation are  7.8/6.4: http://tools.cisco.com/security/center/cvssCalculator.x?vector=AV:N/AC:L/Au:N/C:N/I:N/A:C/E:F/RL:OF/RC:C&version=2.0  CVE ID CVE-2012-4621 has been assigned to document this issue.  Additional information on Cisco's security vulnerability policy can be found at the following URL: http://www.cisco.com/en/US/products/products_security_vulnerability_policy.html

Title: openSSL Vulnerabilities on 1000v  1000v to NX-OS version 5.2(1)SV3(1.4)
RNE: $$IGNORE-PSIRT  Symptom: This Cisco Nexus 1000v (N1K) Series Switch includes a version of the Open Secure Socket Layer (OpenSS) product that is affected by the vulnerability identified by  the Common Vulnerability and Exposures (CVE) IDs:  CVE-2014-3569 CVE-2014-3570 CVE-2014-3571 CVE-2014-3572 CVE-2014-8275 CVE-2015-0204 CVE-2015-0205 CVE-2015-0206  Conditions: Exposure is not configuration dependent  Workaround: Not available.  Further Problem Description: The Secure Socket Layer (SSL) protocol allows for secure communication between a client and a server. The client  usually authenticates the server using an algorithm like RSA or DSS. Some SSL ciphers allow SSL communication  without authentication. Most common Web browsers like Microsoft Internet Explorer, Netscape and Mozilla do not use  anonymous authentication ciphers by default. A vulnerability exists in SSL communications when clients are allowed  to connect using no authentication algorithm. SSL client-server communication may use several different types of  authentication: RSA, Diffie-Hellman, DSS or none. When 'none' is used, the communications are vulnerable to a  man-in-the-middle attack.''  The following ciphers are reported which require no authentication:  AECDH-RC4-SHA AECDH-DES-CBC3-SHA AECDH-AES128-SHA AECDH-AES256-SHA  PSIRT Evaluation: The Cisco PSIRT has assigned this bug the following CVSS version 2 score. The Base and Temporal CVSS scores as of the time of evaluation are 5/3.7: http://tools.cisco.com/security/center/cvssCalculator.x?vector=AV:N/AC:L/Au:N/C:N/I:N/A:P/E:U/RL:OF/RC:C&version=2.0 CVE ID CVE-2014-3569, CVE-2014-3570, CVE-2014-3571, CVE-2014-3572, CVE-2014-8275, CVE-2015-0204, CVE-2015-0205, CVE-2015-0206 has  been assigned to document this issue.   Additional information on Cisco's security vulnerability policy can be found at the following URL: http://www.cisco.com/en/US/products/products_security_vulnerability_policy.html

Title: ASA does not properly validate client cert during VPN auth ( Impacted release 9.4, 9.5 ,9.6 )
RNE: $$IGNORE-PSIRT  CISCO HIGHLY CONFIDENTIAL - CONTROLLED ACCESS  This issue is under review by the Cisco Product Security Incident Response team (PSIRT).  The defect describes a product security vulnerability.  Its contents must be protected from unauthorized disclosure, both internal and external to Cisco.  Do not forward this information to mailing lists or newsgroups.  Documentation writers: it is prohibited to publish this Release-note  Enclosure (RNE) until the content has been approved by PSIRT.  PSIRT may  publish a Security Advisory regarding this defect, and the current text of  this RNE will be replaced with appropriate information.  In the event that  a Security Advisory is not published, PSIRT will replace this text with an  appropriate explanation.  More information on PSIRT is available at http//psirt.cisco.com/.   Cisco's public policy on security vulnerability handling can be reviewed at  http://www.cisco.com/en/US/products/products_security_vulnerability_policy.html. For further information, send a message to psirt@cisco.com.  (marmclau-10/19/17)$$IGNORE-PSIRT  Symptom:  Conditions:  Workaround:  Further Problem Description:
Description: The ASA does not correctly verify the signature of the hash generated as part of the CertificateVerify handshake message.  This results in the ASA accepting that any client that presents a valid client certificate is in possession of the private key for that certificate when in fact it is not.  See EWOK (Entry With Other Key) Exploit PoC for repro steps.This issue has been reproduced onBroken:asa944-5-lfbff-k8.SPAasa944-6-lfbff-k8.SPAasa944-8-lfbff-k8.SPAasa944-10-lfbff-k8.SPAasa944-12-lfbff-k8.SPAWorking Properlyasa942-11-lfbff-k8.SPAasa943-lfbff-k8.SPAasa951-lfbff-k8.SPAasa982-lfbff-k8.SPA

Title: ACS 5 / reflected XSS vulnerability
RNE: Symptom: A vulnerability in The Cisco Access Control Server (ACS) could allow an unauthenticated, remote attacker to to conduct a cross-site scripting (XSS) attack.  The vulnerability is due to improper input validation of certain parameters passed to an affected device. An attacker could exploit this vulnerability by convincing a user to follow a malicious link. An exploit could allow the attacker to execute arbitrary script code in the context of the affected site or allow the attacker to access sensitive browser-based information.  Conditions: Device running with default configuration running an affected version of software.  Workaround: None.  Further Problem Description: None.  PSIRT Evaluation: The Cisco PSIRT has assigned this bug the following CVSS version 2 score. The Base and Temporal CVSS scores as of the time of evaluation are 4.3/4.3: http://tools.cisco.com/security/center/cvssCalculator.x?vector=AV:N/AC:M/Au:N/C:N/I:P/A:N/E:H/RL:U/RC:C&version=2.0 CVE ID  CVE-2015-0728 has been assigned to document this issue. Additional information on Cisco's security vulnerability policy can be found at the following URL: http://www.cisco.com/en/US/products/products_security_vulnerability_policy.html
Description: A security researcher reached out with findings about an XSS vulnerability. See enclosed report.
PSIRT: PSIRT-owner: psirt@cisco.com           This issue has been evaluated and driven to closure by PSIRT.  PSIRT has provided a public Release-note Enclosure (RNE) for this issue which is visible on Cisco.com.   If a customer is being impacted by this issue, please guide them to the 'Workaround' section of the RNE or recommend a software upgrade to a patched release.   If a patched release is not available  for the customer-specific situation, you will need to escalate the issue  through the DE manager or the business unit that owns the DDTs defect.  There is no need to contact PSIRT for this issue.  Do not provide customers with any information beyond what is currently contained in the RNE.

Title: Cisco UCS Central Software Arbitrary Command Execution Vulnerability
RNE: Symptom: A vulnerability in the web framework of the Cisco UCS Central Software could allow an unauthenticated, remote attacker to execute arbitrary commands on the affected device.  The vulnerability is due to improper input validation. An attacker could exploit this vulnerability by sending a crafted HTTP request to an affected device. An exploit could allow the attacker to execute arbitrary commands on the underlying operating system.  Conditions: Device configured with default configuration.  Workaround: None.  Further Problem Description: None.  PSIRT Evaluation: The Cisco PSIRT has assigned this bug the following CVSS version 2 score. The Base and Temporal CVSS scores as of the time of evaluation are 10/8.3: http://tools.cisco.com/security/center/cvssCalculator.x?vector=AV:N/AC:L/Au:N/C:C/I:C/A:C/E:F/RL:OF/RC:C&version=2.0 CVE ID CVE-2015-0701 has been assigned to document this issue. Additional information on Cisco's security vulnerability policy can be found at the following URL: http://www.cisco.com/en/US/products/products_security_vulnerability_policy.html
Description: UCSC Unauthenticated Remote Code Execution via downloadTechFile.cgiUnauthenticated remote users can run commands due to lack of input validation in the cgi script.Don't login to UCS Central:1. curl ;http://x.x.x.x/downloadTechFile.cgi?cookie=NoThanks&fileName=;/usr/bin/pg_dumpall%20-U%20postgres>/opt/cisco/www/visore/data.html&fileUrl=Whatever;2. open up webbrowser to http://x.x.x.x/visore/data.html and notice the entire UCS Central database was dumped

Title: Web Security Virtual Appliance Default Authorized SSH Key Vulnerability
RNE: Symptom: Cisco Web Security Virtual Appliance (WSAv), Cisco Email Security Virtual Appliance (ESAv), and Cisco Security Management Virtual Appliance (SMAv) are affected by the following vulnerabilities:      Cisco Virtual WSA, ESA, and SMA Default Authorized SSH Key Vulnerability     Cisco Virtual WSA, ESA, and SMA Default SSH Host Keys Vulnerability  Cisco has released free software updates that address these vulnerabilities. There are no workarounds for these vulnerabilities.  This advisory is available at the following link: http://tools.cisco.com/security/center/content/CiscoSecurityAdvisory/cisco-sa-20150625-ironport  Conditions: Please see the published Cisco Security Advisory.  Workaround: Please see the published Cisco Security Advisory.  Further Problem Description: PSIRT Evaluation: The Cisco PSIRT has assigned this bug the following CVSS version 2 score. The Base and Temporal CVSS scores as of the time of evaluation are 9.3/7.7:  http://tools.cisco.com/security/center/cvssCalculator.x?vector=AV:N/AC:M/Au:N/C:C/I:C/A:C/E:F/RL:OF/RC:C&version=2.0  CVE ID CVE-2015-4216 has been assigned to document this issue.  Additional information on Cisco's security vulnerability policy can be found at the following URL: http://www.cisco.com/en/US/products/products_security_vulnerability_policy.html
Description: any platform or version comes with a preinstalled authorized key stored at:/root/.ssh/authorized_keys(-enablediag)meaning, all customer is affectedPhysical Devices seem to have a ;unique; key set - ownership of private key is UNKNOWNVirtual appliances are having IAF authorized keys included - Private Key is part of IAF (used for repro)that should not exist to my understanding. sshd will allow anyone to connect, that has the corresponding private key found in that file with root privileges!Quick test:(1) download and install a fresh S300V (or any other Content Security Appliance):(2) only setup IP connectivity on the fresh installation, nothing else required(3) use iaf_dsa key to login with SSH (e.g. ssh -i iaf_dsa) whereas 1.2.3.4 is your installation(4) login as user ;enablediag; first to activate the service account, use any pw as it is not relevant(5) now reconnect to login as user ;service; that provides now full root shell access.Please refer to tac-repro for full detailed description.
PSIRT: PSIRT-owner: srasovic           PSIRT is reviewing this issue for possible inclusion in a Cisco Security  Advisory which could include this DDTs.  Please do not change the  Release-note Enclosure, as PSIRT will modify it appropriately when this  issue is made public.          Should customers request information regarding this DDTs or appear to be running into this DDTs within their network, please bring it to the immediate attention of the Cisco PSIRT at psirt@cisco.com.

Title: Cisco IPS Key Regeneration HTTPS Denial of Service Vulnerability
RNE: Symptom: A vulnerability in the SSL/TLS subsystem used by the web management interface of Cisco Intrusion Prevention System (IPS) software could allow an unauthenticated, remote attacker to cause a denial of service (DoS) condition.  The vulnerability is due to a potential race condition while regenerating the affected device's cryptographic certificate and keys during an upgrade to image 7.2 or later from an image prior to 7.2. An attacker could exploit this vulnerability by negotiating a number of HTTPS connections with the management interface while key regeneration is in process. A successful exploit could allow the attacker to create a DoS condition. The condition will persist until the device has been restarted.  The vulnerability can be triggered only by SSL/TLS traffic directed to the TCP port and IP address of the management interface associated with the web server. The default TCP port is 443. Packets transiting an affected device through the sensing interfaces cannot be used to trigger this vulnerability.  Conditions: Device Upgrade from pre-7.2 to 7.2 or later.  Workaround: Reboot, or to ensure a successful workaround, disconnect the management interface first.  Further Problem Description: PSIRT Evaluation: The Cisco PSIRT has assigned this bug the following CVSS version 2 score. The Base and Temporal CVSS scores as of the time of evaluation are 5.4/4.5: http://tools.cisco.com/security/center/cvssCalculator.x?vector=AV:N/AC:H/Au:N/C:N/I:N/A:C/E:F/RL:OF/RC:C&version=2.0  CVE ID CVE-2015-0631 has been assigned to document this issue.  Additional details about the vulnerability described here can be found at: http://tools.cisco.com/security/center/content/CiscoSecurityNotice/CVE-2015-0631  Additional information on Cisco's security vulnerability policy can be found at the following URL: http://www.cisco.com/en/US/products/products_security_vulnerability_policy.html
Description: From SR 626680129:During an upgrade to 7.2(1) an IPS will generate a TLS key on boot.If there are multiple HTTPS connections trying to connect to the IPS the IPS will go unresponsive and generate a core.txt on the main.app against generating the TLS key.CSM 4.3+ without the fix for CSCuf89842 can precipitate the issue

Title: Crash with IPsec Tunnel between 6500 w IPSEC-3 and ASR9000
RNE: Symptom: A 6500 reloads after negotiating an IPSec tunnel with ASR9000.  Conditions: The 6500 needs to run 12.2(33)SXJ8 and the IPsec engine must be a WS-SSC-600   WS-IPSEC-3 combination.  This crash does not happen with 7600-SSC-400   IPSEC-2 combination.  Workaround: No workaround known.  Further Problem Description: A vulnerability in the IKE subsystem of Cisco WS-IPSEC-3 service module could allow an authenticated, remote attacker to cause a reload of the Catalyst switch.  The vulnerability is due to insufficient bounds checks on a specific message during the establishment of an IPSEC tunnel. An attacker could exploit this vulnerability by successfully establishing an IKE session and sending the offending packet during subsequent negotiations. An exploit could allow the attacker to cause a denial of service by forcibly reloading the switch.  PSIRT Evaluation: The Cisco PSIRT has assigned this bug the following CVSS version 2 score. The Base and Temporal CVSS scores as of the time of evaluation are 4.9/4.9:  http://tools.cisco.com/security/center/cvssCalculator.x?vector=AV:N/AC:H/Au:S/C:N/I:N/A:C/E:H/RL:U/RC:C&version=2.0  CVE ID CVE-2015-0771 has been assigned to document this issue.  Additional information on Cisco's security vulnerability policy can be found at the following URL: http://www.cisco.com/en/US/products/products_security_vulnerability_policy.html
Description: During ASR9k + VSM EFT IPsec testing, we came across the following issue: When IPSec Tunnel is negotiated, between 6500 and ASR9000, the Cat6k crashes if the IPSEC engine is a WS-SSC-600 + WS-IPSEC-3 combination. No crash in case of 7600-SSC-400 and IPSEC-2 module.This crash is seen on two different 6500s with WS-SSC-600 + WS-IPSEC-3, hence no HW related.The crash is also seen in SXJ2 & SXJ7.The crash has always the same footprint:Nov 13 15:13:43.236: %DATACORRUPTION-1-DATAINCONSISTENCY: copy error,  -PC= 0x42EB036C-Traceback= 4058AF88 4059DE90 42EB036C 4176D4E8 433F82EC 433E1154 4340B630 434647FC 43464868 4340C024 4340C0C8 433D3C20 433D5D08 4168414C 41684138*Nov 13 15:13:43.236: %DATACORRUPTION-1-DATAINCONSISTENCY: copy error,  -PC= 0x42EB5844-Traceback= 4058AF88 4059DE90 42EB5844 42EB2DB0 42EB037C%ALIGN-1-FATAL: Corrupted  program counter 15:13:43 UTC Thu Nov 13 2014 pc=0x6DA287DA, ra=0x6DA287DA, sp=0x4A99E300 Early Notification of crash condition.. 15:13:43 UTC Thu Nov 13 2014: Address Error (load or instruction fetch) exception, CPU signal 10, PC = 0x6DA287DA0x4058AF88:data_inconsistency_error_with_original_ra(0x4058aefc)+0x8c0x4059DE90:__memcpy_to_buf(0x4059de40)+0x500x42EB036C:granikos_ipsec_key_create_by_qm(0x42eb0240)+0x12c0x4176D4E8:crypto_engine_ipsec_key_create_by_qm(0x4176d1a4)+0x3440x433F82EC:gen_ipsec_sa(0x433f7e34)+0x4b80x433E1154:prepare_ipsec_sas(0x433e1094)+0xc00x4340B630:ike_qm_fsm_send_qm2(0x4340b5bc)+0x740x434647FC:fsm_execute_internal(0x434646fc)+0x1000x43464868:fsm_execute(0x43464824)+0x440x4340C024:ike_qm_fsm_execute(0x4340bfe4)+0x400x4340C0C8:ike_ph2_fsm(0x4340c044)+0x840x433D3C20:crypto_isakmp_process_block(0x433d250c)+0x17140x433D5D08:crypto_isakmp_proc(0x433d57ec)+0x51c0x4168414C:r4k_process_dispatch(0x41684138)+0x140x41684138:r4k_process_dispatch(0x41684138)+0x0Enter hex value:Decode of stacktrace in crashinfo does not make sense.

Title: Cisco TP Conductor SDP Media Description DoS Vulnerability
RNE: Symptoms: Cisco TelePresence Video Communication Server (VCS), Cisco Expressway and Cisco TelePresence Conductor contain the following vulnerabilities:      SDP Media Description Denial of Service Vulnerability     Authentication Bypass Vulnerability  Successful exploitation of the SDP Media Description Denial of Service Vulnerability may cause the affected system to reload. Successful exploitation of the Authentication Bypass Vulnerability may allow an attacker to bypass authentication and log in to the system with the privileges of an administrator.  Cisco has released free software updates that address these vulnerabilities. Workarounds that mitigate these vulnerabilities are not available. This advisory is available at the following link: http://tools.cisco.com/security/center/content/CiscoSecurityAdvisory/cisco-sa-20150311-vcs  Conditions: See published Cisco Security Advisory  Workaround: See published Cisco Security Advisory  PSIRT Evaluation: The Cisco PSIRT has assigned this bug the following CVSS version 2 score. The Base and Temporal CVSS scores as of the time of evaluation are 7.8/6.4: http://tools.cisco.com/security/center/cvssCalculator.x?vector=AV:N/AC:L/Au:N/C:N/I:N/A:C/E:F/RL:OF/RC:C&version=2.0 CVE ID CVE-2015-0652 has been assigned to document this issue. Additional information on Cisco's security vulnerability policy can be found at the following URL: http://www.cisco.com/en/US/products/products_security_vulnerability_policy.html

Description: customer who experiences crashes on the 1900 platform whenever a PoE injector  Cisco DPSN-35FB (341-0212-01)is inserted  in the link between an IP-Phone and an Switch Cisco SG100-24. This SG 100-24 is connected to int Gi 0/0 of the router.c1900-universalk9-mz.153-1 .T.symbols.gz  read inEnter hex value: 0x23DF67C0z 0x228CC9D8z 0x228CCF60z 0x228D59F4z 0x228D6300z 0x228BBDB8z 0x228BC204z 0x228BC690z 0x228BC8E0z 0x23DE4920z 0x23DE4904z0x23DF67C0:__free(0x23df66f8)+0xc80x228CC9D8:dhcpd_dynamic_update(0x228cc8c0)+0x1180x228CCF60:dhcpd_dynamic_update_allocate(0x228ccc78)+0x2e80x228D59F4:dhcprequest(0x228d5684)+0x3700x228D6300:dhcp_server_receive(0x228d615c)+0x1a40x228BBDB8:dhcpd_receive_packet(0x228bbd20)+0x980x228BC204:dhcpd_read_packet(0x228bbfbc)+0x2480x228BC690:dhcpd_receive_loop(0x228bc268)+0x4280x228BC8E0:dhcpd_receive_process(0x228bc7b8)+0x1280x23DE4920:r4k_process_dispatch(0x23de4904)+0x1c0x23DE4904:r4k_process_dispatch(0x23de4904)+0x0- the device was crashing everyday till disconnect the POE injectors and the IP phones.Bypassing the SG100-24 did not prevent the router from crashing. Title: Nexus 5k Check to see if vulnerable to CVE-2008-1657
RNE: Symptoms:  This bug is to check the vulnerability of the Cisco Nexus 5000 to CVE-2008-1657.  The DE team has confirmed that this product is not affected. Additional details The ForceCommand directive is to force a command to be executed by the ssh server whenever a user logs in.  This ForceCommand option is not enabled by default in the code. PSIRT Evaluation: The Cisco PSIRT has evaluated this issue and does not meet the criteria for PSIRT ownership or involvement. This issue will be addressed via normal resolution channels. Title: Cisco Prime Infrastructure Web Framework Code Cross-Site Scripting Vulnerability
RNE: Symptom: A vulnerability in the web framework code of Cisco Prime Infrastructure could allow an unauthenticated, remote attacker to conduct a cross-site scripting (XSS) attack against the user of the web interface of the affected system.  The vulnerability is due to insufficient input validation of some parameters passed to the web server. An attacker could exploit this vulnerability by convincing the user to access a malicious link or by intercepting the user request and injecting the malicious code. An exploit could allow the attacker to execute arbitrary script code in the context of the affected site or allow the attacker to access sensitive browser-based information.  This advisory is available at the following link: https://tools.cisco.com/security/center/content/CiscoSecurityAdvisory/cisco-sa-20170419-cpi  Conditions: Exposure is not configuration dependent.  Workaround: There are no workarounds that address this vulnerability.   Further Problem Description Additional information about XSS attack and potential mitigations can be found at: http://www.cisco.com/en/US/products/cmb/cisco-amb-20060922-understanding-xss.html   PSIRT Evaluation: The Cisco PSIRT has assigned this bug the following CVSS version 3 score. The Base CVSS score as of the time of evaluation is 5.3: https://tools.cisco.com/security/center/cvssCalculator.x?version=3.0&vector=CVSS:3.0/AV:N/AC:L/PR:N/UI:N/S:U/C:N/I:L/A:N/E:X/RL:X/RC:X CVE ID CVE-2017-6611 has been assigned to document this issue.   Additional information on Cisco's security vulnerability policy can be found at the following URL: http://www.cisco.com/en/US/products/products_security_vulnerability_policy.html  Further Problem Description:
Description: /webacs/rs/ifmGrouping/groupingService/getDataCenterGroupsAtLevel/ComputeResource is vulnerable to Cross Site Scripting (XSS) via the parameter ;id;. This was found during an automated scan using HP WebInspect test tool. It is recommended to sanitize the input parameters properly.Here's a sample request to reproduce this:{{{GET /webacs/rs/ifmGrouping/groupingService/getDataCenterGroupsAtLevel/ComputeResource?id=0%3c%73%43%72%49%70%54%20%74%59%70%45%3d%74%45%78%54%2f%76%42%73%43%72%49%70%54%3e%4d%73%67%42%6f%78%28%38%32%32%35%38%29%3c%2f%73%43%72%49%70%54%3e&path=%2F&start=0 HTTP/1.1}}}

Title: IOS XR Software IPv6 Malformed Packet Denial of Service Vulnerability
RNE: Symptom: A vulnerability in the parsing of malformed IP version 6 (IPv6) packets in Cisco IOS XR Software for Cisco Network Convergence System 6000 (NCS 6000) and Cisco Carrier Routing System (CRS-X) could allow an unauthenticated, remote attacker to cause a reload of a line card that is processing traffic.  The vulnerability is due to improper processing of malformed IPv6 packets carrying extension headers. An attacker could exploit this vulnerability by sending a malformed IPv6 packet, carrying extension headers, through an affected Cisco IOS XR device line card. An exploit could allow the attacker to cause a reload of the line card on the affected Cisco IOS XR device.  Cisco has released free software updates that address this vulnerability.  There are no workarounds that address this vulnerability.  This advisory is available at the following link: http://tools.cisco.com/security/center/content/CiscoSecurityAdvisory/cisco-sa-20150220-ipv6  Conditions: Refer to the published Cisco Security Advisory  Workaround: Refer to the published Cisco Security Advisory  Further Problem Description: PSIRT Evaluation: The Cisco PSIRT has assigned this bug the following CVSS version 2 score. The Base and Temporal CVSS scores as of the time of evaluation are 7.1/5.9:  http://tools.cisco.com/security/center/cvssCalculator.x?version=2.0&vector=AV:N/AC:M/Au:N/C:N/I:N/A:C/E:F/RL:OF/RC:C  CVE ID CVE-2015-0618 has been assigned to document this issue.  Additional information on Cisco's security vulnerability policy can be found at the following URL: http://www.cisco.com/en/US/products/products_security_vulnerability_policy.html
Description: IOS XR Software Malformed IPv6 Packet flooding trigger LC reload

Title: AnyConnect Android Un-restrictive Activity Access Vulnerability
RNE: Symptom: A vulnerability in the exported activites of Cisco AnyConnect for Android could allow an unauthenticated, local attacker to send commands to the AnyConnect Client.  The vulnerability is due to insufficient permissions around the exported activities.  An exploit could allow an attacker to convince a user to perform a malicious action.  Conditions: Anyconnect Clien firr Android OS  Workaround: Not applicable or available.  Further Problem Description: PSIRT Evaluation: The Cisco PSIRT has assigned this bug the following CVSS version 2 score. The Base and Temporal CVSS scores as of the time of evaluation are 2.1/1.9: http://tools.cisco.com/security/center/cvssCalculator.x?vector=AV:L/AC:L/Au:N/C:N/I:P/A:N/E:POC/RL:U/RC:C&version=2.0  No CVE ID has been assigned to this issue.  Additional information on Cisco's security vulnerability policy can be found at the following URL: http://www.cisco.com/en/US/products/products_security_vulnerability_policy.html
Description: Customer Citi has reported following during their vulnerability test for AnyConnect Client 3.0.09431 for Android OS:Unrestrictive access to Activities leading to modification of the application from any other app CVA 1999Here's an example of an intent that can be called by any application which can create a popup box which a customized message that can trick the user into performing an unwanted action.dz> run app.activity.start ?action com.cisco.anyconnect.vpn.android.ACTION_SHOW_POPUP ?component com.cisco.anyconnect.vpn.android.avfcom.cisco.anyconnect.vpn.android.ui.PopupActivity ?m extra string com.cisco.anyconnect.vpn.android.POPUP_TEXT_KEY ?Call 1-800-hacker urgently?Customer requested comment/Action for Cisco:There's no reason why these activities need to be exported. If they need to be exported, there should be a permission defined to control access and that permission should probably be of type signature where only applications with the same developer have access. That is, there's no need for external applications to access these activities.

Title: Evaluation of arc-cuac for Java_December_2015
RNE: Symptom: Cisco Unified Attendant Console Advanced;Cisco Unified Attendant Console Business Edition;Cisco Unified  Attendant Console Department Edition;Cisco Unified Attendant Console Enterprise Edition;Cisco Unified  Attendant Console Premium Edition  includes a version of Commons Collections library that is affected by  the vulnerability identified by the Common Vulnerability and Exposures (CVE) IDs:  CVE-2015-6420  This product is affected by the listed CVE id.  Conditions: Exposure is not configuration dependent.  Workaround: Not available.  Further Problem Description: None.  :PSIRT Evaluation: The Cisco PSIRT has assigned this bug the following CVSS version 2 score. The Base and Temporal CVSS  scores as of the time of evaluation are: 7.5/7.1  http://tools.cisco.com/security/center/cvssCalculator.x? version=2&vector=AV:N/AC:L/Au:N/C:C/I:C/A:C/E:H/RL:U/RC:C  The Cisco PSIRT has assigned this score based on information obtained from multiple sources. This  includes the CVSS score assigned by the third-party vendor when available. The CVSS score assigned may  not reflect the actual impact on the Cisco Product.  Additional information on Cisco's security vulnerability policy can be found at the following URL:  http://www.cisco.com/web/about/security/psirt/security_vulnerability_policy.html
Description: PLEASE READ THIS ENTIRE DESCRIPTION AND THE INCLUDED LINKS BEFORE TAKING ANY ACTION.This defect is to track investigation of the recently reported Apache commons library vulnerability, and its impact on Cisco Unified Attendant Console Advanced;Cisco Unified Attendant Console Business Edition;Cisco Unified Attendant Console Department Edition;Cisco Unified Attendant Console Enterprise Edition;Cisco Unified Attendant Console Premium Edition Sofware product.http://www.kb.cert.org/vuls/id/576313On November 6, 2015 a remote execution vulnerability that affects multiple releases of Apache Commons, was published by Foxglove Security Group. They claim that this issue was disclosed in January 2015. The report contained detailed proof of concept code for a number of applications including WebSphere Application Server, JBoss, Jenkins, OpenNDS and WebLogic. This is a remotely exploitable vulnerability and allows a hacker to inject any malicious code or execute any commands that exist on the server that can result in wide range of possibilities including stealing sensitive information. Apache Commons has developed a patch(would assume they will be issuing an official patch soon too). Patching affected systems is required; no ;work around; is available.This bug has been filed against Cisco Unified Attendant Console Advanced;Cisco Unified Attendant Console Business Edition;Cisco Unified Attendant Console Department Edition;Cisco Unified Attendant Console Enterprise Edition;Cisco Unified Attendant Console Premium Edition to address the vulnerability/ies known as Java_December_2015 and identified by CVE(s): CVE-2015-4852INSTRUCTIONS:If your product ships with the vulnerable version of Java commons collection library you are required to:1. Assign the bug and CHANGE the severity from 7 to 2 (24 hours)2. Add the enclosure called ;Engineering Assessment; and describe what versions of your product are affected.3. Notify PSIRT of fixed version info and C
PSIRT: PSIRT-owner: srasovic   PSIRT is reviewing this issue for possible inclusion in a Cisco Security Advisory which could include this DDTs.  Please do not change the Release-note Enclosure, as PSIRT will modify it appropriately when this issue is made public.  Should customers request information regarding this DDTs or appear to be running into this DDTs within their network, please bring it to the immediate attention of the Cisco PSIRT at psirt@cisco.com.

Title: Evaluation of ciscocm for CVE-2016-7117
RNE: Symptom: Cisco Unified Communications Manager (CallManager) includes a version of the Linux kernel that is affected by the vulnerabilities identified by the following Common Vulnerability and Exposures (CVE) IDs:  CVE-2016-7117   This bug was opened to address the impact on this product.  Conditions: Default configuration  Workaround: CUCM 12.0 will include the fix. Tentative date of the release will be Aug 2017.  Further Problem Description: Additional details about the vulnerabilities listed above can be found at http://cve.mitre.org/cve/cve.html  PSIRT Evaluation: The Cisco PSIRT has assigned this bug the following CVSS version 3 score. The Base CVSS score as of the time of evaluation is 9.8: https://tools.cisco.com/security/center/cvssCalculator.x?version=3.0&vector=CVSS:3.0/AV:N/AC:L/PR:N/UI:N/S:U/C:H/I:H/A:H/E:X/RL:X/RC:X  CVE ID  has been assigned to document this issue.  Additional information on Cisco's security vulnerability policy can be found at the following URL: http://www.cisco.com/en/US/products/products_security_vulnerability_policy.html
Description: In December 2016 has been disclosed a vulnerability in the Linux kernel that may potentially results in arbitrary remote execution by a remote attacker:Use-after-free vulnerability in the __sys_recvmmsg function in net/socket.c in the Linux kernel before 4.5.2 allows remote attackers to execute arbitrary code via vectors involving a recvmmsg system call that is mishandled during error processing.all kernel versions before 4.5.2 are reported to be affected. The objective of this defect is to determine if the product is running an affected Linux kernel version, if so it's to be considered vulnerable, please mention in the defect notes which kernel version the product is using. The kernel version can be determined by running ;uname -a; or ;cat /proc/version; from a Linux shell.For further reference please see:https://web.nvd.nist.gov/view/vuln/detail?vulnId=CVE-2016-7117https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=CVE-2016-7117http://www.securityfocus.com/bid/93304

Title: PSIRT: Reporter  Servlet allows access to contents of local files
RNE: Symptom: The vulnerability is due to a failure to properly restrict paths passed to a specific API command.  An authenticated attacker could exploit the vulnerability by providing the absolute path to the file of interest to the affected API command.  Conditions: Reporter Servlet provides access to authenticated users to view the contents of some of the system files as well.  Workaround: None  Further Problem Description: A vulnerability in the API that supports the Real-Time Monitoring Tool (RTMT) shipped as part of Cisco Unified Communications Manager (CUCM) could allow an authenticated, remote attacker to disclose the contents of arbitrary files on an affected device.  PSIRT Evaluation: The Cisco PSIRT has assigned this bug the following CVSS version 2 score. The Base and Temporal CVSS scores as of the time of evaluation are 6.3/6: http://tools.cisco.com/security/center/cvssCalculator.x?vector=AV:N/AC:M/Au:S/C:C/I:N/A:N/E:F/RL:U/RC:C&version=2.0 CVE ID CVE-2014-8008 has been assigned to document this issue. Additional information on Cisco's security vulnerability policy can be found at the following URL: http://www.cisco.com/en/US/products/products_security_vulnerability_policy.html
Description: The Reporter Servlet API GetFileContent allow authenticated users to access contents of the CUCM's server local files, which should not be exposed to the end user.Eg:https://<ip>:8443/reporter-servlet/GetFileContent?Location=/&FileName=/usr/local/thirdparty/jakarta-tomcat/conf/tomcat-users.xmlThis gap leave the system susceptible to Local File Injection and allows access to source code and configuration files.

Title: CUCM does not encrypt LDAP password for end device page
RNE: $$IGNORE-PSIRT  $$IGNORE  Symptoms: This is a modification on the product to adopt new secure code best practices to enhance  the security posture and resiliency of the Cisco Unified Communications Manager.  The LDAP password for the end device should be encrypted and not saved in plain text within the browser.  Conditions: Device configured with default configuration.  Workaround: Not applicable or available.   Further Problem Description: This issue was found during an internal security audit of the product. This issue should not be made public as it is an internal hardening issue to be considered for integration.  PSIRT Evaluation: The Cisco PSIRT has evaluated this issue and does not meet the criteria for PSIRT ownership or involvement. This issue will be addressed via normal resolution  channels.  If you believe that there is new information that would cause a change in the severity of this issue, please contact psirt@cisco.com for another evaluation.  Additional information on Cisco's security vulnerability policy can be found at the following URL:  http://www.cisco.com/en/US/products/products_security_vulnerability_policy.html
Description: While allowing the browser to save the end device LDAP password, passwords are stored in the browser in clear text.Here are the steps to recreate the trick:1. Add any TCT device on the Call Manager (e.g. Cisco Dual Mode for iPhone)2. Save the LDAP username and password for this device.3. Open this device page from another system using a firefox browser.4. Once device page is opened, just click on SAVE and browser will prompt you to save the password. Click ;Remember Password;5. After this, you can go to saved password history and see the LDAP password there in the clear text.

Title: CUCM: Reflected XSS attack is possible on ccmadmin page
RNE: Symptom: The ccmadmin page of Cisco Unified Communications Manager does not properly sanitize or encode user-supplied data. This makes the web interface vulnerable to reflected cross-site scripting (XSS) attacks.  Conditions: Device running with default configuration running an affected version of software.  Workaround: None  Further Problem Description: Additional information about XSS attacks and potential mitigations can be found at:  https://tools.cisco.com/security/center/content/CiscoAppliedMitigationBulletin/cisco-amb-20060922-understanding-xss https://www.owasp.org/index.php/Cross-site_Scripting_(XSS)  PSIRT Evaluation: The Cisco PSIRT has assigned this bug the following CVSS version 2 score. Title: Security Issue in Apache
RNE: Summary A denial of service vulnerability has been found in the way the multiple overlapping ranges are handled by the Apache HTTPD server. Multiple Cisco products could be affected by this vulnerability.  Mitigations that can be deployed on Cisco devices within the network are available in the Cisco Applied Intelligence companion document for this Advisory: http://tools.cisco.com/security/center/viewAMBAlert.x?alertId=24024  This advisory is posted at http://www.cisco.com/warp/public/707/cisco-sa-20110830-apache.shtml.   PSIRT Evaluation: The Cisco PSIRT has assigned this bug the following CVSS version 2 score. The Base and Temporal CVSS scores as of the time of evaluation are 7.8/7.8:  http://tools.cisco.com/security/center/cvssCalculator.x?vector=AV:N/AC:L/Au:N/C:N/I:N/A:C/E:H/RL:U/RC:C&version=2.0  CVE ID CVE-2011-3192 has been assigned to document this issue.  Additional information on Cisco's security vulnerability policy can be found at the following URL: http://www.cisco.com/en/US/products/products_security_vulnerability_policy.html
Description: A vulnerability has been identified that affects the Apache HTTPd Web Server and is identified by CVE Identifier CVE-2011-3192. The issue affects all versions based on the 1.3, 2.0 and 2.2 code bases. The issue could allow an unauthenticated, remote attacker to create a denial of service (DoS) condition on an affected system or device. When exploited the Apache may consume a significant amount of Memory and CPU resources, and fail to respond to future requests.The Apache team plans to release updated software that mitigates this issue for the 2.0 and 2.2 codetrains in the next day or two. The 1.3 codetrain has been depreciated and will not receive an official fix. Additional Information can be obtained from:PSIRT Hotpage:https://psirt.cisco.com/PSIRThot/apache-rangeoverlap-dosApache Advisory: http://mail-archives.apache.org/mod_mbox/httpd-announce/201108.mbox/browserIntelliShield Alert ID 24004: http://tools.cisco.com/security/center/viewAlert.x?alertId=23983Actions Needed:1. Please assign to an engineer for evaluation, as soon as possible2. If the product is affected please patch as appropriate3. If the product is not affected please contact Omar Santos (os@cisco.com) from PSIRT and document why the product is found not to be affected on an enclosure in this CDETS entry.

Title: OSPF Rogue LSA with maximum sequence number vulnerability
RNE: Symptom: Multiple Cisco products are affected by a vulnerability involving the Open Shortest Path First (OSPF) Routing Protocol Link State Advertisement (LSA) database. This vulnerability could allow an unauthenticated, remote attacker to take full control of the OSPF Autonomous System (AS) domain routing table, allowing the attacker to intercept or black-hole traffic.  The attacker could exploit this vulnerability by injecting crafted OSPF packets. Successful exploitation could cause the targeted router to flush its routing table and propagate the crafted OSPF LSA type 1 update throughout the OSPF AS domain.  To exploit this vulnerability, an attacker must accurately determine certain parameters within the LSA database on the target router. This vulnerability can only be triggered by sending crafted unicast or multicast OSPF LSA type 1 packets. No other LSA type packets can trigger this vulnerability.  OSPFv3 is not affected by this vulnerability. Fabric Shortest Path First (FSPF) protocol is not affected by this vulnerability.  Workarounds that address this vulnerability are available.  This advisory is available at the following link: https://tools.cisco.com/security/center/content/CiscoSecurityAdvisory/cisco-sa-20170727-ospf  Conditions: Please refer to the security advisory.  Consult https://tools.cisco.com/security/center/selectIOSVersion.x for affected versions and first fixed releases.  Workaround: Please refer to the security advisory.  Further Problem Description: This vulnerability was found and reported to Cisco by Dr. Gabi Nakibly from Rafael Advanced Defense Systems.  PSIRT Evaluation:  The Cisco PSIRT has assigned this bug the following CVSS version 3 score. The Base CVSS score as of the time of evaluation is 4.2:  https://tools.cisco.com/security/center/cvssCalculator.x?version=3.0&vector=AV:N/AC:H/PR:N/UI:R/S:U/C:L/I:L/A:N/E:F/RL:O/RC:C  CVE ID CVE-2017-6770 has been assigned to document this issue.  Additional information on Cisco's security vulnerability policy can be found at the following URL: http://www.cisco.com/en/US/products/products_security_vulnerability_policy.html    Symptom:Conditions:Workaround:Further Problem Description:
Description: External researcher reported 15.1(4)MDeviation #1: Rogue LSA with maximum sequence numberA false LSA having the maximum sequence number was sent from Cloud 1 to R1. The false LSA had an LS ID and Advertising Router fields that corresponds to R1's ID. In response R1 flooded over all its interfaces a new LSA having maximum sequence number and maximum age in order to flush the false LSA from all the routers in the network. This action is expected and is in accordance with the OSPF specification. Following the reception of the LSA Acks from all its neighbors R1 was expected to send yet another LSA, but this time with the minimum sequence number. However, R1 does not send this LSA. As a result, the LSA of R1 is not installed in the LS DB of the routers in the network, causing their DB to be inconsistent with the actual network topology. This allows an attacker to send a spoofed LSA that persistently harms the routing in the network.Please contact psirt@cisco.com for further information including researcher report and trace files. This researcher also reported CSCtq32842 and CSCva74758.
