Title: high cpu after enabling dot1x on 2960 switch
RNE: Symptoms: A vulnerability in processing of crafted ARP packets of Cisco IOS 2960 switches could allow an unauthenticated, adjacent attacker to cause high CPU condition on the affected  device that may eventually cause loss of management sessions (telnet, ssh) to the switch.  The vulnerability is due to architectural limitations in the way that ARP packets are handled on 2960 switches when DPI or 802.1x are enabled. An attacker could exploit this  vulnerability by sending a flood of crafted ARP packets to be processed by an affected device. An exploit could allow the attacker to cause high CPU condition on the affected  device that may eventually cause loss of management sessions (telnet, ssh) to the switch.  Conditions: DPI or 802.1x enabled on the switch.  Workaround: None  Further Problem Description: PSIRT Evaluation: The Cisco PSIRT has assigned this bug the following CVSS version 2 score. The Base and Temporal CVSS scores as of the time of evaluation are 2.9/2.8: http://tools.cisco.com/security/center/cvssCalculator.x?vector=AV:A/AC:M/Au:N/C:N/I:N/A:P/E:F/RL:U/RC:C&version=2.0 No CVE ID has been assigned to this issue. Additional information on Cisco's security vulnerability policy can be found at the following URL: http://www.cisco.com/en/US/products/products_security_vulnerability_policy.html

Title: Cisco Jabber Guest Server Cross-site Scripting Vulnerability
RNE: Symptom: A vulnerability in the web-based management interface of Cisco Jabber Guest Server could allow an unauthenticated, remote attacker to conduct a cross-site scripting (XSS) attack against a user of the web-based management interface of the affected software.  The vulnerability is due to insufficient validation of user-supplied input by the web-based management interface of the affected software. An attacker could exploit this vulnerability by persuading a user of the interface to click a crafted link. A successful exploit could allow the attacker to execute arbitrary script code in the context of the interface or allow the attacker to access sensitive browser-based information.  There are no workarounds that address this vulnerability.  For additional information about cross-site scripting attacks and the methods used to exploit these vulnerabilities, see the Cisco Applied Mitigation Bulletin Understanding Cross-Site Scripting (XSS) Threat Vectors and the OWASP reference page Cross-site Scripting (XSS).  This advisory is available at the following link: https://tools.cisco.com/security/center/content/CiscoSecurityAdvisory/cisco-sa-20170802-cj  Conditions: Device running with default configuration running an affected version of software.  Workaround: None.  Further Problem Description: Additional information about XSS attacks and potential mitigations can be found at:  http://www.cisco.com/en/US/products/cmb/cisco-amb-20060922-understanding-xss.html https://www.owasp.org/index.php/Cross-site_Scripting_(XSS)  PSIRT Evaluation: The Cisco PSIRT has assigned this bug the following CVSS version 3 score. The Base CVSS score as of the time of evaluation is 6.1: https://tools.cisco.com/security/center/cvssCalculator.x?version=3.0&vector=CVSS:3.0/AV:N/AC:L/PR:N/UI:R/S:C/C:L/I:L/A:N/E:X/RL:X/RC:X  CVE ID CVE-2017-6762  has been assigned to document this issue.  Additional information on Cisco's security vulnerability policy can be found at the following URL: http://www.cisco.com/en/US/products/products_security_vulnerability_policy.html

Title: Cisco Aironet 1800/2800/3800 Series Access Point MAC Authentication Bypass Vulnerability
RNE: Symptom: A vulnerability in the implementation of Protected Extensible Authentication Protocol (PEAP) functionality for standalone configurations of Cisco Aironet 1800, 2800, and 3800 Series Access Points could allow an unauthenticated, adjacent attacker to bypass authentication and connect to an affected device.  The vulnerability exists because the affected device uses an incorrect default configuration setting of fail open when running in standalone mode. An attacker could exploit this vulnerability by attempting to connect to an affected device. A successful exploit could allow the attacker to bypass authentication and connect to the affected device.  There are no workarounds that address this vulnerability.  This advisory is available at the following link: https://tools.cisco.com/security/center/content/CiscoSecurityAdvisory/cisco-sa-20171101-aironet3  Conditions: This vulnerability exists in all releases prior to the first fixed software release.  The device is configured with a WLAN setting of Flexconnect local switching and a Central Authentication  with MAC filtering.  Workaround: None.  Further Problem Description: PSIRT Evaluation: The Cisco PSIRT has assigned this bug the following CVSS version 3 score. The Base CVSS score as of the time of evaluation is 6.1: https://tools.cisco.com/security/center/cvssCalculator.x?version=3.0&vector=CVSS:3.0/AV:A/AC:L/PR:N/UI:N/S:U/C:L/I:N/A:N/E:X/RL:X/RC:X  CVE ID CVE-2017-12281 has been assigned to document this issue.  Additional information on Cisco's security vulnerability policy can be found at the following URL: http://www.cisco.com/en/US/products/products_security_vulnerability_policy.html  Affected Releases All 8.1 All 8.2 before  8.2.160.0 All 8.3 before  8.3.121.0  Versions 8.0, 7.x, are not applicable  Fixed Releases 8.2.160.0 and higher, recommended 8.2.166.0 8.3.121.0 and higher, recommended 8.3.133.0 8.5.103.0 and higher, recommended 8.5.105.0  8.4.100.0
Description: Standalone COS AP should reject new client if MAC auth is configuredWLC version is 8.2.141.0.All AP are flexconnect mode.WLAN setting is Flexconnect local switching/central auth with MAC filtering.When client try to connect IOS AP which in Standalone mode, ALL NEW connection getting failed.That is expected behavior.However when client try to connect standalone COS AP,the result different from IOS AP, NEW connection passed with PEAP auth.Standalone COS AP should reject ANY new connection as same as IOS APNote:This is not request to Full MAC filter support on flexconnect COS APThat will be handled by enhancement DDTS, CSCvd11973.WLC configuration and E-mail discussion are attached.

Title: CTS Directory Information Disclosure Vulnerability
RNE: Symptoms: CTS will automatically switch to HTTP from HTTPS when retrieving directory information from CUCM if HTTPS connection is not available.  Conditions: CUCM is deployed with secure feature enabled  Workaround: none  Further Problem Description: A vulnerability in the code retrieving directory information of Cisco TelePresence System (CTS) could allow an unauthenticated, remote attacker to intercept and read the content of a directory transferred between the CTS and the Cisco Unified Call Manager (CUCM).  The vulnerability is due to failure to use enforce HTTPS for transferring directory content. An attacker could exploit this vulnerability by blocking the connection over HTTPS between the CTS and CUCM. Due to this vulnerability the CTS will try to then connect to the CUCM via HTTP so Directory information can be gathered by observing the communication between the CTS and CUCM.  PSIRT Evaluation: The Cisco PSIRT has assigned this bug the following CVSS version 2 score. The Base and Temporal CVSS scores as of the time of evaluation are 4.3/3.6: http://tools.cisco.com/security/center/cvssCalculator.x?vector=AV:N/AC:M/Au:N/C:P/I:N/A:N/E:F/RL:OF/RC:C&version=2.0 CVE ID CVE-2014-3274 has been assigned to document this issue.  Additional details about the vulnerability described here can be found at: http://tools.cisco.com/security/center/content/CiscoSecurityNotice/CVE-2014-3274  Additional information on Cisco's security vulnerability policy can be found at the following URL: http://www.cisco.com/en/US/products/products_security_vulnerability_policy.html
Description: Directory ALWAYS transferred to CTS Touch un:encrypted through HTTP:80Security Vulnerability:CTS devices with touch always use default http port 80 to fetch the directory from CUCM,It uses the following string, even in a secure environment:http://mCucmIp/cucm-uds/users?maxIt should be using the following in a secured environment:https://mCucmIP:8443/cucm-uds/users?maxThis is a major vulnerability due to1) Directory is not encrypted in an secure environment - Customer is led to believe that communication goes through secure channels when using a secured CUCM connection.2) It is not specified in CUCM documentation that port 80 has to be opened from endpoint towards CUCM. Directory will not work if firewall for CUCM is configured to follow the documentation ( http://www.cisco.com/en/US/docs/voice_ip_comm/cucm/port/9_1_1/CUCM_BK_T2CA6EDE_00_tcp-port-usage-guide-91_chapter_01.html ) 3) In an unsecured controlled environment the communication goes through port 80 while it should go through 8080This issue is customer found, and customer is running CUCM 9.1 and TX6.0.4 - issue is also occurring in 1.9.3I believe this issue is with the CTS touch code.
PSIRT: PSIRT-owner: psirt@cisco.com           This issue has been evaluated and driven to closure by PSIRT.  PSIRT has provided a public Release-note Enclosure (RNE) for this issue which is visible on Cisco.com. Title: 50892: API exposes ENTIRE Kubernetes platform without authentication - CUSTOMER driven
RNE: $$PREFCS  Symptom: The ICSP platform exposes the entire Kubernetes deployment through a single un authenticated API call.  When accessing the platform, from anywhere it's accessible, there's  a possibility to get full disclosure on anything since there's an open API that exposes every service, components and topology of the affected customer using the ICSP.  Conditions: Any admitted network access.  Workaround: Remove API all together.  Further Problem Description: None.  PSIRT Evaluation: The Cisco PSIRT has assigned this bug the following CVSS version 3 score. The Base CVSS score as of the time of evaluation is 7.5: https://tools.cisco.com/security/center/cvssCalculator.x?version=3.0&vector=CVSS:3.0/AV:N/AC:L/PR:N/UI:N/S:U/C:H/I:N/A:N/E:X/RL:X/RC:X  No CVE ID has been assigned to this issue.  Additional information on Cisco's security vulnerability policy can be found at the following URL: http://www.cisco.com/en/US/products/products_security_vulnerability_policy.html
Description: When running wget from a linux machine to https://<ICSP address>:9443 {  ;paths;: [    ;/api;,    ;/api/v1;,    ;/apis;,    ;/apis/apps;,    ;/apis/apps/v1beta1;,    ;/apis/authentication.k8s.io;,    ;/apis/authentication.k8s.io/v1beta1;,    ;/apis/authorization.k8s.io;,    ;/apis/authorization.k8s.io/v1beta1;,    ;/apis/autoscaling;,    ;/apis/autoscaling/v1;,    ;/apis/batch;,    ;/apis/batch/v1;,    ;/apis/batch/v2alpha1;,    ;/apis/certificates.k8s.io;,    ;/apis/certificates.k8s.io/v1alpha1;,    ;/apis/extensions;,    ;/apis/extensions/v1beta1;,    ;/apis/policy;,    ;/apis/policy/v1beta1;,    ;/apis/rbac.authorization.k8s.io;,    ;/apis/rbac.authorization.k8s.io/v1alpha1;,    ;/apis/storage.k8s.io;,    ;/apis/storage.k8s.io/v1beta1;,    ;/healthz;,    ;/healthz/poststarthook/bootstrap-controller;,    ;/healthz/poststarthook/extensions/third-party-resources;,    ;/healthz/poststarthook/rbac/bootstrap-roles;,    ;/logs;,    ;/metrics;,    ;/swaggerapi/;,    ;/ui/;,    ;/version;  ]}Can do with /version:{  ;major;: ;1;,  ;minor;: ;5;,  ;gitVersion;: ;v1.5.0;,  ;gitCommit;: ;58b7c16a52c03e4a849874602be42ee71afdcab1;,  ;gitTreeState;: ;clean;,  ;buildDate;: ;2016-12-12T23:31:15Z;,  ;goVersion;: ;go1.7.4;,  ;compiler;: ;gc;,  ;platform;: ;linux/amd64;}When trying to access the actual address with the following:https://<icsp address>:9443/ui redirects tohttps://<icsp address>:9443/api/v1/proxy/namespaces/kube-system/services/kubernetes-dashboard/#/workload?namespace=defaulthttps://<icsp address>:9443/api/v1/proxy/namespaces/kube-system/services/kubernetes-dashboard/#/secret/default/default-token-6qptd?namespace=defaultTHE API ACCESS IS WITHOUT AUTHENTICATION AND EXPOSES THE ENTIRE ICSP PLATFORM INFORMATION, including services, topologies, and components connected to the ICSP platform. NEED TO SHUT THE API.
PSIRT: PSIRT-owner: psirt@cisco.com           This issue has been evaluated and driven to closure by PSIRT.  PSIRT has provided a public Release-note Enclosure (RNE) for this issue which is visible on Cisco.com. Title: Failure to Encrypt Messages with Very Long Subject Headers
RNE: $$IGNORE-PSIRT   CISCO HIGHLY CONFIDENTIAL - CONTROLLED ACCESS  This issue is under review by the Cisco Product Security Incident Response team (PSIRT).  The defect describes a product security vulnerability.  Its contents must be protected from unauthorized disclosure,Symptom:Conditions:Workaround:
Description: PXE uses too much resources and fails to encrypt message, hermes core dumps for messages with long subject === Problem ===  Please see bug #76020. For this bug I'm using mbox with long subject header. Will try to find out whether such mbox is real cause of this problem or it can be reproduced under another circumstances.   As for now I am reporting that injecting of one message with size 9.5M causes great problems on ESA with enabled encryption service.  === Setup ===  NOTE: the mbox used for repro is here qa47.qa:/home/ahrytskiv/mboxes/bug76020_a.mbox  1. Image appliance with build 7.5.0-438 build. 2. Create Public listener with default settings. 3. Create encryption profile Key Service Type: IronPort Encryption Profile(in network) IronPort Encryption Appliance URL internal and external: https://postx01.qa Under ;;Message Settings;; select 'Enable Secure Reply All' and 'Enable Secure Message Forwarding' options (I think it doesn't matter).  All other settings leave default.  4. Create Incoming Content Filter to encrypt messages on delivery.  f_e: if (true) { encrypt-deferred (;;encr;;, ;;$Subject;;, 0); }   5. Apply this filter on Incoming Mail Policies. 6. Optionally: create route to your drain to see messages going from ESA.  The version of PXE(updater server is 'stage-updates.ironport.com:443'):   PXE Engine 6.8.0-008 Domain Mappings File 1.0.0  Also I have script to view top output  ------------------ #!/bin/sh  echo ;;        =======================================;; while : ; do     top -b $1 echo ;;        =======================================;;     sleep $2  done ------------------  Run as  nohup sh /data/pub/configuration/w.sh 5 10 | tee /data/pub/configuration/w.log &  Top 5 rows every 10 seconds written to stdout and to file.  Also for debug  tail -f /var/log/messages tail -f /data/log/heimdall/thirdparty/thirdparty.current tail -f /data/log/heimdall/her
PSIRT: PSIRT-owner: srasovic        PSIRT is reviewing this issue for possible inclusion in a Cisco Security Advisory which could include this DDTs.

Title: Cisco Wireless LAN Controller RADIUS Change of Authorization Denial of Service Vulnerability
RNE: Symptom: A vulnerability in the Remote Authentication Dial-In User Service (RADIUS) Change of  Authorization (CoA) Request processing of the Cisco Wireless LAN Controller could allow  an unauthenticated, remote attacker to cause a denial of service (DoS) condition by  disconnecting a single connection.  The vulnerability is due to lack of proper input validation of the of the Radius CoA  packet header. An attacker could exploit this vulnerability by sending a crafted Radius  CoA packet to the targeted device. An exploit could allow the attacker to unexpectedly  disconnect a connection through the WLC.  Conditions: The only vulnerable release is 8.3.102.0.  Workaround: None.  Further Problem Description: None.  PSIRT Evaluation: The Cisco PSIRT has assigned this bug the following CVSS version 2 score. The Base and Temporal CVSS scores as of the time of evaluation are 5/4.1: http://tools.cisco.com/security/center/cvssCalculator.x?vector=AV:N/AC:L/Au:N/C:N/I:N/A:P/E:F/RL:OF/RC:C&version=2.0  CVE ID CVE-2016-9195 has been assigned to document this issue.  Additional information on Cisco's security vulnerability policy can be found at the following URL: http://www.cisco.com/en/US/products/products_security_vulnerability_policy.html
Description: WLC: CoA-Request processed despite mismatch in shared secretTested in 8.3.102.0, sending a CoA request from a Linux machine running the freeradius ;radclient; tool.When the shared secret is incorrect, the debug aaa show that the received message authenticator doesn't match the calculated one, yet the disconnect is processed.See debug-output for more details.
PSIRT: PSIRT-owner: srasovic        PSIRT is reviewing this issue for possible inclusion in a Cisco Security Advisory which could include this DDTs.

Title: Cross-Site Scripting - Non-Persistent
RNE: Symptom: A vulnerability in the serviceability page of Cisco Unified Communications Manager (CUCM) could allow an unauthenticated, remote attacker to conduct reflected cross-site scripting (XSS) attacks.  The vulnerability is due to improper sanitization or encoding of user-supplied data by the serviceability page of an affected version of CUCM. An attacker could exploit this vulnerability by persuading a targeted user to follow a malicious link. An exploit could allow the attacker to conduct a reflected XSS attack.  Conditions: Device configured with default configuration.  Workaround: None.  Further Problem Description: None.  PSIRT Evaluation: The Cisco PSIRT has assigned this bug the following CVSS version 3 score. The Base CVSS score as of the time of evaluation is 6.1: https://tools.cisco.com/security/center/cvssCalculator.x?version=3.0&vector=CVSS:3.0/AV:N/AC:L/PR:N/UI:R/S:C/C:L/I:L/A:N/E:X/RL:X/RC:X  CVE ID CVE-2017-3821 has been assigned to document this issue.  Additional information on Cisco's security vulnerability policy can be found at the following URL: http://www.cisco.com/en/US/products/products_security_vulnerability_policy.html
Description: The 'CUCM' application does not properly validate user input and is therefore vulnerable to non-persistent Cross-Site Scripting (XSS) identified in Unified Reporting and Unified Serviceability (Alarm Configuration)Within Unified Reporting the 'name' parameter is vulnerable to XSS in two URLs. This can be seen by using the following URL and activated when the Generate Report button is pressedhttps://<cucm>/cucreports/generateReport.do?isStandard=true&name=v4e5q%27-confirm(%27xss%27)-%27ct9tti3ilk3&transform=truehttps://<cucm>/cucreports/showReport.do?isStandard=true&name=XSS%27-confirm(%27xss%27)-%27fooWithin the Alarm Configuration URL the 'NodeID' parameter is vulnerable to XSS. This can be seen by using the following URL and activated when the Service Group 'Go' button is pressedhttps://<cucm>/ccmservice/alarmconfig.jsp?NodeID=<nodeID>%22);document.write(%27XSS%27);confirm(%27xss%27);%20//
PSIRT: PSIRT-owner: srasovic        PSIRT is reviewing this issue for possible inclusion in a Cisco Security Advisory which could include this DDTs.

Title: Cisco ASA SharePoint RAMFS Integrity and Lua Injection Vulnerability
RNE: Symptoms: A vulnerability in the SSL VPN code of Cisco ASA Software could allow an authenticated, remote attacker to overwrite arbitrary file present on the RAMFS file system or inject Lua scripts.  The vulnerability is due to insufficient validation of the code that handled session information of the SSL VPN when a sharepoint handled is created. A sharepoint handler is created when a valid sharepoint connection is initiated.. An attacker could exploit this vulnerability by sending crafted HTTP request to the affected system. SSL VPN feature needs to be configured for the system to be vulnerable.  An exploit could allow the attacker to overwrite arbitrary file on the RAMFS cache or inject lua scripts. As results an attacker can cause a denial of service to the Clientless SSL VPN portal or potentially cause the reload of the system.  This vulnerability was reported to Cisco by Alec STUART-MUIRK  Conditions: SSL VPN should be configured on the system. Additionally a Sharepoint handled needs to be present in order to exploit this issue.  Workaround: none   PSIRT Evaluation: The Cisco PSIRT has assigned this bug the following CVSS version 2 score. The Base and Temporal CVSS scores as of the time of evaluation are 4/3.3: http://tools.cisco.com/security/center/cvssCalculator.x?vector=AV:N/AC:L/Au:S/C:N/I:P/A:N/E:F/RL:OF/RC:C&version=2.0 CVE ID CVE-2014-3399 has been assigned to document this issue.  Additional details about the vulnerability described here can be found at: http://tools.cisco.com/security/center/content/CiscoSecurityNotice/CVE-2014-3399  Additional information on Cisco's security vulnerability policy can be found at the following URL: http://www.cisco.com/en/US/products/products_security_vulnerability_policy.html
Description: affects Cisco ASA 9.0 and above.An authenticated remote WebVPN user can overwrite any file on the WebVPN ramfs. However, they can only control part of the file content.This code was introduced after a change in SharePoint cookie handler code prevented a mandatory generation of  random values for cookie webvpnSharePoint. If the cookie value webvpnSharePoint is already present then the existing/given (attacker controlled) value is used.This bug can be found in the webvpnSharePoint cookie handler. An attacker can inject ;../; to escape directories and manipulate the file name where the WebVPN session data is stored. The file will be created if the file does not exist. Existing files will be overwritten.For further details about exploitation please contact psirt.
PSIRT: PSIRT-owner: psirt@cisco.com           This issue has been evaluated and driven to closure by PSIRT.  PSIRT has provided a public Release-note Enclosure (RNE) for this issue which is visible on Cisco.com.   If a customer is being impacted by this issue, please guide them to the 'Workaround' section of the RNE or recommend a software upgrade to a patched release.   If a patched release is not available  for the customer-specific situation, you will need to escalate the issue  through the DE manager or the business unit that owns the DDTs defect.  There is no need to contact PSIRT for this issue.  Do not provide customers with any information beyond what is currently contained in the RNE.

Title: Key Reinstallation attacks against WPA protocol
RNE: Symptom: The products  Cisco WAP121 Wireless-N Access Point with Single Point Setup Cisco WAP321 Wireless-N Access Point with Single Point Setup  implement a WPA supplicant and as such are affected by the WPA protocol vulnerabilities identified by the following Common Vulnerability and Exposures (CVE) ID:  CVE-2017-13077: reinstallation of the pairwise key in the 4-way handshake CVE-2017-13078: reinstallation of the group key in the 4-way handshake CVE-2017-13079: reinstallation of the integrity group key in the 4-way handshake CVE-2017-13080: reinstallation of the group key in the group key handshake CVE-2017-13081: reinstallation of the integrity group key in the group key handshake CVE-2017-13082: accepting a retransmitted Fast BSS Transition Reassociation Request and reinstalling the pairwise key while processing it CVE-2017-13086: reinstallation of the Tunneled Direct-Link Setup (TDLS) PeerKey (TPK) key in the TDLS handshake CVE-2017-13087: reinstallation of the group key (GTK) when processing a Wireless Network Management (WNM) Sleep Mode Response frame CVE-2017-13088: reinstallation of the integrity group key (IGTK) when processing a Wireless Network Management (WNM) Sleep Mode Response frame  As disclosed in https://tools.cisco.com/security/center/content/CiscoSecurityAdvisory/cisco-sa-20171016-wpa  Conditions: Exposure is not configuration dependent.  Workaround: Not available.  Further Problem Description: PSIRT Evaluation: The Cisco PSIRT has assigned this bug the following CVSS version 3 score. The Base CVSS score as of the time of evaluation is 4.3:  https://tools.cisco.com/security/center/cvssCalculator.x?version=3&vector=CVSS:3.0/AV:A/AC:L/PR:N/UI:N/S:U/C:N/I:L/A:N  Additional information on Cisco's security vulnerability policy can be found at the following URL: http://www.cisco.com/en/US/products/products_security_vulnerability_policy.html
Description: New vulnerabilities have been identified on the WPA protocol (WPA1 and WPA2) that allow for key re-installation. Two of those vulnerabilities affect wireless devices acting as supplicant, while the remaining one affects wireless devices acting as authenticator.These vulnerabilities allow (depending on specific device configuration) for packet replaying, packet decryption, and *may allow* for packet forging/packet injection.As these are *protocol* level vulnerabilities (instead of being implementation vulnerabilities), there is a high likelihood that any wireless product implementing WPA1 or WPA2, as either supplicant or authenticator, will be affected. We have confirmed that any product using the Open Source packages ?hostapd? or ?wpa_supplicant? *will be affected by these vulnerabilities*.The Cisco PSIRT has a draft paper with details on the vulnerabilities, and tools that can be used to help reproduce the vulnerabilities on devices working as supplicant or authenticator. Due to the sensitive nature of this information, they're NOT attached to the bug but will be provided on an as-needed basis to developers involved on analyzing and fixing this vulnerability on any affected product.Please contact dciccaro@cisco.com and fcasotto@cisco.com to get access to the paper and the tools. We can also provide a patch for products using the packages ?hostapd? or ?wpa_supplicant?. Please include PSIRT-1457134228 on the subject line of any emails about this issue.Products that1) have NOT YET reached End of Software Maintenance (EOSWM):  product has to be evaluated and a fix developed2) have reached EOSWM, but NOT YET End of Support: product has to be evaluated, but no fix needs to be developed3) have reached End of Support: no evaluation nor fix neededThis bug has been opened for the following products:WAP121 Wireless-N Access Point with Single Point SetupWAP321 Wireless-N Selectable-Band Access Point with Single Point Setup

Title: PCP - Web Framework Access Controls Bypass Vulnerability
RNE: Symptoms: A vulnerability in the web framework of Cisco Prime Collaboration Provisioning could allow an authenticated, remote attacker to access higher-privileged functions.  An exploit could allow the attacker to access functions some of which should be accessible only to users who have administrative privileges. This includes creating an administrative user.  Cisco has released software updates that address this vulnerability. Workarounds that mitigate this vulnerability are not available. This advisory is available at the following link: http://tools.cisco.com/security/center/content/CiscoSecurityAdvisory/cisco-sa-20150916-pcp  Conditions: see security advisory  Workaround: see security advisory  Further Problem Description: PSIRT Evaluation: The Cisco PSIRT has assigned this bug the following CVSS version 2 score. The Base and Temporal CVSS scores as of the time of evaluation are 8.5/7: http://tools.cisco.com/security/center/cvssCalculator.x?vector=AV:N/AC:M/Au:S/C:C/I:C/A:C/E:F/RL:OF/RC:C&version=2.0 CVE ID  has been assigned to document this issue. Additional information on Cisco's security vulnerability policy can be found at the following URL: http://www.cisco.com/en/US/products/products_security_vulnerability_policy.html
Description: PCP today doesn't have access control when sending AJAX (or GET/POST) requests in some places. For example, from a logged-in ;ordering; user session, a hacker can send a POST request to add a device into PCP; or to send a GET request to get a list of devices belonging to other domains.Here is a list of places missing the access control:1. Device Setup2. Provisioning Setup3. User Provisioning4. Batch Provisioningand  others listed in the web.xml file:   <url-pattern>/ipt/device/*</url-pattern>   <url-pattern>/ipt/domain/*</url-pattern>   <url-pattern>/ipt/serviceArea/*</url-pattern>   <url-pattern>/ipt/userrole/*</url-pattern>   <url-pattern>/ipt/productTemplates/*</url-pattern>   <url-pattern>/ipt/dashboard/*</url-pattern>   <url-pattern>/ipt/maintenance/*</url-pattern>   <url-pattern>/ipt/batch/*</url-pattern>   <url-pattern>/ipt/ucservice/*</url-pattern>   <url-pattern>/ipt/configmgmt/*</url-pattern>   <url-pattern>/ipt/selfcare/jsp/*</url-pattern>   <url-pattern>/ipt/gsWizard/*</url-pattern>   <url-pattern>/ipt/support/*</url-pattern>   <url-pattern>/ipt/system/*</url-pattern>

Title: AnyConnect Secure Mobility Client Hostscan Path Traversal Vulnerability
RNE: Symptom: A vulnerability in Inter-process communication (IPC) channel of Cisco AnyConnect Secure Mobility Client Hostscan module could allow an authenticated, local attacker to write and overwrite arbitrary files with elevated privileges.  The vulnerability is due to missing a path traversal vulnerability in certain IPC commands. An attacker could exploit this vulnerability by sending crafted IPC messages. An exploit could allow an attacker to write or overwrite arbitrary files on the filesystem.  Conditions: Cisco AnyConnect Secure Mobility Client Hostscan module installed.  Workaround: Not applicable or available.  Further Problem Description: PSIRT Evaluation: The Cisco PSIRT has assigned this bug the following CVSS version 2 score. The Base and Temporal CVSS scores as of the time of evaluation are 4.6/4.1: http://tools.cisco.com/security/center/cvssCalculator.x?vector=AV:L/AC:L/Au:S/C:N/I:C/A:N/E:POC/RL:U/RC:C&version=2.0  CVE ID CVE-2015-0665 has been assigned to document this issue.  Additional information on Cisco's security vulnerability policy can be found at the following URL: http://www.cisco.com/en/US/products/products_security_vulnerability_policy.html

Title: ACS evaluation for CVE-2014-6271 and CVE-2014-7169
RNE: The Cisco Secure Access Control Server (ACS) includes a version of bash that is affected by the vulnerabilities identified by the Common Vulnerability and Exposures (CVE) IDs:  CVE-2014-6271 CVE-2014-7169  This bug has been opened to address the potential impact on this product. Analysis from development team: All shipping versions of ACS are vulnerable CVE-2014-6271, CVE-2014-7169,  CVE-2014-7186, CVE-2014-7187 , CVE-2014-6277 and CVE-2014-6278 (AKA ShellShock bug). ACS patch will be made available for all supported versions of ACS in a timely manner.  That said, the exposure of this bug in ACS is very limited.  The shellshock vulnerability allows an SSH AUTHENTICATED user run a generic Linux command.   The key word being 'AUTHENTICATED'.  Hence if an attacker does not have the username and password of an ACS CLI user, they will not  be able to exploit this vulnerability on ACS.   If the user DOES have credentials, and would like to exploit the shellshock, that CLI user would be able to run generic Linux commands on the ACS Server that would normally not be able to run (Because the ACS CLI does not expose generic Linux commands).  However those Linux commands will run as the logged in CLI user account, not as the Linux root user.  Hence, this limits exposure of the vulnerability in ACS.  An example of an exploit using shellshock in ACS would be to view Linux system files they would normally not be able to view.   The workaround to remove the vulnerability would be to disable the SSH daemon via the following CLI, then reload the ACS server to ensure all  SSH sessions have been terminated.  The following CLI demonstrates how to to disable SSH service and reload the node:  ---snip acs1/admin# configure terminal acs1/admin(config)# no service sshd enable  acs1/admin(config)# end acs1/admin# reload Save the current ADE-OS running configuration? (yes/no) [yes] ? yes Continue with reboot? [y/n] y ---snip   Disable SSH as follows (until the ACS patch with the fix for CSCur00511 is installed):  ---snip acs1/admin# configure terminal acs1/admin(config)# no service sshd enable  acs1/admin(config)# end acs1/admin# reload Save the current ADE-OS running configuration? (yes/no) [yes] ? yes Continue with reboot? [y/n] y ---snip   The other work around  can be restrict IP addresses to access CLI of ACS only for known admin laptops by making configuration change on end switch /firewall device where ACS is connected .  For example:  tcp permit trusted segment ACS hosts eq 22  tcp deny any acs eq 22  permit rest        The Cisco Secure Access Control Server (ACS) includes a version of bash that is affected by the vulnerabilities identified by the Common Vulnerability and Exposures (CVE) IDs:  CVE-2014-6271 CVE-2014-7169  This bug has been opened to address the potential impact on this product. (yes/no) [yes] ? yes Continue with reboot? For example:  tcp permit trusted segment ACS hosts eq 22  tcp deny any acs eq 22  permit rest  Symptom: The Cisco Secure Access Control Server (ACS) includes a version of bash that is affected by the vulnerabilities identified by the Common Vulnerability and Exposures (CVE) IDs:  CVE-2014-6271 CVE-2014-7169  This bug has been opened to address the potential impact on this product. Analysis from development team: All shipping versions of ACS are vulnerable CVE-2014-6271, CVE-2014-7169,  CVE-2014-7186, CVE-2014-7187 , CVE-2014-6277 and CVE-2014-6278 (AKA ShellShock bug). ACS patch will be made available for all supported versions of ACS in a timely manner.  That said, the exposure of this bug in ACS is very limited.  The shellshock vulnerability allows an SSH AUTHENTICATED user run a generic Linux command.   The key word being 'AUTHENTICATED'.  Hence if an attacker does not have the username and password of an ACS CLI user, they will not  be able to exploit this vulnerability on ACS.   If the user DOES have credentials, and would like to exploit the shellshock, that CLI user would be able to run generic Linux commands on the ACS Server that would normally not be able to run (Because the ACS CLI does not expose generic Linux commands).  However those Linux commands will run as the logged in CLI user account, not as the Linux root user.  Hence, this limits exposure of the vulnerability in ACS.  An example of an exploit using shellshock in ACS would be to view Linux system files they would normally not be able to view.   The workaround to remove the vulnerability would be to disable the SSH daemon via the following CLI, then reload the ACS server to ensure all  SSH sessions have been terminated.  The following CLI demonstrates how to to disable SSH service and reload the node:  ---snip acs1/admin# configure terminal acs1/admin(config)# no service sshd enable  acs1/admin(config)# end acs1/admin# reload Save the current ADE-OS running configuration? (yes/no) [yes] ? yes Continue with reboot? [y/n] y ---snip  Conditions:  ACS server is exposed to this vulnerability only if they have ssh service enabled.  If SSH is enabled, a remote user with ACS CLI credentials will be able to exploit the vulnerability and run generic Linux commands.    Workaround:  Disable SSH as follows (until the ACS patch with the fix for CSCur00511 is installed):  ---snip acs1/admin# configure terminal acs1/admin(config)# no service sshd enable  acs1/admin(config)# end acs1/admin# reload Save the current ADE-OS running configuration? (yes/no) [yes] ? yes Continue with reboot? [y/n] y ---snip   The other work around  can be restrict IP addresses to access CLI of ACS only for known admin laptops by making configuration change on end switch /firewall device where ACS is connected .  For example:  tcp permit trusted segment ACS hosts eq 22  tcp deny any acs eq 22  permit rest  Further Problem Description: Fixed Code: Patch for DDTS CSCur00511 is ready and available on CCO. The patch is included in all cumulative patches from version 5.4.0.46.7/5.5.0.46.6/5.6.0.22.1 and later. We recommend that you download the latest cumulative patches.  Download from: CCO / Support / Download Software http://www.cisco.com/cisco/pub/software/portal/select.html?i=!y Select: Security / Identity Management / Cisco Secure Access Control System / Cisco Secure Access Control System 5.4 / 5.4.0.46.0  Patch filename: 5-4-0-46-(latest).tar.gpg Readme and installaion instructions: Acs-5-4-0-46-(latest)-Readme.txt  Download from: CCO / Support / Download Software http://www.cisco.com/cisco/pub/software/portal/select.html?i=!y Select: Security / Identity Management / Cisco Secure Access Control System / Cisco Secure Access Control System 5.5 / 5.5.0.46  Patch filename: 5-5-0-46-(latest).tar.gpg Readme and installaion instructions: Acs-5-5-0-46-(latest)-Readme.txt  Download from: CCO / Support / Download Software http://www.cisco.com/cisco/pub/software/portal/select.html?i=!y Select: Security / Identity Management / Cisco Secure Access Control System / Cisco Secure Access Control System 5.6 / 5.6.0.22  Patch filename: 5-6-0-22-(latest).tar.gpg Readme and installaion instructions: Acs-5-6-0-22-(latest)-Readme.txt  Download from: CCO / Support / Download Software http://www.cisco.com/cisco/pub/software/portal/select.html?i=!y Select: Security / Identity Management / Cisco Secure Access Control System / Cisco Secure Access Control System 5.3 / 5.3.0.40  Patch filename: 5-3-0-40-(latest).tar.gpg Readme and installaion instructions: Acs-53(latest)-Readme.txt    PSIRT Evaluation: The Cisco PSIRT has assigned this bug the following CVSS version 2 score. The Base and Temporal CVSS scores as of the time of evaluation are  7.5/7.5:  http://tools.cisco.com/security/center/cvssCalculator.x?vector=AV:N/AC:L/Au:N/C:P/I:P/A:P/E:H/RL:U/RC:C&version=2.0  The Cisco PSIRT has assigned this score based on information obtained from multiple sources. This includes the CVSS score assigned by the third-party vendor when available. The CVSS score assigned may not reflect the actual impact on the Cisco Product.  Additional information on Cisco's security vulnerability policy can be found at the following URL:  http://www.cisco.com/web/about/security/psirt/security_vulnerability_policy.html
Description: PLEASE READ THIS ENTIRE DESCRIPTION AND THE INCLUDED LINKS BEFORE TAKING ANY ACTION.A serious vulnerability has been discovered in the Bash shell widely used in various Cisco products. Additional background information can be found on PSIRT's internal hot page at: https://psirt.cisco.com/PSIRThot/BashSep14 This defect has been created to evaluate the impact to this product.IMMEDIATE ACTION REQUIRED:==========================Please evaluate your product in the next 48 hours and file the DE-Evaluation enclosure per the instructions at:https://psirt.cisco.com/PSIRThot/BashSep14/InstructionsToEngineering

Title: 802.1x MAC flooding Denial of Service
RNE: $$IGNORE-PSIRT  Symptom:  Conditions:  Workaround:  Further Problem Description:
Description: Raising bug now and setting up recreate in lab.  Customer Reports:Behavior observed on tested platforms:# 3750 IOS 12.2(55)SE5Switch unable to perform 802.1x authentication during attackSwitch unable to perform 802.1x authentication even after attackSwitch performance is severely degraded. CPU is on max.Switch is reliably crashing when attack lasts for longer time (minutes).Reload needed for recovery.# 3650 IOS XE 3.3.4Switch unable to perform 802.1x authentication during attackSwitch unable to perform 802.1x authentication even after attackSwitch performance is severely degraded.CPU is on aprox 80pct.Reload needed to recover.# 3650 - denali 16.3.5Switch unable to perform 802.1x authentication during attackSwitch able to perform authentication again when the attack is short (100.000 packets)Switch unable to perform 802.1x authentication after longer attack (500.000 packets)Switch performance is slightly degraded.CPU is on aprox 80pct.Reload needed to recover after longer attack# customer switch where this was observed in the wild:Cat 4500E, Sup7L-E, IOS XE 3.6.5Affected switch is always queueing dot1x messages and is sending ;EAP failure; packets fora long time after attack to port which was source of an attack.When attack is long enough ( I found that 400.000 packets are enough), 802.1x stopsworking - no further dot1x activity seen in debug.Instructions for recreation:switch configured with dot1x, working connectivity to ISE - lab switch configuration will be attached.Computer with ;macof; tool connected to any port configured with dot1x port auth. Macof isfreely avilable, for example as a part of ;Kali; distro.Macof tool executed with parameter ;-n 400000; (or more) which generates 400.000 packetswith random MAC on port. It tooks aproximately one minute.  When I generate smaller amount of packets than 400.000, cat3650 is able to recover after attack.

Title: Authenticated user can download any message from spam quarantine
RNE: $$IGNORE-PSIRT Symptoms: A vulnerability in the spam quarantine of Cisco Email Security Appliance and Cisco Content Security Management Appliance could allow an authenticated, remote attacker to download any message from the spam quarantine by modifying browser string information. The vulnerability is due to a lack of verification of authenticated user accounts. An attacker could exploit this vulnerability by modifying browser strings to see messages submitted by other users to the spam quarantine within their company.   Conditions: A device running an affected version of software.  Workaround: None.  Further Problem Description: None.  PSIRT Evaluation: The Cisco PSIRT has assigned this bug the following CVSS version 3 score. The Base CVSS score as of the time of evaluation is 6.5: https://tools.cisco.com/security/center/cvssCalculator.x?version=3.0&vector=CVSS:3.0/AV:N/AC:L/PR:L/UI:N/S:U/C:H/I:N/A:N/E:X/RL:X/RC:X  CVE ID  has been assigned to document this issue.  Additional information on Cisco's security vulnerability policy can be found at the following URL: http://www.cisco.com/en/US/products/products_security_vulnerability_policy.html
Description: Authenticated user can download any message from spam quarantine just changing message id and keyword 'Detail' to 'Download' in browser stringfor example:https://sma:83/Message?action=Detail&CSRFKey=d947c29b-c7b0-b3e3-9ed6-1b0947171d29&mid=3user A, MID =3https://sma:83/Message?action=Download&CSRFKey=d947c29b-c7b0-b3e3-9ed6-1b0947171d29&mid=4MID=4 belongs to user B.

Title: Virtual ESA Default Authorized SSH Key Vulnerability
RNE: Symptom: Cisco Web Security Virtual Appliance (WSAv), Cisco Email Security Virtual Appliance (ESAv), and Cisco Security Management Virtual Appliance (SMAv) are affected by the following vulnerabilities:      Cisco Virtual WSA, ESA, and SMA Default Authorized SSH Key Vulnerability     Cisco Virtual WSA, ESA, and SMA Default SSH Host Keys Vulnerability  Cisco has released free software updates that address these vulnerabilities. There are no workarounds for these vulnerabilities.  This advisory is available at the following link: http://tools.cisco.com/security/center/content/CiscoSecurityAdvisory/cisco-sa-20150625-ironport  Conditions: Please see the published Cisco Security Advisory.  Workaround: Please see the published Cisco Security Advisory.  Further Problem Description: PSIRT Evaluation: The Cisco PSIRT has assigned this bug the following CVSS version 2 score. The Base and Temporal CVSS scores as of the time of evaluation are 9.3/7.7:  http://tools.cisco.com/security/center/cvssCalculator.x?vector=AV:N/AC:M/Au:N/C:C/I:C/A:C/E:F/RL:OF/RC:C&version=2.0  CVE ID CVE-2015-4216 has been assigned to document this issue.  Additional information on Cisco's security vulnerability policy can be found at the following URL: http://www.cisco.com/en/US/products/products_security_vulnerability_policy.html
Description: any platform or version comes with a preinstalled authorized key stored at:/root/.ssh/authorized_keys(-enablediag)meaning, all customer is affectedPhysical Devices seem to have a ;unique; key set - ownership of private key is UNKNOWNVirtual appliances are having IAF authorized keys included - Private Key is part of IAF (used for repro)that should not exist to my understanding. sshd will allow anyone to connect, that has the corresponding private key found in that file with root privileges!Quick test:(1) download and install a fresh S300V (or any other Content Security Appliance):(2) only setup IP connectivity on the fresh installation, nothing else required(3) use iaf_dsa key to login with SSH (e.g. ssh -i iaf_dsa) whereas 1.2.3.4 is your installation(4) login as user ;enablediag; first to activate the service account, use any pw as it is not relevant(5) now reconnect to login as user ;service; that provides now full root shell access.Please refer to tac-repro for full detailed description.

Title: Session Token Vulnerabilities with the Cisco CUIC infrastructure URLs.
RNE: Symptoms:  A vulnerability in the web framework of the Cisco Unified Intelligence Center could allow an unauthenticated, remote attacker to perform a cross-site request forgery (CSRF) attack against a vulnerable web interface.  The vulnerability is due to insufficient CSRF protections on the web interface. An attacker could exploit this vulnerability by persuading a user of the affected system to follow a malicious link or visit an attacker-controlled website.  A successful exploit could allow the attacker to submit arbitrary requests to the affected device via the affected web page.  Conditions: Cisco Unified Intelligence Center version 11.0.0.99000-186.  Workaround: None.  Further Problem Description: None.  PSIRT Evaluation: The Cisco PSIRT has assigned this bug the following CVSS version 2 score. The Base and Temporal CVSS scores as of the time of evaluation are 5/4.1: http://tools.cisco.com/security/center/cvssCalculator.x?vector=AV:N/AC:L/Au:N/C:P/I:N/A:N/E:F/RL:OF/RC:C&version=2.0 CVE ID CVE-2015-4274 has been assigned to document this issue. Additional information on Cisco's security vulnerability policy can be found at the following URL: http://www.cisco.com/en/US/products/products_security_vulnerability_policy.html
Description: Session token in URL- Sensitive information within URLs may be logged in various locations, including the user's browser, the web server, and any forward or reverse proxy servers between the two endpoints. URLs may also be displayed on-screen, bookmarked or emailed around by users. They may be disclosed to third parties via the Referer header when any off-site links are followed. Placing session tokens into the URL increases the risk that they will be captured by an attacker. Issue remediationThe application should use an alternative mechanism for transmitting session tokens, such as HTTP cookies or hidden fields in forms that are submitted using the POST method.

The Base CVSS score as of the time of evaluation is 5.3: https://tools.cisco.com/security/center/cvssCalculator.x?version=3.0&vector=CVSS:3.0/AV:N/AC:L/PR:N/UI:N/S:U/C:L/I:N/A:N/E:X/RL:X/RC:X  CVE ID CVE-2016-2183 has been assigned to document this issue. Description: Build Details:---------------> show summary-------------------[ firepower ]--------------------Model                     : Cisco ASA5515-X Threat Defense (75) Version 6.2.0.1(Build 41)UUID                      : da2ab4c6-195f-11e7-9499-89a2a2b94074Rules update version      : 2016-03-28-001-vrtVDB version               : 271----------------------------------------------------Description:--------------Nexpose - VA scan on the FDM FR Patch 6.2.0.1 -41 found use of Triple DES ciphers, as used in the TLS and this have a birthday bound of approximately four billion blocks, which makes it easier for remote attackers to obtain cleartext data via a birthday attack against a long-duration encrypted session, as demonstrated by an HTTPS session using Triple DES in CBC mode, aka a ;Sweet32; attack. CVE-2016-2183 - ssl-cve-2016-2183-sweet32Security Issue : https://web.nvd.nist.gov/view/vuln/detail?vulnId=CVE-2016-2183                       https://sweet32.info/                       https://www.openssl.org/blog/blog/2016/08/24/sweet32                        https://access.redhat.com/articles/2548661Steps :-----------1. Run the Nexpose Vulnerability Scanner targetting FDM IP addressActual Result :------------------server is configured to  support for 3DES suite.Scan Report Attached See Scan Section :  3.2.3 , 3.3.5, .Expected Result:--------------------Configure the server to disable support for 3DES suite.

Title: Traceback in thread name: ssh
RNE: Symptom: A Cisco ASA may crash with a traceback in the SSH process.  Conditions: ASA with 2 SSH sessions that are active to the ASA console. One of the SSH sessions reaches the idle timeout, while some config changes are made on the other session.  Workaround: None   Further Problem Description: The impact to the failover pairs is minimal and the pair will switch over to be available for traffic.  The backport of this fix to the 8.2 train was deemed too risky for that train.  However, we have not have any reports of this crash from customers running 8.2 at the moment of publication. On the other hand, it is recommended to customers running version 8.2 to migrate to 8.4 to fix this issue.     PSIRT Evaluation: The Cisco PSIRT has assigned this bug the following CVSS version 2 score. The Base and Temporal CVSS scores as of the time of evaluation are 6.3/4.9:  http://tools.cisco.com/security/center/cvssCalculator.x?vector=AV:N/AC:M/Au:S/C:N/I:N/A:C/E:POC/RL:OF/RC:C&version=2.0  CVE ID CVE-2012-5717 has been assigned to document this issue.  Additional information on Cisco's security vulnerability policy can be found at the following URL: http://www.cisco.com/en/US/products/products_security_vulnerability_policy.html  More Info:
Description: -Test platform:ASA5520-Test image:8.0.4.100-Traffic profile:Spirent 80 bytes 50% line rate  UDP and TCP syn attck for more than 2000 sessions and cause CPU usage upto 96%-Description:1)During test DDTS CSCsj43068 verification, I issue 2 SSH session to the ASA and test different CPU-HOG time.2)After tests for sometime and leave the SSH console idle for timeout and both SSH ssessions are released and conosle found following traceback:ASA5520-stress#======= ALLOCATED BLOCK CHECKSUM FAILED ============== BLOCK NOT FOUND ========. Block ptr: ccccccccAn internal error occurred.  Specifically, a programming assertion wasviolated.  Copy the error message exactly as it appears, and get theoutput of the show version command and the contents of the configurationfile.  Then call your technical support representative.assertion ;0; failed: file ;block.c;, line 2341Thread Name: ssh (Old pc 0x08b4465b ebp 0xd72a7d30)Abort: Assert failure10/21/2009 Update:-We re-test this in the 8.0.4 official release and see the same traceback there. Also the customer was not seen this issue before, so we lower the severity to no show stopper for 8.0.5 maintenance release.=========================== NOTE =========================== This bug is a symptom of a class of bugs that were first seen in 8.2, it had something to do with some kind of race condition, the rewrite was the better solution, it eliminated that class of bugs, which we had been patching one by one in the past. This rewrite was first done starting the new code of 8.4 and it was hard to back any further. So there were no fixes in 8.2.x releases.Anyone facing this should upgrade to at least 8.4 to get the fix.

Title: GSS Cross-Site Request Forgery Vulnerability
RNE: Symptom: An attacker could exploit this issue to perform CSRF attack against the users of the web interface.  Conditions: none  Workaround: none  Further Problem Description: A vulnerability in the web framework could allow an unauthenticated, remote attacker to conduct a cross-site request forgery (CSRF) attack against the user of the web interface. The vulnerability is due to insufficient CSRF protections.  An attacker could exploit this vulnerability by convincing the user of the affected system to follow a malicious link or visit an attacker-controlled website. A successful exploit could allow the attacker to submit arbitrary requests to the affected device via the affected web browser with the privileges of the user.   PSIRT Evaluation: The Cisco PSIRT has assigned this bug the following CVSS version 2 score. The Base and Temporal CVSS scores as of the time of evaluation are 4.3/4.1: http://tools.cisco.com/security/center/cvssCalculator.x?vector=AV:N/AC:M/Au:N/C:N/I:P/A:N/E:F/RL:U/RC:C&version=2.0 CVE ID CVE-2013-5471 has been assigned to document this issue.  Additional details about the vulnerability described here can be found at: http://tools.cisco.com/security/center/content/CiscoSecurityNotice/CVE-2013-5471  Additional information on Cisco's security vulnerability policy can be found at the following URL: http://www.cisco.com/en/US/products/products_security_vulnerability_policy.html
Description: Following vulnerability seen on GSS device:CWE-352: Cross-Site Request Forgery (CSRF) http://cwe.mitre.org/data/definitions/352.htmlDescription SummaryThe web application does not, or can not, sufficiently verify whether a well-formed, valid, consistent request was intentionally provided by the user who submitted the request.Extended DescriptionWhen a web server is designed to receive a request from a client without any mechanism for verifying that it was intentionally sent, then it might be possible for an attacker to trick a client into making an unintentional request to the web server which will be treated as an authentic request. This can be done via a URL, image load, XMLHttpRequest, etc. and can result in exposure of data or unintended code execution.

Title: ASA Digital Certificate HTTP Authentication Bypass Vulnerability
RNE: Summary  Cisco Adaptive Security Appliance (ASA) Software is affected by the following vulnerabilities:      IPsec VPN Crafted ICMP Packet Denial of Service Vulnerability     SQL*Net Inspection Engine Denial of Service Vulnerability     Digital Certificate Authentication Bypass Vulnerability     Remote Access VPN Authentication Bypass Vulnerability     Digital Certificate HTTP Authentication Bypass Vulnerability     HTTP Deep Packet Inspection Denial of Service Vulnerability     DNS Inspection Denial of Service Vulnerability     AnyConnect SSL VPN Memory Exhaustion Denial of Service Vulnerability     Clientless SSL VPN Denial of Service Vulnerability   These vulnerabilities are independent of one other; a release that is affected by one of the vulnerabilities may not be affected by the others.  Successful exploitation of the IPsec VPN Crafted ICMP Packet Denial of Service Vulnerability, SQL*Net Inspection Engine Denial of Service Vulnerability, HTTP Deep Packet Inspection Denial of Service Vulnerability, DNS Inspection Denial of Service Vulnerability and Clientless SSL VPN Denial of Service Vulnerability may result in a reload of an affected device, leading to a denial of service (DoS) condition.  Successful exploitation of the Digital Certificate Authentication Bypass Vulnerability, Remote Access VPN Authentication Bypass Vulnerability, and Digital Certificate HTTP Authentication Bypass Vulnerability may result in an authentication bypass, which could allow the attacker access to the inside network via remote access VPN or management access to the affected system via the Cisco Adaptive Security Device Management (ASDM).  Successful exploitation of the AnyConnect SSL VPN Memory Exhaustion Denial of Service Vulnerability may exhaust available memory, which could result in general system instability and cause the affected system to become unresponsive and stop forwarding traffic.  Cisco has released free software updates that address these vulnerabilities. Workarounds are available for some of the vulnerabilities. This advisory is available at the following link: http://tools.cisco.com/security/center/content/CiscoSecurityAdvisory/cisco-sa-20131009-asa  Note: The Cisco Firewall Services Module (FWSM) for Cisco Catalyst 6500 Series Switches and Cisco 7600 Series Routers may be affected by the SQL*Net Inspection Engine Denial of Service Vulnerability. A separate Cisco Security Advisory has been published to disclose the vulnerabilities that affect the Cisco FWSM. This advisory is available at: http://tools.cisco.com/security/center/content/CiscoSecurityAdvisory/cisco-sa-20131009-fwsm  PSIRT Evaluation: The Cisco PSIRT has assigned this bug the following CVSS version 2 score. The Base and Temporal CVSS scores as of the time of evaluation are 10/8.3: http://tools.cisco.com/security/center/cvssCalculator.x?vector=AV:N/AC:L/Au:N/C:C/I:C/A:C/E:F/RL:OF/RC:C&version=2.0 CVE ID CVE-2013-5511 has been assigned to document this issue. Additional information on Cisco's security vulnerability policy can be found at the following URL: http://www.cisco.com/en/US/products/products_security_vulnerability_policy.html
Description: wbrown 06/11/2013 3:02 PM (8.4.4/7.1.3) - Using 5580-20 for testing.  This problem is seen using 8.4.4, 9.1.1.2, 9.1.2 and 9.0.2.101.     There are a couple CLI used to control ASDM authentication:1. http authentication-certificate outside2. aaa authentication http console LOCAL1 is to control whether or not the client will be asked for a cert.  2 is to control whether or not the client will be asked to enter username/password.  Turning both 1 and 2 on results in the user needing both user/password and cert to connect - this works OK.  Enabling only #1 works OK with user/password.  Logic would indicate that turning off #2 would result in a ;cert-only; connection but instead the ASDM connection is allowed without entering any username or password and the client is NOT prompted to send a certificate either.  There are also no syslogs appearing  on the ASA to indicate that it received a client cert.  This may or may not be a PSIRT issue.

Title: Cisco Unified Contact Center Express Cross-site Scripting Vulnerability
RNE: Symptom: A vulnerability in the web-based management interface of Cisco Unified Contact Center Express   could allow an unauthenticated, remote attacker to conduct a cross-site scripting (XSS) attack  against a user of the web-based management interface of an affected device.  The vulnerability is due to insufficient validation of user-supplied input by the web-based management interface of an affected device. An attacker could exploit this vulnerability by persuading a user of the  interface to click a crafted link. A successful exploit could allow the attacker to execute arbitrary script  code in the context of the interface or allow the attacker to access sensitive browser-based information.  Additional information about XSS attacks and potential mitigations can be found at the following links:      https://tools.cisco.com/security/center/content/CiscoAppliedMitigationBulletin/cisco-amb-20060922-understanding-xss     https://www.owasp.org/index.php/Cross-site_Scripting_(XSS)   This advisory is available at the following link: https://tools.cisco.com/security/center/content/CiscoSecurityAdvisory/cisco-sa-20171018-ucce  Conditions: Device running with default configuration running an affected version of software.  Workaround: None.  Further Problem Description: Additional information about XSS attacks and potential mitigations can be found at:  https://tools.cisco.com/security/center/content/CiscoAppliedMitigationBulletin/cisco-amb-20060922-understanding-xss https://www.owasp.org/index.php/Cross-site_Scripting_(XSS)  PSIRT Evaluation: The Cisco PSIRT has assigned this bug the following CVSS version 3 score. The Base CVSS score as of the time of evaluation is 6.1: https://tools.cisco.com/security/center/cvssCalculator.x?version=3.0&vector=CVSS:3.0/AV:N/AC:L/PR:N/UI:R/S:C/C:L/I:L/A:N/E:X/RL:X/RC:X  CVE ID CVE-2017-12288 has been assigned to document this issue.  Additional information on Cisco's security vulnerability policy can be found at the following URL: http://www.cisco.com/en/US/products/products_security_vulnerability_policy.html
Description: Phishing Through FramesThis is by design, and still exists. A query to shindig to concat and include multiple URLs can also contain any URL which Shindig will try to GET and concat. We are not filtering on what possible URLs are allowed and what URLs are not allowed. There is a planned effort to do a POST request with the requested URLs being moved into the body (rather than query params) so they cannot be manipulated.

Additional information on Cisco's security vulnerability policy can be found at the following URL: http://www.cisco.com/en/US/products/products_security_vulnerability_policy.html  Further Problem Description:
Description: The Cisco ASA uses Heimdal libraries/code. This bug is to investigate and document that all of the Heimdal security vulnerabilities have been addressed in the ASA.  For example: CVE-2010-1324 CVE-2010-1323 CVE-2010-4020 CVE-2010-4021There are no references/bugs that document that these have been patched.Note that this bug is being used to address the Heimdal code that has been ported to link with the ASA lina process as opposed to the MIT Kerberos distribution that is installed conventionally in the ASA WindRiver Linux OS.The code under scrutiny here was ported and modified to link and run with the lina process and resides in Xpix/unicorn/contrib/kerberos/heimdal.The following actions are required:1) This defect must be assigned to an engineer and triaged as soon as possible.2) If the CVEs do not have any impact to the product, then the bug should be junked and the reasons of why the CVEs do not apply need to be documented in the J-comments.3) If the defect does have impact then it should be added to your existing work queue for action.

Title: Kukri Wlc crashed with apfMsConnTask_3 in 8.6.1.114 build - codenomicon 802.11 suite
RNE: $$IGNORE-PSIRT  Symptoms: A vulnerability in certain input and validation checking mechanisms of the Cisco Wireless LAN Controller (WLC) could allow an unauthenticated, adjacent attacker to cause a Denial-of-Service (DoS) condition to an affected device.   The vulnerability is due to malformed management traffic causing the WLC to incorrectly process certain information elements (IE) within the ingress packet streams. An attacker could exploit this vulnerability by wirelessly transmitting certain malicious, malformed packets to an affected device, such as a man-in-the-middle (MITM) attack. An exploit could allow the attacker to cause a complete loss to the availability of certain resources running on the appliance.  Conditions: Device running an affected version of software.   Workaround: None.   Further Problem Description: Please refer to the Security Advisory.  PSIRT Evaluation: The Cisco PSIRT has assigned this bug the following CVSS version 3 score. The Base CVSS score as of the time of evaluation is 7.4: https://tools.cisco.com/security/center/cvssCalculator.x?version=3.0&vector=CVSS:3.0/AV:A/AC:L/PR:N/UI:N/S:C/C:N/I:N/A:H/E:X/RL:X/RC:X  CVE ID  has been assigned to document this issue.  Additional information on Cisco's security vulnerability policy can be found at the following URL: http://www.cisco.com/en/US/products/products_security_vulnerability_policy.html
Description: PROBLEM DESCRIPTION:====================Kukri wlc crashed twice When running codenomicon 802.11 ap suite against 2702 ap which is joined to kukri wlc. Tried the same suite in 8.6.1.106 and 8.6.1.114 build.  Not required on 8.3EXPECTED BEHAVIOR:==================No crash seen on ap or wlc. Title: NAM change password functionality does not verify old password
RNE: $$IGNORE-PSIRT  Symptom: NAM will authenticate using EAP to an authentication server.  If it is using Mschapv2 or GTC, the server will verify the users credentials, and if they are valid and  expired, the server will send a reply indicating the password was valid but expired.  If the credentials were invalid, the server would simply fail the EAP  authentication.  In the case that the creds are expired, NAM will receive a message indicating that the password is expired and will prompt the user with a dialog  box that contains one box for current password and 2 boxes for the new password.  At this point if a user enters an invalid password and new passwords that  match and meet password change criteria the password will be changed.  Conditions: NAM provides 802.1x authentication and can be configured multiple ways.  If NAM is configured for what is referred to as prelogon, that means the  authentication over 802.1x occurs as the user is logging in to the Windows machine.  NAM under that scenario must have single signon (SSO) configured to  work.  Workaround: None.  Further Problem Description: None.  PSIRT Evaluation: The Cisco PSIRT has assigned this bug the following CVSS version 3 score. The Base CVSS score as of the time of evaluation is 1.8: https://tools.cisco.com/security/center/cvssCalculator.x?version=3.0&vector=CVSS:3.0/AV:P/AC:H/PR:N/UI:R/S:U/C:N/I:L/A:N/E:X/RL:X/RC:X  No CVE ID has been assigned to this issue.  Additional information on Cisco's security vulnerability policy can be found at the following URL: http://www.cisco.com/en/US/products/products_security_vulnerability_policy.html
Description: The NAM password change dialog provides a text box for current (old) password and 2 text boxes for new password which is instantiated when NAM is configured for connection attempt of ;before user logon; and the password has expired before the user logs on.  If a user does not enter the correct current password, the NAM will allow the password to be changed.

Title: Cisco ASA Heap Overflow in Webvpn CIFS
RNE: Symptoms: A vulnerability in Common Internet Filesystem (CIFS) code in the Clientless SSL VPN functionality of Cisco ASA Software could allow an authenticated, remote attacker to cause a heap overflow.  The vulnerability is due to insufficient validation of user supplied input. An attacker could exploit this vulnerability by sending a crafted URL to the affected system. An exploit could allow the remote attacker to cause a reload of the affected system or potentially execute code.  Note: Only traffic directed to the affected system can be used to exploit this vulnerability. This vulnerability affects systems configured in routed firewall mode only and in single or multiple context mode. This vulnerability can be triggered by IPv4 or IPv6 traffic. A valid TCP connection is needed to perform the attack. The attacker needs to have valid credentials to log in to the Clientless SSL VPN portal.  Cisco has released software updates that address this vulnerability. Workarounds that mitigate this vulnerability are available. This advisory is available at the following link: https://tools.cisco.com/security/center/content/CiscoSecurityAdvisory/cisco-sa-20170208-asa  Conditions: See advisory  Workaround: See advisory  Further Problem Description:  PSIRT Evaluation: The Cisco PSIRT has assigned this bug the following CVSS version 3 score. The Base CVSS score as of the time of evaluation is 8.8: https://tools.cisco.com/security/center/cvssCalculator.x?version=3.0&vector=CVSS:3.0/AV:N/AC:L/PR:L/UI:N/S:U/C:H/I:H/A:H/E:X/RL:X/RC:X  CVE ID CVE-2017-3807 has been assigned to document this issue.  Additional information on Cisco's security vulnerability policy can be found at the following URL: http://www.cisco.com/en/US/products/products_security_vulnerability_policy.html

Title: Cisco FXOS and NX-OS Authentication, Authorization, and Accounting Denial of Service Vulnerability
RNE: Symptom: A vulnerability in the authentication, authorization, and accounting (AAA) implementation of Cisco Firepower Extensible Operating System (FXOS) and NX-OS System Software could allow an unauthenticated, remote attacker to cause an affected device to reload.  The vulnerability occurs because AAA processes prevent the NX-OS System Manager from receiving keepalive messages when an affected device receives a high rate of login attempts, such as in a brute-force login attack. System memory can run low on the FXOS devices under the same conditions, which could cause the AAA process to unexpectedly restart or cause the device to reload.  An attacker could exploit this vulnerability by performing a brute-force login attack against a device that is configured with AAA security services. A successful exploit could allow the attacker to cause the affected device to reload.  Cisco has released software updates that address this vulnerability. There are workarounds that address this vulnerability.  This advisory is available at the following link: https://tools.cisco.com/security/center/content/CiscoSecurityAdvisory/cisco-sa-20171018-aaavty  Conditions: Please refer to the Security Advisory.  Workaround: Please refer to the Security Advisory.  Further Problem Description: Please refer to the Security Advisory.  PSIRT Evaluation: The Cisco PSIRT has assigned this bug the following CVSS version 3 score. The Base CVSS score as of the time of evaluation is 8.6: https://tools.cisco.com/security/center/cvssCalculator.x?version=3.0&vector=CVSS:3.0/AV:N/AC:L/PR:N/UI:N/S:C/C:N/I:N/A:H/E:X/RL:X/RC:X  CVE ID CVE-2017-3883 has been assigned to document this issue.  Additional information on Cisco's security vulnerability policy can be found at the following URL: http://www.cisco.com/en/US/products/products_security_vulnerability_policy.html

Title: Cisco TelePresence TC and TE Software DNS Buffer Overflow Vulnerability
RNE: Symptoms: Cisco TelePresence TC and TE Software are affected by the following vulnerabilities:      Six Session Initiation Protocol (SIP) denial of service vulnerabilities     Cisco TelePresence TC and TE Software DNS Buffer Overflow Vulnerability     Cisco TelePresence TC and TE Software Input Validation Vulnerability     Cisco TelePresence TC and TE Software tshell Command Injection Vulnerability     Cisco TelePresence TC and TE Software Heap Overflow Vulnerability     Cisco TelePresence TC and TE Software U-Boot Buffer Overflow Vulnerability     Cisco TelePresence TC and TE Software Unauthenticated Serial Port Access Vulnerability     Cisco TelePresence TC H.225 Denial of Service Vulnerability  Successful exploitation of these vulnerabilities could allow an attacker to cause the affected system to reload, execute arbitrary commands or obtain privileged access to the affected system.  Note: This security advisory does not provide information about the OpenSSL TLS Heartbeat Read Overrun Vulnerability identified by CVE-2014-0160 (also known as Heartbleed).  For additional information on Cisco products affected by the Heartbleed vulnerability, refer to the Cisco Security Advisory available at the following link:  http://tools.cisco.com/security/center/content/CiscoSecurityAdvisory/cisco-sa-20140409-heartbleed   Cisco has released free software updates that address these vulnerabilities. There are no workarounds that mitigate these vulnerabilities. This advisory is available at the following link: http://tools.cisco.com/security/center/content/CiscoSecurityAdvisory/cisco-sa-20140430-tcte  Conditions: See published Cisco Security Advisory  Symptom:  Conditions:  Workaround: See published Cisco Security Advisory  Further Problem Description: See published Cisco Security Advisory PSIRT Evaluation: The Cisco PSIRT has assigned this bug the following CVSS version 2 score. The Base and Temporal CVSS scores as of the time of evaluation are 7.6/6.3: http://tools.cisco.com/security/center/cvssCalculator.x?vector=AV:N/AC:H/Au:N/C:C/I:C/A:C/E:F/RL:OF/RC:C&version=2.0 CVE ID CVE-2012-3072, CVE-2014-2168 has been assigned to document this issue. Additional information on Cisco's security vulnerability policy can be found at the following URL: http://www.cisco.com/en/US/products/products_security_vulnerability_policy.html
Description: The DNS FSM has a callback for regular DNS lookups which converts the struct addrinfos returned by the resolver library into an FSM message with netaddrs in it.The relevant code is:while (rai) {/* Fill in from addrinfo to struct net_addr in DNS_HOSTENT* for each addrinfo in the linked list */if (netaddr_initFromAddrinfo(&response->addresses[num], rai))++num;elseeventlogputs(;DNS: Skipping one address\n;);rai = rai->ai_next;}Which fails to test that num is less than the actual size of the response->addresses array.This could potentially lead to remotely exploitable buffer overruns, where an attacker able to inject DNS traffic would be allowed to run arbitrary code.

Title: ACL slow-path matching failed for host member in IPv4 obj-group
RNE: Symptoms: An issue in the Object-ACL matching process Cisco Aggregation Services Router 9000 (ASR9K) could allow an unauthenticated, remote attacker to bypass protection offerred by a configured ACL on an affected device.  The issue is due to ASR9K incorrectly handling host access control entries by incorrectly matching ''any'' address instead of the specified ''host'' address. An attacker could exploit this vulnerability to bypass the access control list leading to traffic loss or unwanted permits.  Conditions: ASR9K running affected software.  Workaround: Manually replace ''host ip'' with ''ip/32''  PSIRT Evaluation: The Cisco PSIRT has assigned this bug the following CVSS version 2 score. The Base and Temporal CVSS scores as of the time of evaluation are 5/4.1: http://tools.cisco.com/security/center/cvssCalculator.x?vector=AV:N/AC:L/Au:N/C:P/I:N/A:N/E:F/RL:OF/RC:C&version=2.0 CVE ID CVE-2015-0694 has been assigned to document this issue. Additional information on Cisco's security vulnerability policy can be found at the following URL: http://www.cisco.com/en/US/products/products_security_vulnerability_policy.html

Title: Cross Domain Resource loaded Over HTTP
RNE: $$IGNORE-PSIRT  CISCO HIGHLY CONFIDENTIAL - CONTROLLED ACCESS  This issue is under review by the Cisco Product Security Incident Response team (PSIRT).  The defect describes a product security vulnerability.  Its contents must be protected from unauthorized disclosure, both internal and external to Cisco.  Do not forward this information to mailing lists or newsgroups.  Documentation writers: it is prohibited to publish this Release-note  Enclosure (RNE) until the content has been approved by PSIRT.  PSIRT may  publish a Security Advisory regarding this defect, and the current text of  this RNE will be replaced with appropriate information.  In the event that  a Security Advisory is not published, PSIRT will replace this text with an  appropriate explanation.  More information on PSIRT is available at http//psirt.cisco.com/.   Cisco's public policy on security vulnerability handling can be reviewed at  http://www.cisco.com/en/US/products/products_security_vulnerability_policy.html. For further information, send a message to psirt@cisco.com.  (jklimarc-12/12/17)
Description: The application was observed to include a resource from an external domain via an unencrypted transport (HTTP). By not utilising an encrypted transport, it is significantly harder to verify the integrity of the included resource. An attacker may not be able to modify this resource in transit to perform malicious attacks like Man in the middle. As the affected application is utilising HTTPS, the resources that are included via an unencrypted transport result in a compromise of the confidentiality and integrity protections afforded to the application by using HTTPS.

Title: Cisco Firepower Detection Engine PGM Protocol Decoding Denial of Service Vulnerability
RNE: Symptom: A vulnerability in the detection engine parsing of Pragmatic General Multicast (PGM) protocol packets for Cisco Firepower System Software could allow an unauthenticated, remote attacker to cause a denial of service (DoS) condition due to the Snort process unexpectedly restarting.  The vulnerability is due to improper input validation of the fields in the PGM protocol packet. An attacker could exploit this vulnerability by sending a crafted PGM packet to the detection engine on the targeted device. An exploit could allow the attacker to cause a DoS condition if the Snort process restarts and traffic inspection is bypassed or traffic is dropped.  Cisco has released software updates that address this vulnerability. There are no workarounds that address this vulnerability.  This advisory is available at the following link:  https://tools.cisco.com/security/center/content/CiscoSecurityAdvisory/cisco-sa-20170419-fpsnort  Conditions: Please refer to Security Advisory.  Workaround: Please refer to Security Advisory.  Further Problem Description: Please refer to Security Advisory.  PSIRT Evaluation: The Cisco PSIRT has assigned this bug the following CVSS version 3 score. The Base CVSS score as of the time of evaluation is 8.6: https://tools.cisco.com/security/center/cvssCalculator.x?version=3.0&vector=CVSS:3.0/AV:N/AC:L/PR:N/UI:N/S:C/C:N/I:N/A:H/E:X/RL:X/RC:X  CVE ID CVE-2016-6368 has been assigned to document this issue.  Additional information on Cisco's security vulnerability policy can be found at the following URL: http://www.cisco.com/en/US/products/products_security_vulnerability_policy.html
Description: ===================================================Cisco Snort PGM Protocol Decoding DoS Vulnerability===================================================SUMMARY=======Snort is vulnerable to a denial of service (access violation) when handles IPPGM (Pragmatic General Multicast) protocol packets.Versions 2.9.8.0 and previous are affected.TECHNICAL DETAILS=================Snort has a built-in function pgm_nak_detect in src/decode.c to detectPGM_NAQ_OVERFLOW attacks (CVE-2006-3442). It is called wherever an IP packetwith a PGM header is analyzed.The function calculates the checksum of the PGM header without checking, asrequired by in_chksum_ip, that the header's length is multiple of 4 bytes.For a POC and further exploit details please contact psirt@cisco.com

Title: MRA Edge devices able to register using crdentials from a different user
RNE: Symptoms:  A vulnerability in the edge device of the Cisco Unified Communications Manager (CUCM) using Mobile and Remote Access (MRA) could allow an unauthenticated, remote attacker to hijack a user session.  The vulnerability is due to improper identity validation of the edge device.  An attacker could exploit this vulnerability by hijacking the session of a previously authenticated user. A successful exploit could allow the attacker to hijack the user session and perform actions in the context of the user.  Conditions: In order to exploit this vulnerability, a CUCM registered user must have previously logged in and accessed said edge device before a session hijack can occur.  Workaround: None.  Further Problem Description: None.  PSIRT Evaluation: The Cisco PSIRT has assigned this bug the following CVSS version 2 score. The Base and Temporal CVSS scores as of the time of evaluation are 4/3.3: http://tools.cisco.com/security/center/cvssCalculator.x?vector=AV:N/AC:L/Au:S/C:P/I:N/A:N/E:F/RL:OF/RC:C&version=2.0 CVE ID CVE-2015-6410 has been assigned to document this issue. Additional information on Cisco's security vulnerability policy can be found at the following URL: http://www.cisco.com/en/US/products/products_security_vulnerability_policy.html
Description: 1) MobileRemoteAccess/Collab Edge device  was used by user-X . ie., the device was configured with 'user-x' as 'owner id' etc., 2) The device was registered as user-x's  device . 3) device was physically given to another user ( say user-Y) . Device configuration on CUCM was changed by admin with a different line and owner user id of ' user-Y'4) Device was able to registered by 'user-X' ( the previous owner) using 'User-X's credentials. behavior of system at #4 is not desired. This is deemed as a security issue.   Let me know what logs you need for this .
