Title: ACL leak if "remark" is added to ACL
RNE: Summary A vulnerability exists in Cisco Nexus 5000 and 3000 Series Switches that may allow traffic to bypass deny statements in access control lists (ACLs) that are configured on the device.  Cisco has released free software updates that address this vulnerability.  A workaround is available to mitigate this vulnerability.  This advisory is posted at http://www.cisco.com/warp/public/707/cisco-sa-20110907-nexus.shtml  PSIRT Evaluation: The Cisco PSIRT has assigned this bug the following CVSS version 2 score. The Base and Temporal CVSS scores as of the time of evaluation are 5/4.1:  http://tools.cisco.com/security/center/cvssCalculator.x?vector=AV:N/AC:L/Au:N/C:P/I:N/A:N/E:F/RL:OF/RC:C&version=2.0  CVE ID CVE-2011-2581 has been assigned to document this issue.  Additional information on Cisco's security vulnerability policy can be found at the following URL: http://www.cisco.com/en/US/products/products_security_vulnerability_policy.html
Description: Remark in following ACL is equivalent to permit everything after that and also you wont see any statistics log hitting the acl as well. IP access list test        statistics per-entry         10 permit tcp any any established [match=46]         11 permit tcp any 192.85.3.0/24 eq bgp [match=0]         20 permit tcp any eq bgp any [match=0]         39 permit pim 192.85.3.0/24 any [match=23]         60 remark multicast groups        71 permit udp any 233.200.79.1/27 [match=0] The ACL work as expected without the remark comment.

Title: Upgrade NTPd used within Cisco UCM.
RNE: Symptom: NTP package used within this product requires upgrading due to know security vulnerability.  Conditions: Versions prior to first fixed release contain a version of NTP package that is vulnerable to CVE-2009-3563  Workaround: * Filter NTP mode 7 packets coming into and/or going out of your network. * Filter NTP mode 7 packets where both the source and destination ports are 123, the privileged NTP port. * Employ anti-spoofing IP address filters at your borders to prevent UDP traffic claiming to be from a local address that originate outside your network.   Further Problem Description An unexpected NTP mode 7 packets (MODE_PRIVATE) with spoofed IP data can lead ntpd to reply with a mode 7 response to the spoofed address.  This may result in the service playing packet ping-pong with other ntp servers or even itself which causes CPU usage and excessive disk use due to logging.  An attacker can use this to conduct denial of service attacks.
Description: UCM is vulnerable to CVE-2009-3563:Upon receipt of an incorrect mode 7 request or a mode 7 error response from an address which is not listed in a ;restrict ... noquery; or ;restrict ... ignore; statement, ntpd will reply with a mode 7 error response (and log a message).  Affects all versions of NTPd from ntp.org
PSIRT: PSIRT-owner: psirt@cisco.com          This issue has been evaluated and driven to closure by PSIRT.  PSIRT has provided a public Release-note Enclosure (RNE) for this issue which is visible on Cisco.com.   If a customer is being impacted by this issue, please guide them to the 'Workaround' section of the RNE or recommend a software upgrade to a patched release. There is no need to contact PSIRT for this issue.  Do not provide customers with any information beyond what is currently contained in the RNE.

Title: Cisco ACS Dom-based XSS Vulnerability
RNE: Symptom: A vulnerability in the Cisco Secure Access Control Server (ACS) web interface could allow an unauthenticated,  remote attacker to impact the integrity of the system by executing a Document Object Model (DOM) Based (environment  or client side) cross-site scripting (XSS) attack.  The vulnerability is due to a lack of input validation on user-supplied data within the DOM input. An attacker could exploit  this vulnerability by sending crafted URLs that contain malicious DOM statements to the affected system. An exploit could  allow the attacker to effect the integrity of the system because of database manipulation.  Conditions: Device running with default configuration running an affected version of software.  Workaround: None.  Further Problem Description: Additional information about XSS attacks and potential mitigations can be found at:  https://www.owasp.org/index.php/DOM_Based_XSS https://www.owasp.org/index.php/Types_of_Cross-Site_Scripting#DOM_Based_XSS_.28AKA_Type-0.29  PSIRT Evaluation: The Cisco PSIRT has assigned this bug the following CVSS version 2 score. The Base and Temporal CVSS scores as of the time of evaluation are 4.3/4.1: http://tools.cisco.com/security/center/cvssCalculator.x?vector=AV:N/AC:M/Au:N/C:N/I:P/A:N/E:F/RL:U/RC:C&version=2.0 CVE ID CVE-2015-6346 has been assigned to document this issue. Additional information on Cisco's security vulnerability policy can be found at the following URL: http://www.cisco.com/en/US/products/products_security_vulnerability_policy.html

Title: IDFW NetBIOS Logout Probe Auth State Change Vulnerability
RNE: Symptoms: Limitations of the NetBIOS logout probe functionality of the Cisco Adaptive Security Appliance (ASA) Identity Firewall (IDFW) feature allows for manipulation of currently authenticated users.  Conditions: Installation of an affected release of ASA software configured to make use of the ''user-identity logout-probe netbios local-system'' configuration of the IDFW feature.  Workaround: Do not configure the use of NetBIOS logout probes for the IDFW feature.  PSIRT Evaluation: The Cisco PSIRT has assigned this bug the following CVSS version 2 score. The Base and Temporal CVSS scores as of the time of evaluation are 4.3/3.9: http://tools.cisco.com/security/center/cvssCalculator.x?vector=AV:N/AC:M/Au:N/C:N/I:P/A:N/E:POC/RL:U/RC:C&version=2.0 CVE ID CVE-2014-0653 has been assigned to document this issue.  Additional details about the vulnerability described here can be found at: http://tools.cisco.com/security/center/content/CiscoSecurityNotice/CVE-2014-0653  Additional information on Cisco's security vulnerability policy can be found at the following URL: http://www.cisco.com/en/US/products/products_security_vulnerability_policy.html
Description: One option when configuring the identity firewall feature is that of a logout  probe. Since active directory agent has no method of discovering logout events, a netbios probe option is available to allow an ASA to decide if a user at a particular IP address is still on the network.  The probe command is:  user-identity logout-probe netbios local-system <options>The 3 options are:  exact-match - The probed machine must respond with a packet containing only one username, which must match the username associated with the IP address in the ASA's IDFW database.  match-any - The probed machine must respond with a packet containing any number of usernames, only one of which must match the username associated with the IP address in the ASA's IDFW database.  user-not-needed - The probed machine must respond with a packet, but no check on username is performed by the ASA.Using any of these options, however, will open up the user to one of two attacks.See attack_examples enclosure for additional details.
PSIRT: PSIRT-owner: psirt@cisco.com           This issue has been evaluated and driven to closure by PSIRT.  PSIRT has provided a public Release-note Enclosure (RNE) for this issue which is visible on Cisco.com. Title: Cisco ASA VNMC Input Validation Vulnerability
RNE: Symptom: Cisco Adaptive Security Appliance (ASA) Software is affected by the following vulnerabilities:      Cisco ASA SQL*NET Inspection Engine Denial of Service Vulnerability     Cisco ASA VPN Denial of Service Vulnerability     Cisco ASA IKEv2 Denial of Service Vulnerability     Cisco ASA High Performance Monitor Denial of Service Vulnerability     Cisco ASA GPRS Tunneling Protocol Inspection Engine Denial of Service Vulnerability     Cisco ASA SunRPC Inspection Engine Denial of Service Vulnerability     Cisco ASA DNS Inspection Engine Denial of Service Vulnerability     Cisco ASA VPN Failover Command Injection Vulnerability     Cisco ASA VNMC Command Input Validation Vulnerability     Cisco ASA Local Path Inclusion Vulnerability     Cisco ASA Clientless SSL VPN Information Disclosure and Denial of Service Vulnerability     Cisco ASA Clientless SSL VPN Portal Customization Integrity Vulnerability     Cisco ASA Smart Call Home Digital Certificate Validation Vulnerability  These vulnerabilities are independent of one another; a release that is affected by one of the vulnerabilities may not be affected by the others.  Successful exploitation of the Cisco ASA SQL*NET Inspection Engine Denial of Service Vulnerability, Cisco ASA VPN Denial of Service Vulnerability, Cisco ASA IKEv2 Denial of Service Vulnerability, Cisco ASA High Performance Monitor Denial of Service Vulnerability, Cisco ASA GPRS Tunneling Protocol Inspection Engine Denial of Service Vulnerability, Cisco ASA SunRPC Inspection Engine Denial of Service Vulnerability, and Cisco ASA DNS Inspection Engine Denial of Service Vulnerability may result in a reload of an affected device, leading to a denial of service (DoS) condition.  Successful exploitation of the Cisco ASA VPN Failover Command Injection Vulnerability, Cisco ASA VNMC Command Input Validation Vulnerability, and Cisco ASA Local Path Inclusion Vulnerability may result in full compromise of the affected system.  Successful exploitation of the Cisco ASA Clientless SSL VPN Information Disclosure and Denial of Service Vulnerability may result in the disclosure of internal information or, in some cases, a reload of the affected system.  Successful exploitation of the Cisco ASA Clientless SSL VPN Portal Customization Integrity Vulnerability may result in a compromise of the Clientless SSL VPN portal, which may lead to several types of attacks, which are not limited to cross-site scripting (XSS), stealing of credentials, or redirects of users to malicious web pages.  Successful exploitation of the Cisco ASA Smart Call Home Digital Certificate Validation Vulnerability may result in a digital certificate validation bypass, which could allow the attacker to bypass digital certificate authentication and gain access inside the network via remote access VPN or management access to the affected system via the Cisco Adaptive Security Device Management (ASDM).  Cisco has released free software updates that address these vulnerabilities. Workarounds that mitigate some of these vulnerabilities are available.  This advisory is available at the following link: http://tools.cisco.com/security/center/content/CiscoSecurityAdvisory/cisco-sa-20141008-asa  Conditions: See published Cisco Security Advisory  Workaround: See published Cisco Security Advisory  PSIRT Evaluation: The Cisco PSIRT has assigned this bug the following CVSS version 2 score. The Base and Temporal CVSS sscores as of the time of evaluation are 6.5/6.2: http://tools.cisco.com/security/center/cvssCalculator.x?vector=AV:L/AC:L/Au:M/C:C/I:C/A:C/E:F/RL:OF/RC:C&version=2.0 CVE ID CVE-2014-3390 has been assigned to document this issue. Additional information on Cisco's security vulnerability policy can be found at the following URL: http://www.cisco.com/en/US/products/products_security_vulnerability_policy.html
Description: This vulnerability is quite serious as it allows a ;jailbreak; escape from the restricted CLI environment and into the underlying Linux OS.The vulnerability is found in the Cisco ASA 9.2 (on a 5505) and it seems it has been carried across from the Cisco 1000v code.The vulnerability stems from a parsing flaw and unfiltered user-input to a shell command.The vulnerability can be exploited as: ciscoasa(config)# vnmc policy-agentciscoasa(config-vnmc-policy-agent)#ciscoasa(config-vnmc-policy-agent)# registration host 1.1.1.1ciscoasa(config-vnmc-policy-agent)# shared-secret |/mnt/disk0/revsocat.sh (shared-secret &/mnt/disk0/revsocat.sh  will also work)Please contact Omar Santos (os@cisco.com) to obtain access to the script - revsocat.shWhere revsocat.sh and socat has been uploaded to disk0:  using standard ftp/scp etc...The result is access to the underlying Linux OS.. from here a malicious user could infect (ptrace) the running LINA process to insert hidden config etc..

Title: CUCM Cross Site Scripting vulnerability in ccmivr page
RNE: Symptom: A vulnerability in several parameters of the ccmivr page of Cisco Unified Communication Manager (CallManager) could allow an unauthenticated, remote attacker to a cross-site scripting (XSS) attack against a user of the web interface on the affected system.  The vulnerability is due to insufficient input validation of some parameters used by that page.  An attacker could exploit this vulnerability by convincing the user of the system to follow an attacker supplied link.  An exploit could allow the attacker to cause arbitrary script or HTML code to be executed on the users browser within the context of the affected application.  Conditions: Running a version prior to the Known Fixed Releases.  Workaround: None  Further Problem Description: PSIRT Evaluation: The Cisco PSIRT has assigned this bug the following CVSS version 2 score. The Base and Temporal CVSS scores as of the time of evaluation are 4.3/3.6: http://tools.cisco.com/security/center/cvssCalculator.x?vector=AV:N/AC:M/Au:N/C:N/I:P/A:N/E:F/RL:OF/RC:C&version=2.0  CVE ID CVE-2015-4272 has been assigned to document this issue.  Additional information on Cisco's security vulnerability policy can be found at the following URL: http://www.cisco.com/en/US/products/products_security_vulnerability_policy.html
Description: In order to exploit the vulnerability, an attacker would build a carefully crafted link and trick their victim info following this link. When the victim navigates to the attacker's link, their Web browser will execute the attacker supplied JavaScript, which in turn can perform malicious actions on the CCM Web applications on behalf of the user.Steps to reproduce:In order to reproduce the issue, please navigate tohttps://10.36.41.11/ccmivr/IVRReturntoMain.do?ccmusername=%22%3E%3Cscript%3Ealert%2823%29%3C/script%3EHave attached excel sheet which has snap shot from customer issue in sheet 4.2Customer saw the issue on 10.5.1.10000-7 versionPossible fix:Need to verify the input that is provided.

Title: Cisco ASA Cross Site Scripting SSLVPN Vulnerability
RNE: Symptom: A vulnerability in the HTTP Web based management interface of the Cisco Adaptive  Security Appliance (ASA) could allow an unauthenticated, remote attacker to conduct a cross-site scripting (XSS) attack against a user of the web interface of the  affected system.  The vulnerability is due to insufficient input validation of a user-supplied value.  An attacker could exploit this vulnerability by convincing a user to follow a malicious  link. An exploit could allow the attacker to execute arbitrary script code in the context  of the affected  site or allow the attacker to access sensitive browser-based information.  Conditions: Device running with default configuration running an affected version of software.  Workaround: None.  Further Problem Description: Additional information about XSS attacks and potential mitigations can be found at:  http://www.cisco.com/en/US/products/cmb/cisco-amb-20060922-understanding-xss.html https://www.owasp.org/index.php/Cross-site_Scripting_(XSS)  Credit: Cisco would like to thank Adam Willard, Raytheon Foreground Security, for reporting this vulnerability. The Base and Temporal CVSS scores as of the time of evaluation are 3.5/3.3: http://tools.cisco.com/security/center/cvssCalculator.x?vector=AV:N/AC:M/Au:S/C:N/I:P/A:N/E:F/RL:U/RC:C&version=2.0 No CVE ID has been assigned to this issue. Additional information on Cisco's security vulnerability policy can be found at the following URL: http://www.cisco.com/en/US/products/products_security_vulnerability_policy.html

One (ours says no domain found) and then the second is the alert(1).==This has worked in Internet Explorer but did not work in Firefox. Chrome has not been tested.https://XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX/+CSCOE+/files/browse.html?code=init&path=\');alert(1);//cifs%3A%2F%2FUsersfunction loadContent(){  showTable();        top.last_dir = nullshowDir('\\');alert(1);//cifs://Users', 'init', true);window.onresize();}It appears the ' is escaped but the \ is not.This has been tested on two customer's sites.

Title: Credentials configured for LDAP Authentication Method saved in the clear
RNE: Symptom: The Cisco Email Security Appliance (ESA) if configured for Lightweight Directory Access Protocol (LDAP) authentication does not store credentials used to access other server resources in an encrypted format.  The LDAP server credentials are not stored encrypted on the ESA. These unencrypted credentials expose  the application and its elements to attack.  Conditions: Having a configured LDAP profile and using credentials for the Authentication Method instead of an anonymous connection.  Workaround: None.  Further Problem Description: None  PSIRT Evaluation: The Cisco PSIRT has assigned this bug the following CVSS version 2 score. The Base and Temporal CVSS scores as of the time of evaluation are 1.7/1.6: http://tools.cisco.com/security/center/cvssCalculator.x?vector=AV:L/AC:L/Au:S/C:P/I:N/A:N/E:F/RL:U/RC:C&version=2.0 No CVE ID has been assigned to this issue. Additional information on Cisco's security vulnerability policy can be found at the following URL: http://www.cisco.com/en/US/products/products_security_vulnerability_policy.html
Description: When configured, the credentials specified for the Authentication Method inside the LDAP configuration are stored in clear text in the live config.bluedevil:service 2] grep servers /data/db/config/hermes.ldap/data.cfgservers = (2,1436904927431957L,;503DE59E33C6-FCH1609V041;,;admin;,{;dummy_ldap;:{;authtype;:;password;,;name;:;dummy_ldap;,;server_type;:;;,;hostname;:;172.16.0.1;,;authdata;:{;password;:;DummyLDAPP@$w0rd;,;user;:;DummyLDAPuser;},;connection_behavior;:;load_balance;,;port;:3268,;base;:;dc=example,dc=com;,;cache_size;:10000,;use_ssl;:0,;cache_ttl;:900,;compatibility;:{},;max_connections;:10}})In the above information, you can clearly see that in the LDAP profile ;DummyLDAP;, we are using the credentials:user ID: DummyLDAPuserPassword: DummyLDAPP@$w0rd

Title: Security Vulnerability IX running 8.1.2.1(3) for port 6970
RNE: $$IGNORE-PSIRT  CISCO HIGHLY CONFIDENTIAL - CONTROLLED ACCESS  This issue is under review by the Cisco Product Security Incident Response team (PSIRT).  The defect describes a product security vulnerability.  Its contents must be protected from unauthorized disclosure, both internal and external to Cisco.  Do not forward this information to mailing lists or newsgroups.  Documentation writers: it is prohibited to publish this Release-note  Enclosure (RNE) until the content has been approved by PSIRT.  PSIRT may  publish a Security Advisory regarding this defect, and the current text of  this RNE will be replaced with appropriate information.  In the event that  a Security Advisory is not published, PSIRT will replace this text with an  appropriate explanation.  More information on PSIRT is available at http//psirt.cisco.com/.   Cisco's public policy on security vulnerability handling can be reviewed at  http://www.cisco.com/en/US/products/products_security_vulnerability_policy.html. For further information, send a message to psirt@cisco.com.  (fcasotto-05/11/17)  Symptom: Allowing a remote, unauthenticated user to read any file as root (WebUI issue on :6970)  Conditions: Web browsers generally canonicalize so the issue won't be able to reproduce in IE/Chrome/Firefox. It can be done either from a Linux machine's terminal or from a raw putty session.  Workaround:  Further Problem Description: it looks like it's limited to the service on port 6970 - Some kind of HTTP server. It can be reproduced with  ;curl --path-as-is http://IPaddress:6970/../../../../etc/shadowhttp://IP?address:6970/../../../../etc/shadow  ;  o   The path-as-is option is really important, as without it curl is going to canonicalize the path and it won't pull anything o   Web browsers generally canonicalize so it is not able to be reproduced in IE/Chrome/Firefox.  *    Shadow would take a while to crack -  but if you change it to   ;curl http://IP address:6970/../../../../nv/usr/local/etc/ccm-cfg.xml   ; =it will have plain-text credentials in the SSHGroup section  Even this also works :   ;curl http://IP Address:6970/nv/usr/local/etc/ccm-cfg.xml ;  Reproduction//Putty You could do it in putty if you set the following options: *         Host: IP address *         Port: 6970 *         Connection type: Raw  Then copy-paste the following line and hit enter twice:   ;GET /../../../../nv/usr/local/etc/ccm-cfg.xml HTTP/1.1 ;
Description: Issue in the IX series device, allowing a remote, unauthenticated user to read any file as root (WebUI issue on :6970)After exploration, the attacker downloaded the configuration files containing plaintext passwords (/nv/usr/local/etc/ccm-cfg.xml, section 'SSHGroup')These passwords allowed the attacker to remotely administer the device (SSH/WebUI)These passwords are good for wider telepresence systems.

Title: FI rebooted due to CDP hap reset
RNE: $$IGNORE-PSIRT  Symptom: FI rebooted due to CDP process crash.  Conditions: Observed during normal operations.  Workaround: If CDP is still crashes immediately after FI reboot, execute the following commands to avoid FI reboot.   connect nxos  system no hap-reset   Contact with CDP core dump files.  Further Problem Description:
Description: UCSM 2.2.6e , FI 6296During normal operations, CDP on both FI crashed and resulted in reboot of FI Core dump fileshttp://www-tac.cisco.com/Teams/ks/c3/getLargeFile.php?srId=681654082&fileName=cisco-logs.zipLab re-create steps Configure windows 7 laptop / OS interface with 9 or 10 IPv6 addresses Connect the device to FI port and flap the interface. FI will continue to be reboot as long as device is connected to FI / port is in enabled state. CDP crashes due to buffer overflow as number of IP addresses exceeds the limit for the neighbor node.

Title: Cisco AnyConnect XSS Vulnerability
RNE: Symptoms: Cisco AnyConnect Secure Mobility Client and Cisco Host Scan are vulnerable to XSS attack  Conditions: Attacker needs to convince a user to use a crafted URL  Workaround: none  Further Problem Description:  A vulnerability in Cisco AnyConnect Secure Mobility Client and Cisco Host Scan could allow an unauthenticated, remote attacker to conduct a cross-site scripting (XSS) attack against the user of the client when AnyConnect is launched through the web interface.  The vulnerability is due to insufficient validation of an URL used build a path to an applet inside a Document Object Model. An attacker could exploit this vulnerability by convincing a user to click on a malicious URL.  This issue has been reported to cisco by Jason Sinchak  Additional information about XSS and mitigation can be found at: http://tools.cisco.com/security/center/content/CiscoAppliedMitigationBulletin/cisco-amb-20060922-understanding-xss PSIRT Evaluation: The Cisco PSIRT has assigned this bug the following CVSS version 2 score. The Base and Temporal CVSS scores as of the time of evaluation are 4.3/4.3: http://tools.cisco.com/security/center/cvssCalculator.x?vector=AV:N/AC:M/Au:N/C:N/I:P/A:N/E:H/RL:U/RC:C&version=2.0 CVE ID CVE-2014-8021 has been assigned to document this issue.  Additional details about the vulnerability described here can be found at: http://tools.cisco.com/security/center/content/CiscoSecurityNotice/CVE-2014-8021  Additional information on Cisco's security vulnerability policy can be found at the following URL: http://www.cisco.com/en/US/products/products_security_vulnerability_policy.html

Title: Cisco FireSIGHT MC stored XSS in Devices VPN

The vulnerability is due to improper sanitization of parameter values. An attacker could exploit this vulnerability by injecting malicious code into an affected parameter and then convincing the user to access a web page that would trigger the execution of the injected code. Title: Cisco AnyConnect Network Access Manager Dual-Homed Interface Vulnerability
RNE: Symptom: A vulnerability in the Network Access Manager (NAM) of Cisco AnyConnect Secure Mobility Client could allow an authenticated, local attacker to enable multiple network adapters.      The vulnerability is due to insufficient NAM policy enforcement. An attacker could exploit this vulnerability by manipulating network interfaces of the device to allow multiple active network interfaces. A successful exploit could allow the attacker to send traffic over a non-authorized network interface.      Cisco has released software updates that address this vulnerability. Workarounds that address this vulnerability are not available.      This advisory is available at the following link:     https://tools.cisco.com/security/center/content/CiscoSecurityAdvisory/cisco-sa-20171004-anam  Conditions: An affected release of Cisco AnyConnect Mobility Client with a NAM policy restricting active network interfaces.  Workaround: None.  Further Problem Description: PSIRT Evaluation: The Cisco PSIRT has assigned this bug the following CVSS version 3 score. The Base CVSS score as of the time of evaluation is 5.5: https://tools.cisco.com/security/center/cvssCalculator.x?version=3.0&vector=CVSS:3.0/AV:L/AC:L/PR:L/UI:N/S:U/C:H/I:N/A:N/E:X/RL:X/RC:X  CVE ID CVE-2017-12268 has been assigned to document this issue.  Additional information on Cisco's security vulnerability policy can be found at the following URL: http://www.cisco.com/en/US/products/products_security_vulnerability_policy.html
Description: They are using NAM to connect to a corporate wired network, and wireless adapter is disabled at this time. When they reboot machine, log back on they successfully connect to the wired network.However ,after this completes, users can then attach to a second wireless network via MS networking while wire connected to the corporate network and data can be passed between the networks. Ideally this Dual homing scenario should be prevented.

Title: CUCM affected by Apache Tomcat vulnerabilities
RNE: Symptom: Cisco Unified Communications Manager and Unified Communications Manager Session Management Edition includes a version of Apache Tomcat that is affected by the vulnerabilities identified by the following Common  Vulnerability and Exposures (CVE) IDs:   CVE-2017-7674 CVE-2017-12616  This bug was opened to address the potential impact on this product.  Conditions: Device with default configuration. The CUCM versions that appear affected are: 12.0(1.10000.10) 11.5(1.10000.6) 11.0(1.10000.10) 10.5(2.10000.5) 10.0(1.10000.24) 9.1(2.10000.28)  admin:show packages active tomcat Active Side Package(s): for tomcat package(s) platform-tomcat-1.0.0.0-1.i386 cm-cmtomcat-1.1.0.0-1.i386 cm-tomcatstats-0.0.0.1-0.i386 tomcat-7.0.64-0.i386  Workaround: Not currently available.  Further Problem Description: Additional details about the vulnerabilities listed above can be found at  http://cve.mitre.org/cve/cve.html or https://nvd.nist.gov/vuln/detail/CVE-2017-7674.  PSIRT Evaluation: The Cisco PSIRT has assigned this bug the following CVSS version 3 score. The Base CVSS score as of the time of evaluation is 4.3: https://tools.cisco.com/security/center/cvssCalculator.x?version=3.0&vector=CVSS:3.0/AV:N/AC:L/PR:N/UI:R/S:U/C:N/I:L/A:N/E:X/RL:X/RC:X  CVE ID CVE-2017-7674 and CVE-2017-12616 has been assigned to document this issue.  Additional information on Cisco's security vulnerability policy can be found at the following URL: http://www.cisco.com/en/US/products/products_security_vulnerability_policy.html
Description: New Apache Tomcat vulnerabilities has reported and would like to know how they effect Call manager and UC applicationsCVE-2017-7674 Description:The CORS Filter in Apache Tomcat 9.0.0.M1 to 9.0.0.M21, 8.5.0 to 8.5.15, 8.0.0.RC1 to 8.0.44 and 7.0.41 to 7.0.78 did not add an HTTP Vary header indicating that the response varies depending on Origin. This permitted client and server side cache poisoning in some circumstances.

Title: SCCP inspection DoS vulnerability

Title: IR800 Integrated Services Router ROM Monitor Input Validation Vulnerability
RNE: Symptom: A vulnerability in the ROM Monitor (ROMMON) code of Cisco IR800 Integrated Services Router Software could allow an unauthenticated, local attacker to boot an unsigned Hypervisor on an affected device and compromise the integrity of the system.  The vulnerability is due to insufficient sanitization of user input. An attacker who can access an affected router via the console could exploit this vulnerability by entering ROMMON mode and modifying ROMMON variables. A successful exploit could allow the attacker to execute arbitrary code and install a malicious version of Hypervisor firmware on an affected device.  There are no workarounds that address this vulnerability.  This advisory is available at the following link: https://tools.cisco.com/security/center/content/CiscoSecurityAdvisory/cisco-sa-20170906-isr  Conditions: No special condition. The issue happen to rommon-1, which is in the earlier stages of the system boot.  Workaround: There is no workaround.  PSIRT Evaluation: The Cisco PSIRT has assigned this bug the following CVSS version 3 score. The Base CVSS score as of the time of evaluation is 6.4: https://tools.cisco.com/security/center/cvssCalculator.x?version=3.0&vector=CVSS:3.0/AV:P/AC:H/PR:N/UI:N/S:U/C:H/I:H/A:H/E:X/RL:X/RC:X  CVE ID CVE-2017-12223 has been assigned to document this issue.  Additional information on Cisco's security vulnerability policy can be found at the following URL: http://www.cisco.com/en/US/products/products_security_vulnerability_policy.html
Description: It is possible to boot an unsigned hypervisor and do anything on IR800 by abusing a command injection vulnerability in rommon-1. Title: Cisco Identity Services Engine EAP-TLS Certificate Denial of Service Vulnerability
RNE: $$IGNORE-PSIRT  CISCO HIGHLY CONFIDENTIAL - CONTROLLED ACCESS  This issue is under review by the Cisco Product Security Incident Response team (PSIRT).  The defect describes a product security vulnerability.  Its contents must be protected from unauthorized disclosure, both internal and external to Cisco.  Do not forward this information to mailing lists or newsgroups.  Documentation writers: it is prohibited to publish this Release-note  Enclosure (RNE) until the content has been approved by PSIRT.  PSIRT may  publish a Security Advisory regarding this defect, and the current text of  this RNE will be replaced with appropriate information.  In the event that  a Security Advisory is not published, PSIRT will replace this text with an  appropriate explanation.  More information on PSIRT is available at http//psirt.cisco.com/.   Cisco's public policy on security vulnerability handling can be reviewed at  http://www.cisco.com/en/US/products/products_security_vulnerability_policy.html. For further information, send a message to psirt@cisco.com.  (tfinn-06/09/17)  $$IGNORE-PSIRT  Symptoms: A vulnerability in the Extensible Authentication Protocol (EAP)-TLS certificate handling  during SSL connection setup for the Cisco Identity Services Engine (ISE) could allow an  unauthenticated, remote attacker to cause the ISE application server to unexpectedly restart.  The vulnerability is due to incomplete input validation of the client EAP-TLS certificate. An  attacker could exploit this vulnerability by initiating a SSL connection to the ISE with a crafted  EAP-TLS certificate. An exploit could allow the attacker to cause a DoS condition due to the ISE  application server restarting. The ISE application could continue to restart while the client  attempts the SSL connection.  The same EAP-TSL certificate if imported to the ISE trust store by an administrator user could  cause the same DoS condition. This exploit would require valid administrator credentials.  Conditions: TBD - Vulnerable versions.  Workaround: None.  Further Problem Description: None.  PSIRT Evaluation: The Cisco PSIRT has assigned this bug the following CVSS version 3 score. The Base CVSS score as of the time of evaluation is 8.6: https://tools.cisco.com/security/center/cvssCalculator.x?version=3.0&vector=CVSS:3.0/AV:N/AC:L/PR:N/UI:N/S:C/C:N/I:N/A:H/E:X/RL:X/RC:X  CVE ID  has been assigned to document this issue.  Additional information on Cisco's security vulnerability policy can be found at the following URL: http://www.cisco.com/en/US/products/products_security_vulnerability_policy.html
Description: Certificates with special characters DDoS ISEClient with special characters running EAP-TLS crashes ISE's application process after sending the certificate.This can be reproduced by adding the certificate into the trusted store as wellTest certificate contained: O = FORSVARSMAKTEN (swedish O)OpenSSL contains O=F\xC3\x96RSVARSMAKTEN

Title: Cisco IOS and Cisco IOS XE input queue holding Vulnerability
RNE: Symptom: A vulnerability in the UDP processing code of Cisco IOS and Cisco IOS XE Software could allow an unauthenticated, remote attacker to cause the input queue of an affected system to hold UDP packets, causing an interface queue wedge and a denial of service (DoS) condition.  The vulnerability is due to Cisco IOS Software application changes that create UDP sockets and leave the sockets idle without closing them. An attacker could exploit this vulnerability by sending UDP packets with a destination port of 0 to an affected device. A successful exploit could allow the attacker to cause UDP packets to be held in the input interfaces queue, resulting in a DoS condition. The input interface queue will stop holding UDP packets when it receives 250 packets.  There are workarounds that address this vulnerability.   This advisory is available at the following link: https://tools.cisco.com/security/center/content/CiscoSecurityAdvisory/cisco-sa-20170906-ios-udp  Conditions: This issue is addressed via different bugs id, consult the advisory https://tools.cisco.com/security/center/content/CiscoSecurityAdvisory/cisco-sa-20170906-ios-udp for further details.  Device with default configuration.  Below table indicates affected trains and fixed releases.  Cisco IOS Software 15.1GC Train		Vulnerable 15.2GC Train		Vulnerable 15.2GCA Train		Vulnerable 15.4(3)M Train		Vulnerable, first fixed in 15.4(3)M8 15.4(2)T Train		Vulnerable, first fixed in 15.4(2)T3 15.6(2)S4		Vulnerable  No other Cisco IOS Software trains/releases are affected.  Cisco IOS XE Software   3.14S Train:		Vulnerable  3.15S Train:		Vulnerable  3.16S Train:   	Vulnerable, first fixed in 3.16.6S  3.16XB Train:		Vulnerable  3.17S Train:		Vulnerable  3.18S/SP Trains:	Vulnerable   No other Cisco IOS XE Software trains/releases are affected.  Cisco IOS XE 16.x Software  16.1 Train:		Not Vulnerable  16.2 Train:		Vulnerable  16.3 Train:		Vulnerable, first fixed in 16.3.3  16.4 and later trains: Not Vulnerable  Workaround: None.  In the event that the interface has a input hold queue  250, the interface would wedge.  Configure the affected interface with a hold queue greater  than 250.  If the hold queue was originally 75 configure the hold queue for 325 (75   250).  Router(config)#interface fastEthernet 0/0 Router(config-if)#hold-queue 325 in  Further Problem Description: PSIRT Evaluation: The Cisco PSIRT has assigned this bug the following CVSS version 3 score. The Base CVSS score as of the time of evaluation is 5.3: https://tools.cisco.com/security/center/cvssCalculator.x?version=3.0&vector=CVSS:3.0/AV:N/AC:L/PR:N/UI:N/S:U/C:N/I:N/A:L/E:X/RL:X/RC:X  CVE ID CVE-2017-6627 has been assigned to document this issue.  Additional information on Cisco's security vulnerability policy can be found at the following URL: http://www.cisco.com/en/US/products/products_security_vulnerability_policy.html
Description: vob/ios/sys/man_infra_server.c creates a ;dummy; UDP socket which actually receives all the messages addressed to UDP port 0.ipsla_isr2-1#sh udpProto        Remote      Port      Local       Port  In Out  Stat TTY OutputIF... 17     0.0.0.0             0 --any--             0   0   0   211   0 ipsla_isr2-1#sh udp detail ...Proto        Remote      Port      Local       Port  In Out  Stat TTY OutputIF 17     0.0.0.0             0 --any--             0   0   0   211   0  Queues: output 0         input  0 (drops 0, max 50, highwater 0)This happens in this code:    /*     * We open a ;dummy; file descriptor in order to force socket_select     * to watch for events OTHER than sockets -- for instance, we can have     * socket_select watch for events coming in on our watched queue. In      * that event, the select will return -1, and errno will be set to      * EINTR.      */    server_context.dummy_fd = manet_infra_socket_open();    if (socket_watch_other_events(watch) == -1) {        if (MANET_INFRA_DEBUG_ERROR) {            buginf(;\n%s: socket_watch_other_events FAILED.;,                     MANET_INFRA_DEBUG_FUNCTION);        }    }

Title: Evaluation of mse for Apache Tomcat October 2017 Vulnerability
RNE: Symptom: This bug has been filed to evaluate the product against the Apache Tomcat vulnerability released on  October 3rd, 2017 by the Apache Software Foundation, identified by CVE ID:  CVE-2017-12617: Apache Tomcat HTTP PUT Arbitrary File Upload Vulnerability  Cisco has evaluated the impact of the vulnerability on this product and concluded that the product is  not affected.  Conditions: Not applicable  Workaround: Not applicable  Further Problem Description: None.  PSIRT Evaluation: The Cisco PSIRT has evaluated this issue and does not meet the criteria for PSIRT ownership or  involvement. This issue, if applicable, will be addressed via normal resolution channels.  If you believe that there is new information that would cause a change in the severity of this issue,  please contact psirt@cisco.com for another evaluation.
Description: PLEASE READ THIS ENTIRE DESCRIPTION AND THE INCLUDED LINKS BEFORE TAKING ANY ACTION.On October 3rd, 2017 the Apache Software Foundation disclosed CVE-2017-12617 Apache Tomcat HTTP PUT Arbitrary File Upload Vulnerability.When running with HTTP PUTs enabled (e.g. via setting the readonly initialisation parameter of the Default servlet to false) it was possible to upload a JSP file to the server via a specially crafted request. This JSP could then be requested and any code it contained would be executed by the server.This bug has been filed against the product Cisco Mobility Services Engineto address this vulnerability:CVE-2017-12617 Apache Tomcat HTTP PUT Arbitrary File Upload VulnerabilityPLEASE EVALUATE YOUR PRODUCT BY FILLING IN THE FORM AT:https://psirt-apps.cisco.com/bugdom_pub/pre_eval.php?slip_id=PSIRT-0148469704 IMPORTANT NOTE ABOUT SEVERITY: If the bug has a Severity of *issue_not_a_bug_or_enhancement (Sev7)*, then CHANGE THE SEVERITY to Sev 2. The bug may have been raised initially as Sev 7 to overcome some CDETS limitations when filing hundreds of bugs for ALL potentially affected Cisco products.

Title: Cisco TP TC Software SIP Denial of Service Vulnerability
RNE: Symptoms: Cisco TelePresence TC and TE Software are affected by the following vulnerabilities:      Six Session Initiation Protocol (SIP) denial of service vulnerabilities     Cisco TelePresence TC and TE Software DNS Buffer Overflow Vulnerability     Cisco TelePresence TC and TE Software Input Validation Vulnerability     Cisco TelePresence TC and TE Software tshell Command Injection Vulnerability     Cisco TelePresence TC and TE Software Heap Overflow Vulnerability     Cisco TelePresence TC and TE Software U-Boot Buffer Overflow Vulnerability     Cisco TelePresence TC and TE Software Unauthenticated Serial Port Access Vulnerability     Cisco TelePresence TC H.225 Denial of Service Vulnerability  Successful exploitation of these vulnerabilities could allow an attacker to cause the affected system to reload, execute arbitrary commands or obtain privileged access to the affected system.  Note: This security advisory does not provide information about the OpenSSL TLS Heartbeat Read Overrun Vulnerability identified by CVE-2014-0160 (also known as Heartbleed).  For additional information on Cisco products affected by the Heartbleed vulnerability, refer to the Cisco Security Advisory available at the following link:  http://tools.cisco.com/security/center/content/CiscoSecurityAdvisory/cisco-sa-20140409-heartbleed   Cisco has released free software updates that address these vulnerabilities. Title: Nexpose Scanner Reported: Click Jacking issue on PI 22 M45 Build
RNE: Symptoms  Several Pages on the Cisco Prime Network Control System(NCS) do not properly restrict X-Frames, which may result in a ''click jacking'' vulnerability. This is identified by scanners such as Nexpose.  Conditions: The following urls are reported with ''X-Frame option is not available''  1.	https://10.126.168.93/  2.	https://10.126.168.93/index.jsp  3.	https://10.126.168.93/tomcat.css  4.	https://10.126.168.93/webacs/pages/common/updateQuickView.jsp  5.	https://10.126.168.93:8082/styles/login.css  6.	https://10.126.168.93:8082/login.jsp  Workaround:  This issue is already it is fixed via these two bugs in PI 22. CSCuj42444    Cross Frame Scripting CSCuo79961    Cross Frame Scripting - version 2 (XFSv2) on PI server llogin page  Further Problem Description:  Scanner is reported issue in the particular urls mentioned.  PSIRT Evaluation: The Cisco PSIRT has assigned this bug the following CVSS version 2 score. The Base and Temporal CVSS scores as of the time of evaluation are 4.3/3.7: http://tools.cisco.com/security/center/cvssCalculator.x?vector=AV:N/AC:M/Au:N/C:N/I:P/A:N/E:H/RL:OF/RC:C&version=2.0 No CVE ID has been assigned to this issue. Additional information on Cisco's security vulnerability policy can be found at the following URL: http://www.cisco.com/en/US/products/products_security_vulnerability_policy.html
Description: Build:PI 22 M45Description:Ran NExpose Scanner for M45 build & found this issue.CLICK JACKINGClickjacking, also known as a UI redress attack, is a method in which an attacker uses multiple transparent or opaque layers to trick a user into clicking a button or link on a page other than the one they believe they are clicking. Thus, the attacker is ;hijacking; clicks meant for one page and routing the user to an illegitimate page.Attached have the list of issues reported.Solution:Use HTTP X-Frame-OptionsSend the HTTP response headers with X-Frame-Options that instruct the browser to restrict framing where it is not allowed.

Title: BGP Processing Enhancements
RNE: Summary Cisco IOS Software contains a vulnerability in the Border Gateway Protocol (BGP) routing protocol feature.   The vulnerability can be triggered when the router receives a malformed attribute from a peer on an existing BGP session.  Successful exploitation of this vulnerability can cause all BGP sessions to reset.  Repeated exploitation may result in an inability to route packets to BGP neighbors during reconvergence times.  Cisco has released free software updates that address this vulnerability.  There are no workarounds for this vulnerability.  This advisory is available at the following link: http://tools.cisco.com/security/center/content/CiscoSecurityAdvisory/cisco-sa-20120926-bgp  Note: The September 26, 2012, Cisco IOS Software Security Advisory bundled publication includes 9 Cisco Security Advisories. Eight of the advisories address vulnerabilities in Cisco IOS Software, and one advisory addresses a vulnerability in Cisco Unified Communications Manager. Each Cisco IOS Software Security Advisory lists the Cisco IOS Software releases that correct the vulnerability or vulnerabilities detailed in the advisory as well as the Cisco IOS Software releases that correct all Cisco IOS Software vulnerabilities in the September 2012 bundled publication.  Individual publication links are in ''Cisco Event Response: Semi-Annual Cisco IOS Software Security Advisory Bundled Publication'' at the following link:  http://www.cisco.com/web/about/security/intelligence/Cisco_ERP_sep12.html PSIRT Evaluation: The Cisco PSIRT has assigned this bug the following CVSS version 2 score. The Base and Temporal CVSS scores as of the time of evaluation are 7.1/5.9: http://tools.cisco.com/security/center/cvssCalculator.x?vector=AV:N/AC:M/Au:N/C:N/I:N/A:C/E:F/RL:OF/RC:C&version=2.0 CVE ID CVE-2012-4617 has been assigned to document this issue. Additional information on Cisco's security vulnerability policy can be found at the following URL: http://www.cisco.com/en/US/products/products_security_vulnerability_policy.html
Description: BGP Malformed attribute #22This DDTS is used as Bulk ddts for all issues related with PMSI found on WBTProblem is Att#22, buffer overflow can corrupt memory or permit code injection.This is a very similar bug to CSCty58300 (Att #23) but with a different attribute (This bug is Att #22)

Title: Cisco Prime Infrastructure and Evolved Programmable Network Manager XML Injection Vulnerability
RNE: Symptom: A vulnerability in the web based user interface of Cisco Prime Infrastructure (PI) and Evolved Programmable  Network Manager (EPNM) could allow an authenticated, remote attacker to have have read and write access to information stored in the affected system as well as perform remote code execution.  The vulnerability is due to improper handling of XML External Entity (XXE) entries when parsing an XML file.  An attacker could exploit this vulnerability by convincing the administrator of an affected system to import a crafted XML file with malicious entries which could allow the attacker to read and write files and execute remote  code within the application.  Cisco has released software updates that address this vulnerability. There are no workarounds that address this vulnerability.    This advisory is available at the following link:  https://tools.cisco.com/security/center/content/CiscoSecurityAdvisory/cisco-sa-20170621-piepnm  Conditions: Please refer to the Security Advisory.  Workaround: Please refer to the Security Advisory.  Further Problem Description: Please refer to the Security Advisory.  PSIRT Evaluation:  Credit: Cisco would like to thank Pichaya Morimoto (discovery, analysis, coordination) from the SEC Consult Vulnerability Lab for responsibly reporting the identified  vulnerability.  The Cisco PSIRT has assigned this bug the following CVSS version 3 score. The Base CVSS score as of the time of evaluation is 8.8: https://tools.cisco.com/security/center/cvssCalculator.x?version=3.0&vector=CVSS:3.0/AV:N/AC:L/PR:L/UI:N/S:U/C:H/I:H/A:H/E:X/RL:X/RC:X  CVE ID CVE-2017-6662 has been assigned to document this issue.  Additional information on Cisco's security vulnerability policy can be found at the following URL: http://www.cisco.com/en/US/products/products_security_vulnerability_policy.html

Title: Sending crafted TCP packets can cause DOS because of AC Rule evaluation and session tracking
RNE: $$IGNORE-PSIRT  Symptoms: A vulnerability in the configuration of Access Control (AC) Policies on the Cisco Firepower System Software and Firepower Management Center (FMC) could allow an unauthenticated, remote attacker to cause a partial denial of service (DoS) condition due to the blocking of certain traffic flows.  The vulnerability is due to spoofed, ingress packets causing the affected device to blacklist certain traffic flows when set to use default system policies, impacting the device to properly return outbound traffic, where no specific Transmission Control Protocol (TCP) sequence exists. An attacker could exploit this vulnerability by sending maliciously crafted packets to a device which target known protocols and ports running on certain applications within an affected system. An exploit could allow the attacker to cause a partial impact to services running on the device.  Conditions: Please refer to the security advisory.  Workaround: Please refer to the security advisory.   Further Problem Description: Please refer to the security advisory.   PSIRT Evaluation: The Cisco PSIRT has assigned this bug the following CVSS version 3 score. The Base CVSS score as of the time of evaluation is 4: https://tools.cisco.com/security/center/cvssCalculator.x?version=3.0&vector=CVSS:3.0/AV:N/AC:H/PR:N/UI:N/S:C/C:N/I:N/A:L/E:X/RL:X/RC:X  CVE ID  has been assigned to document this issue.  Additional information on Cisco's security vulnerability policy can be found at the following URL: http://www.cisco.com/en/US/products/products_security_vulnerability_policy.html
Description: An attacker can craft packets to be sourced from whatever IP. If the Access Control policy blocks all inbound packets an attacker could completely shut down outbound communication to certain IPs based on this. For example, if I were to send 65535 packets such as: Source IP (domain of cisco.com, lets just say this is 1.1.1.1 for example's sake)Source Port 443Destination IP would be a client IP you want to block access to cisco.com, so just for example lets say this is 10.0.0.1.Destination port: 1-65535 If an attacker sent all of these packets at once snort would create a session for all of these where the initiator IP is 1.1.1.1 (cisco.com) and if this hit a block rule in the AC policy (which most firewalls run a block all default action for inbound traffic) then this would create 65535 sessions between these 2 IPS that would be blacklisted until they timed out, or the attacker could keep transmitting reset packets, essentially making the timeout unlimited, then 10.0.0.1 would never be able to open a TCP connection with 1.1.1.1 on port 443 because all of the 5 tuple sessions would be blacklisted.The intent of this bug is to address the issue where a teardown packet (eg FIN/RST) or a packet with no data causes a blacklist verdict and will block packets from the same session in both directions. These packets should not create a session and should only be dropped, not blacklisted. This will ensure a new session using the same 5-tuple will subsequently be allowed.Steps to reproduce:1)	Configure an inline set on FTD with an any any allow AC rule, with an IPS policy associated with the rule.2)	Configure the following Snort rule in the above IPS policy:        drop tcp any any <> any any ( sid:10000002; flags:*F; )3)	Send a FIN packet, observe that it gets dropped and blacklisted by the above rule4)	Send a SYN packet with the same 5-tuple as the FIN packetActual results: SYN packet is droppedExpected results: SYN packet is not dropped
PSIRT: PSIRT-owner: psirt@cisco.com           This issue has been evaluated and driven to closure by PSIRT.  PSIRT has provided a public Release-note Enclosure (RNE) for this issue which is visible on Cisco.com. Title: ESMTP Inspection Bypass via STARTTLS
RNE: Symptoms: If ESMTP inspection is enabled, the ASA will prevent invalid ESMTP commands from being sent from the client to the server. However, if a non-standard email message is sent, the ASA will not correctly recognize some of the patterns.  Conditions: ASA configured with ESMTP inspection.  Workaround: None, other than disabling ESMTP inspection.  PSIRT Evaluation: The Cisco PSIRT has assigned this bug the following CVSS version 2 score. The Base and Temporal CVSS scores as of the time of evaluation are 4.3/4.1: http://tools.cisco.com/security/center/cvssCalculator.x?vector=AV:N/AC:M/Au:N/C:P/I:N/A:N/E:F/RL:U/RC:C&version=2.0 No CVE ID has been assigned to this issue. Additional information on Cisco's security vulnerability policy can be found at the following URL: http://www.cisco.com/en/US/products/products_security_vulnerability_policy.html
Description: If ESMTP inspection is enabled, the ASA will prevent invalid ESMTP commands from being sent from the client to the server. After a client issues a STARTTLS verb and the server has responded with a 220, the ASA does not filter data for the rest of the connection (since it will be encrypted).However, if a client sends a STARTTLS command before the server has sent its initial 220 greeting, the ASA will incorrectly recognize this as a legitimate exchange and stop filtering the conversation even though no data is being encrypted. This allows subsequent verbs to to sent without being sanitized.This works regardless of the allow-tls configuration on the ASA. An example conversation shown below.C: starttls badparamS: 220 server greeting not maskedS: 502 5.5.2 Error: command not recognized <-- From the filtered/bad starttls commandC: BADCOMMAND <--- Not filteredS: 502 5.5.2 Error: command not recognizedC: BADCOMMAND2 <--- Not filteredS: 502 5.5.2 Error: command not recognized
PSIRT: PSIRT-owner: psirt@cisco.com           This issue has been evaluated and driven to closure by PSIRT. Title: Cisco MDS vulnerability to Aug 2015 ARP DOS attack
RNE: Symptom: A vulnerability in the Address Resolution Protocol (ARP) input packet  processing of the Cisco Nexus Operating System (NX-OS) devices unauthenticated, adjacent attacker to cause a denial of service (DoS)  condition.  The vulnerability is due to improper input validation of the ARP packet and  the Maximum Transmission Unit (MTU) size which results in a buffer overflow  which can cause the DoS condition. An attacker could exploit this vulnerability  by sending a crafted ARP packet to the device. An exploit could allow the attacker  to cause the device to be unavailable due to a DoS condition of the ARP module.  CVE ID CVE-2015-4323 has been assigned to document this issue.  Conditions: Device running with default configuration running an affected version of software.  Workaround: The MTU size should be configured lower.  Further Problem Description: None.  PSIRT Evaluation: The Cisco PSIRT has assigned this bug the following CVSS version 2 score. The Base and Temporal CVSS scores as of the time of evaluation are 6.1/5.8:    http://tools.cisco.com/security/center/cvssCalculator.x?vector=AV:A/AC:L/Au:N/C:N/I:N/A:C/E:F/RL:U/RC:C&version=2.0  Additional information on Cisco's security vulnerability policy can be found at the following URL:    http://www.cisco.com/en/US/products/products_security_vulnerability_policy.html
Description: Please determine if N3K CSCuu78074 crash vulnerability fix is need for MDSTrigger : Send ARP reply destined to switch with MTU size 9100

Title: GHOST vulnerability on glibc (CVE-2015-0235)
RNE: Symptom: On January 27, 2015, a buffer overflow vulnerability in the GNU C library (glibc) was publicly announced. This vulnerability is related to the various gethostbyname functions included in glibc and affect applications that call these functions. This vulnerability may allow an attacker to obtain sensitive information from an exploited system or, in some instances, perform remote code execution with the privileges of the application being exploited. This vulnerability is documented in CVE-2015-0235.  Cisco has analyzed this vulnerability and concluded that the previously listed products are not impacted.   Conditions: Not applicable  Workaround: Not applicable  Further Problem Description: While the vulnerable functions are present, analysis has demonstrated that there are no ways to trigger the problematic sections remotely.  Additional details about those vulnerabilities can be found at http://cve.mitre.org/cve/cve.html  PSIRT Evaluation: The Cisco PSIRT has evaluated those issues and they do not meet the criteria for PSIRT ownership or involvement. Those issues will be addressed via normal resolution channels.  If you believe that there is new information that would cause a change in the severity of those issues, please contact psirt@cisco.com for another evaluation.  Additional information on Cisco's security vulnerability policy can be found at the following URL:  http://www.cisco.com/web/about/security/psirt/security_vulnerability_policy.html

Title: Key Reinstallation attacks against WPA protocol
RNE: Symptom: The following Cisco products:  * Cisco Aironet Access Points running Cisco IOS Software (this includes both stand-alone hardware and wireless APs embedded on routers) * Cisco ASA 5506W-X w/ FirePOWER Services (embedded Cisco wireless AP 702)  implement a WPA authenticator and as such are affected by the WPA protocol vulnerabilities identified by the following Common Vulnerability and Exposures (CVE) ID:  CVE-2017-13082: accepting a retransmitted FT Reassociation Request and reinstalling the pairwise key while processing it  As disclosed in https://tools.cisco.com/security/center/content/CiscoSecurityAdvisory/cisco-sa-20171016-wpa  Those products are not affected by the following Common Vulnerability and Exposures (CVE) IDs:  CVE-2017-13077: reinstallation of the pairwise key in the 4-way handshake CVE-2017-13078: reinstallation of the group key in the 4-way handshake CVE-2017-13079: reinstallation of the integrity group key in the 4-way handshake CVE-2017-13080: reinstallation of the group key in the group key handshake CVE-2017-13081: reinstallation of the integrity group key in the group key handshake CVE-2017-13086: reinstallation of the Tunneled Direct-Link Setup (TDLS) PeerKey (TPK) key in the TDLS handshake CVE-2017-13087: reinstallation of the group key (GTK) when processing a Wireless Network Management (WNM) Sleep Mode Response frame CVE-2017-13088: reinstallation of the integrity group key (IGTK) when processing a Wireless Network Management (WNM) Sleep Mode Response frame  Conditions: Exposure to CVE-2017-13082 is only possible  if 802.11r(ft) is  use (Enabled or in Adaptive mode)  Workaround: If no interactive applications such as Voice over IP (VoIP) or video are being used on the network, you can disable 11r support on the access point.  If VoIP applications are in use but the supplicants support CCKM (for example, Cisco Wireless Phones) - you can disable 11r support and reconfigure the clients to use CCKM (Cisco Centralized Key Management), which should provide a similar roaming experience.  NOTE: Disabling 11r support may have negative performance and availability impact on the network. Customers should verify that disabling 11r would not negatively impact their environment before performing such configuration change on their infrastructure devices.  Further Problem Description: Cisco wireless APs models 1570, 1700, 2700 and 3700 are NOT vulnerable for 5Ghz connections, but are vulnerable on 2.4Ghz connections.  All other wireless APs are vulnerable on both 2.4Ghz and 5Ghz connections.  PSIRT Evaluation: The Cisco PSIRT has assigned this bug the following CVSS version 3 score. The Base CVSS score as of the time of evaluation is 4.3:  https://tools.cisco.com/security/center/cvssCalculator.x?version=3&vector=CVSS:3.0/AV:A/AC:L/PR:N/UI:N/S:U/C:N/I:L/A:N  Additional information on Cisco's security vulnerability policy can be found at the following URL: http://www.cisco.com/en/US/products/products_security_vulnerability_policy.html  Affected Releases Support for FT was added in 7.2, all releases after that are affected if FT is enabled Releases 7.0 and lower are not affected 8.5.103.0 8.4 all releases 8.3.100.0 to 8.3.131.0 for all AP types 8.2 up to 8.2.160.0  8.1 all releases 8.0 up to 8.0.150.0 7.2 to 7.6  all releases  Resolved Releases 8.0.152.0 8.2.164.0 and higher 8.3.132.0 and higher. It is recommended to use 8.3.133.0 8.3.130.6 (escalation) 8.5.105.0 and higher  (additional releases will be included here as they are made available)
Description: Additional fix for  IV error, proper correction for all scenarios. The fix was initially attempted via CSCvf47808 however it was later discovered that that fix was not effective in some scenarios.

Title: Client traffic to local resources go through when the client is in WebAuth reqd state
RNE: $$IGNORE-PSIRT  Symptoms: A vulnerability in Web Authentication (WebAuth) clients for the Cisco Wireless LAN  Controller (WLC) could allow an unauthenticated, adjacent attacker to bypass authentication  and pass traffic.  The vulnerability is due to incorrect implementation of authentication for WebAuth clients  in a specific configuration. An attacker could exploit this vulnerability by sending traffic  to local network resources without having gone through authentication. An exploit could allow the attacker to bypass authentication and pass traffic.  Conditions: This vulnerability exists in all software versions prior to the first fixed for the following specific WLC configuration only.  1. The Access Point (AP) is configured in FlexConnect Mode with NAT. 2. The WLAN is configured for central switching meaning the client is being assigned    a unique IP address. 3. The AP is configured with a Split Tunnel ACL for access local network resources. This means    that the AP is doing the NAT on the connection. 4. The client is using WebAuth.  This vulnerability does not apply to Dot1x clients in the same configuration.  Workaround: None.  Further Problem Description: None.  PSIRT Evaluation: The Cisco PSIRT has assigned this bug the following CVSS version 3 score. The Base CVSS score as of the time of evaluation is 3.4: https://tools.cisco.com/security/center/cvssCalculator.x?version=3.0&vector=CVSS:3.0/AV:A/AC:H/PR:N/UI:N/S:C/C:N/I:L/A:N/E:X/RL:X/RC:X  No CVE ID has been assigned to this issue.  Additional information on Cisco's security vulnerability policy can be found at the following URL: http://www.cisco.com/en/US/products/products_security_vulnerability_policy.html
Description: Topology:               AP---AP Switch(Local DHCP server)---Router(NAT)---WLC---Central DHCP server                           |                 Local ResourcesImage: 8.3.104.105 Platform: 8540.a)	AP in FlexConnect Mode behind NATb)	WLAN is Central switching(client acquiring Unique IP address)c)	AP is enabled with Split Tunnel ACL for accessing local resources(AP does the NATing here)d)	Dot1x clients, we don't see any issuese)	WebAuth clients, we see issue in traffic to local resources once the WebAuth timers expire. Client can pass traffic to local resources when in WebAuth reqd state.
PSIRT: PSIRT-owner: poxman@cisco.com  The PSIRT will not publish a Security Advisory for this issue, and the Release Note Enclosure, visible by customers via the Bug Toolkit on cisco.com will server as the customer notification vehicle to disclose this problem.  Last updated by elparis on Mon Mar 27 22:25:37 EST 2006.

Title: ASA crashes in DHCPV6 Relay agent feature Functionality
RNE: Symptom: A vulnerability in the DHCPv6 relay feature of Cisco Adaptive Security Appliance (ASA) software could allow an unauthenticated, remote attacker to cause an affected device to reload.  The vulnerability is due to insufficient validation of DHCPv6 packets. Cisco ASA Software is affected by this vulnerability only if the software is configured with the DHCPv6 relay feature. An attacker could exploit this vulnerability by sending crafted DHCPv6 packets to an affected device.   Note: Only DHCPv6 packets directed to the Cisco ASA interface where the DHCPv6 relay is enabled can be used to trigger this vulnerability. This vulnerability affects systems configured in routed or transparent firewall mode and in single or multiple context mode. This vulnerability can be triggered only by IPv6 traffic.   Cisco has released software updates that address this vulnerability. Workarounds that mitigate this vulnerability are not available. This advisory is available at the following link: http://tools.cisco.com/security/center/content/CiscoSecurityAdvisory/cisco-sa-20150115-asa-dhcp  Conditions: See Security Advisory  Workaround:  Further Problem Description: PSIRT Evaluation: The Cisco PSIRT has assigned this bug the following CVSS version 2 score. The Base and Temporal CVSS scores as of the time of evaluation are 7.1/6.4: http://tools.cisco.com/security/center/cvssCalculator.x?vector=AV:N/AC:L/Au:N/C:N/I:N/A:C/E:F/RL:OF/RC:C&version=2.0 CVE ID CVE-2015-6324 has been assigned to document this issue. Additional information on Cisco's security vulnerability policy can be found at the following URL: http://www.cisco.com/en/US/products/products_security_vulnerability_policy.html

Title: N5k/N6k need PTP DoS protection mechanism
RNE: $$IGNORE-PSIRT  Symptoms: A vulnerability in certain input and validation checking mechanisms in Cisco Nexus 5000 and 6000 Series Switch Software could allow an unauthenticated, remote attacker to cause a denial of service (DoS) condition to an affected device.  The vulnerability is due to a lack of proper flow-control mechanisms for Precision Time Protocol (PTP) frames. An attacker could exploit this vulnerability by sending a stream of crafted PTP traffic to the targeted device. An exploit could allow the attacker to cause a DoS condition, impacting the traffic passing through the device.   Conditions: Device configured with default configuration. running an affected version of software.  Workaround: None.  Further Problem Description: Please refer to the Security Advisory: (LINK)  PSIRT Evaluation: The Cisco PSIRT has assigned this bug the following CVSS version 3 score. The Base CVSS score as of the time of evaluation is 8.6: https://tools.cisco.com/security/center/cvssCalculator.x?version=3.0&vector=CVSS:3.0/AV:N/AC:L/PR:N/UI:N/S:C/C:N/I:N/A:H/E:X/RL:X/RC:X  CVE ID  has been assigned to document this issue.  Additional information on Cisco's security vulnerability policy can be found at the following URL: http://www.cisco.com/en/US/products/products_security_vulnerability_policy.html

Title: Cisco Networking Services Sensitive Information Disclosure Vulnerability
RNE: Symptom: A vulnerability in the debug logging function of Cisco Networking Services (CNS) used for the  configuring of Cisco IOS networking devices could allow an authenticated, local attacker to disclose sensitive data.  The vulnerability is due to insufficient protections of sensitive data at rest. An attacker could exploit  this vulnerability by accessing a specific file and reading the sensitive information.  Conditions: Exposure is not configuration dependent.  Workaround: The command ''debug cns ...'' should not be issued on the CNS CLI.  Further Problem Description: None.  PSIRT Evaluation: The Cisco PSIRT has assigned this bug the following CVSS version 2 score. The Base and Temporal CVSS scores as of the time of evaluation are 4/3.8: http://tools.cisco.com/security/center/cvssCalculator.x?vector=AV:N/AC:L/Au:S/C:P/I:N/A:N/E:F/RL:U/RC:C&version=2.0 CVE ID CVE-2015-6375 has been assigned to document this issue. Additional information on Cisco's security vulnerability policy can be found at the following URL: http://www.cisco.com/en/US/products/products_security_vulnerability_policy.html
Description: CNS debug output shows AAA login password in clear textConfigured the AAA authentication/Authorization for wireless (WebUI) login page and enabled the 'debug cns all'. Trying to connect to webUI using browser & enter valid user name and password. The device debugs shows the AAA login password in clear text.Steps to recreate:     1. Configure the device to use AAA for authentication and authorization for http using method list.          aaa new-model          aaa authentication login Admin_Access group ACS_GR           aaa authorization exec Admin_Access group ACS_GR           aaa group server tacacs+ ACS_GR          server name ACS          tacacs server ACS           address ipv4 10.64.68.110             key cisco123          exit          ip http server          ip http authentication aaa login-authentication Admin_Access          ip http authentication aaa exec-authorization Admin_Access          ip http authentication aaa       2. Ensure the AAA has the valid user name and password configured for authenticating the request       3. Enable the below debugs                 debug cns all                           4. Login to the webUI using the browser [E.g http://<deviceIP>/Observed behavior===========          Shows the AAA user name and password in clear text. Example from CCO image<wsse:Security xmlns:wsse=;http://schemas.xmlsoap.org/ws/2002/04/secext;>     <wsse:UsernameToken SOAP:mustUnderstand=;false;>       <wsse:Username>j</wsse:Username>       <wsse:Password>jjjjj</wsse:Password>     </wsse:UsernameToken>   </wsse:Security>Expected behavior:===========           Password should not be exposed in clear text. Should be replaced with *****Image Used for Test: ct5760-ipservicesk9.SPA.03.06.03.E.152-2.E3.binPlatform : KatanaNote: Please refer the enclosure for the complete logs.

Description: There are a few new CVEs for the apache version that the WAE is running.CVE-2017-3167In Apache httpd 2.2.x before 2.2.33 and 2.4.x before 2.4.26, use of the ap_get_basic_auth_pw() by third-party modules outside of the authentication phase may lead to authentication requirements being bypassed.CVE-2017-3169In Apache httpd 2.2.x before 2.2.33 and 2.4.x before 2.4.26, mod_ssl may dereference a NULL pointer when third-party modules call ap_hook_process_connection() during an HTTP request to an HTTPS port.CVE-2017-7679In Apache httpd 2.2.x before 2.2.33 and 2.4.x before 2.4.26, mod_mime can read one byte past the end of a buffer when sending a malicious Content-Type response header.In Apache httpd before 2.2.34 and 2.4.x before 2.4.27, the value placeholder in [Proxy-]Authorization headers of type 'Digest' was not initialized or reset before or between successive key=value assignments by mod_auth_digest.

Description: https://psirt.cisco.com/PSIRThot/CVE-2015-0235Please note that not all versions of glibc are affected. According to a Qualys blog post (and quoting): The first vulnerable version of the GNU C Library affected by this is glibc-2.2, released on November 10, 2000. We identified a number of factors that mitigate the impact of this bug. In particular, we discovered that it was fixed on May 21, 2013 (between the releases of glibc-2.17 and glibc-2.18).It is also relevant to note that products using an affected glibc release and using the gethostbyname*() set of functions are affected based on specific conditions on which they invoke those functions. RNE: $$IGNORE  Symptom: Cisco Common Services Platform Collector includes a version of the Diffie-Hellman cipher suite that is affected by the vulnerabilities identified by the following Common  Vulnerability and Exposures (CVE) IDs:   CVE-2015-4000  This bug was opened to address the potential impact on this product.  Conditions: Device with default configuration.  Workaround: Not currently available.  Further Problem Description: Additional details about the vulnerabilities listed above can be found at http://cve.mitre.org/cve/cve.html. Additional information on Cisco's security vulnerability policy can be found at the following URL: http://www.cisco.com/en/US/products/products_security_vulnerability_policy.html
Description: Diffie-Hellman key exchange is a popular cryptographic algorithm that allows Internet protocols to agree on a shared key and negotiate a secure connection. It is fundamental to many protocols including HTTPS, SSH, IPsec, SMTPS, and protocols that rely on TLS.Logjam researchers have uncovered several weaknesses in how Diffie-Hellman key exchange has been deployed. CVE ID CVE-2015-4000 has been assigned to the vulnerability in the TLS protocol

Title: Specific SNMP GET request causes 'pfm' service to crash on Nexus 5K
RNE: Symptoms: Cisco Nexus 5000 devices contain a denial of service vulnerability within the SNMP subsystem.  This vulnerability could allow an authenticated,  remote attacker to crash the device by submitting a malformed SNMP request to a specific MIB.  Conditions: Cisco Nexus 5000 devices running an affected version of Cisco NX-OS Software.  Workaround: None.  Further Problem Description: PSIRT Evaluation: The Cisco PSIRT has assigned this bug the following CVSS version 2 score. The Base and Temporal CVSS scores as of the time of evaluation are  6.8/6.5: http://tools.cisco.com/security/center/cvssCalculator.x?vector=AV:N/AC:L/Au:S/C:N/I:N/A:C/E:F/RL:U/RC:C&version=2.0  CVE ID CVE-2012-4124 has been assigned to document this issue.  Additional information on Cisco's security vulnerability policy can be found at the following URL: http://www.cisco.com/en/US/products/products_security_vulnerability_policy.html
Description: Executing an SNMP get request for an object in the cefcFanTrayStatusTable table in CISCO-ENTITY-FRU-CONTROL-MIB using a very large value for the table's entPhysicalIndex causes the pfm service to crash and the switch to reboot.snmpget -v1 -cpublic 10.1.15.100 .1.3.6.1.4.1.9.9.117.1.4.1.1.1.2147483648Stacktrace:#0  0x080f8bc3 in get_pfm_snmp_entity_fex ()#1  0x080f8fae in pfm_snmp_parse_fex_entity_index ()#2  0x08101f46 in pfm_snmp_get_fan_status ()#3  0x080da5ae in pfm_mts_get_snmp_fan_sts_mib_internal ()#4  0x080da68e in pfm_mts_get_snmp_fan_sts_mib ()#5  0x0809c5b5 in pfm_demux ()#6  0xb3f84ff4 in fu_fsm_engine_process_app_ev () from /isan/lib/libfsrv.so#7  0xb3fa649a in fu_fsm_engine () from /isan/lib/libfsrv.so#8  0x080ba282 in main ()

Title: Cisco TelePresence vTS  Server Serial Console Privileged Access
RNE: Symptoms: Cisco TelePresence Server on Virtual Machine contains an undocumented privileged account that can be accessed via serial console available through the vSphere controller.  The access via this account is protected by a password which is however default and static across all Cisco Virtual TelePresence Server deployment.  This account is present only on the Cisco Virtual TelePresence Server Software.  Cisco TelePresence Server Software for appliances is not affected. This issue is fixed in Cisco Virtual TelePresence Server Software version 4.1(1.85) where login access through this account as been removed.  Conditions: Administrative access to the vSphere is needed to use this account.  Workaround: The account password can be changed by contacting Cisco TAC.   Further Problem Description: An issue in the Cisco Virtual TelePresence Server Software could allow an authenticated, local attacker to access the shell of the underlying operating system with the privilege of the root user.  The issue is due to an undocumented privileged access through the serial connection which is available via the vSphere controller. An attacker could exploit this issue to obtain privileged access to the underlying operating system. The attacker would need to have administrative privilege on the vSphere controller. An exploit could allow the attacker to get access to the underlying operating system with the privileges of the root user. Cisco TelePresence Server Software for appliances is not affected by this issue. PSIRT Evaluation: The Cisco PSIRT has assigned this bug the following CVSS version 2 score. The Base and Temporal CVSS scores as of the time of evaluation are 6.8/5.6: http://tools.cisco.com/security/center/cvssCalculator.x?vector=AV:L/AC:L/Au:S/C:C/I:C/A:C/E:F/RL:OF/RC:C&version=2.0 CVE ID CVE-2015-0660 has been assigned to document this issue. Additional information on Cisco's security vulnerability policy can be found at the following URL: http://www.cisco.com/en/US/products/products_security_vulnerability_policy.html
Description: An administrator who has access to the vTS' serial console through vSphere can access the underlying operating system through a bash shell. While at the default console (one recommended for some configuration and logging tasks), pressing Alt-F2 will bring up a login prompt for a bash shell belonging to the underlying Linux operating system. Note that vSphere access also requires authentication.The root account is available. It is password-protected, but the password is the same for all versions (to date) on all vTS instances.This root login is not published in any documentation, customer-facing or otherwise.The only way to either change the root password or disable the shell login is to use the account - log in as root - and then use standard Linux commands (passwd, user mod etc) to do so.This vulnerability violates requirement SEC-CRE-NOBACK in the PSB. It only exists on vTS, and *not* on the following other TS platforms:-320 / 310-8710-7010
