Title: Cisco Unified Communications Manager Multiple CUPS Vulnerabilities
RNE: Symptom: Cisco Unified Communications Manager includes a version of CUPS that is affected by the vulnerabilities identified by the following Common Vulnerability and Exposures (CVE) IDs:  CVE-2015-1158,CVE-2015-1159,CVE-2014-9679    This bug was opened to address the potential impact on this product.  Conditions: Device running with default configuration running an affected version of software.  Workaround: None.  Further Problem Description: Additional details about the vulnerabilities listed above can be found at http://cve.mitre.org/cve/cve.html    PSIRT Evaluation: The Cisco PSIRT has assigned this bug the following CVSS version 2 score. The Base and Temporal CVSS scores as of the time of evaluation are 10/9.5: http://tools.cisco.com/security/center/cvssCalculator.x?vector=AV:N/AC:L/Au:N/C:C/I:C/A:C/E:F/RL:U/RC:C&version=2.0    CVE ID CVE-2015-1158,CVE-2015-1159,CVE-2014-9679 has been assigned to document this issue.    Additional information on Cisco's security vulnerability policy can be found at the following URL: http://www.cisco.com/en/US/products/products_security_vulnerability_policy.html
Description: A string reference count bug was found in cupsd, causing premature freeingof string objects. An attacker can submit a malicious print job thatexploits this flaw to dismantle ACLs protecting privileged operations,allowing a replacement configuration file to be uploaded which in turnallows the attacker to run arbitrary code in the CUPS server (CVE-2015-1158)A cross-site scripting flaw was found in the cups web templating engine. Anattacker could use this flaw to bypass the default configuration settingsthat bind the CUPS scheduler to the 'localhost' or loopback interface.(CVE-2015-1159)An integer overflow leading to a heap-based buffer overflow was found inthe way cups handled compressed raster image files. An attacker couldcreate a specially-crafted image file, which when passed via the cupsRaster filter, could cause the cups filter to crash. (CVE-2014-9679)Fixed version: cups-1.4.2-67.el6_6
PSIRT: PSIRT-owner: rosalaza           PSIRT is reviewing this issue for possible inclusion in a Cisco Security  Advisory which could include this DDTs.  Please do not change the  Release-note Enclosure, as PSIRT will modify it appropriately when this  issue is made public.          Should customers request information regarding this DDTs or appear to be running into this DDTs within their network, please bring it to the immediate attention of the Cisco PSIRT at psirt@cisco.com.

Title: Supervisor CPU consistently at 90%, system slow to respond
RNE: Symptom:  CPU usage of the active supervisor is consistently around 90%. The `show process cpu` CLI  command shows that the vrrp-eng process is the consumer:    switch#  show process cpu | include vrrp-eng   1675   2215685686  268836864  1565842753   94.3  vrrp-eng  Conditions:  This issue occurs when the active supervisor receives VRRP frames with IP Authentication Header  (AH) type authentication.  Workaround:  Use an ACL on mgmt0 interface to filter such frames in future, save the configuration change and  then either reload the active supervisor -or- perform a system switchover -or- perform a switch  reload.  Further Problem Description:  PSIRT Evaluation:  The Cisco PSIRT has assigned this bug the following CVSS version 2 score. The Base and Temporal CVSS scores as of the time of evaluation are : 5.0/4.1 http://tools.cisco.com/security/center/cvssCalculator.x?vector=AV:N/AC:L/Au:N/C:N/I:N/A:P/E:F/RL:OF/RC:C&version=2.0  CVE ID CVE-2013-5566 has been assigned to document this issue.  Additional details about the vulnerability described here can be found at: http://tools.cisco.com/security/center/content/CiscoSecurityNotice/CVE-2013-5566  Additional information on Cisco's security vulnerability policy can be found at the following URL: http://www.cisco.com/en/US/products/products_security_vulnerability_policy.html

Title: Evaluate MDS 9700 Linux kernel CVE-2011-3188 Vulnerability
RNE: Symptom: Cisco MDS 9700 Series Multilayer Switches includes a version of the Linux kernel that is affected by  the vulnerabilities identified by the following Common Vulnerability and Exposures (CVE) IDs:  CVE-2011-3188  This bug was opened to address the potential impact on this product.  Conditions: Default configuration  Workaround: There is no workaround  Further Problem Description: Additional details about the vulnerabilities listed above can be found at http://cve.mitre.org/cve/cve.html or https://nvd.nist.gov/vuln/detail/CVE-2011-3188.  PSIRT Evaluation: The Cisco PSIRT has assigned this bug the following CVSS version 2 score. The Base and Temporal CVSS scores as of the time of evaluation are 6.8/6.5:  http://tools.cisco.com/security/center/cvssCalculator.x?vector=AV:N/AC:M/Au:N/C:P/I:P/A:P/E:F/RL:U/RC:C&version=2.0  CVE ID CVE-2011-3188 has been assigned to document this issue.  Additional information on Cisco's security vulnerability policy can be found at the following URL: http://www.cisco.com/en/US/products/products_security_vulnerability_policy.html
Description: This bug is to evaluate Linux kernel CVE-2011-3188 for the MDS 9700 platform.Analysis from MDS Escalation:9700 running 6.2.19 is running Wind River 3.0 linux, kernel version is 2.6.27. I checked the sources for this linux build, which I presume are located in /auto/andfreetownone/REL_6_2_19/third-party/src/linux/kernel/wrl3/linux-2.6.27_wrl30, and after comparing them with diffs required to fix the vulnerability listed in https://cve.mitre.org/cgi-bin/cvename.cgi?name=CVE-2011-3188, it seems to me that this vuln is actually not fixed even on 9700.This bug is to decide if CVE-2011-3188 needs to be fixed on the 9700 and other non-legacy MDS platforms.===> ORIGINAL CSCue60408 2013 MDS bug which was closed for 9500EMC reports a customer scanned their MDS switch running NX-OS 5.2(2d) and reported it vulnerable to CVE-2011-3188 -  This bug is open for the development team to either (a) implement the required fixes on the kernel to fix CVE-2011-3188 (diffs are linked to from the MITRE page), or (b) document the issue as a false positive.

Title: Apache Mod_Rewrite - CVE-2006-3747
RNE: Symptom:  ACNS may be susceptible to CVE-2006-3747.   Conditions: CM GUI being used or RPC.  Workaround None  Further Problem Description: None
Description: THREAT:Apache's mod_rewrite is a rule-based rewriting engine which rewrites requested URLs for the Apache Web server.The mod_rewrite module is exposed to an off-by-one buffer-overflow condition. Specifically, this issue presents itself on a system with the active configuration ;RewriteEngine on;. However ;RewriteEngine on; is typically not enabled by default in Apache HTTPD implementations.IMPACT:A remote attacker can exploit certain rewrite rules to crash the HTTPD server and potentially cause arbitrary code execution.

Title: Evaluation of positron for struts2-jakarta rce vulnerability
RNE: Symptom: This product includes a version of Apache Struts2 that is affected by the vulnerability identified by one or  more of the following Common Vulnerability and Exposures (CVE) IDs:  CVE-2017-5638  And disclosed in https://tools.cisco.com/security/center/content/CiscoSecurityAdvisory/cisco-sa-20170310- struts2  This bug has been opened to address the potential impact on this product.  Cisco has confirmed that this product is impacted. Refer to the fixed version field for information about fixed  release  Conditions: Exposure is not configuration dependent. A hot patch for these releases will be provided by the 24th of  March. The hot patch will only work on the latest release for each train. The Base CVSS score as of  the time of evaluation is: 9.8  https://tools.cisco.com/security/center/cvssCalculator.x? version=3&vector=CVSS:3.0/AV:N/AC:L/PR:N/UI:N/S:U/C:H/I:H/A:H/E:U/RL:O/RC:U/CR:L/IR:L/AR:L/M AV:L/MAC:L/MPR:N/MUI:R/MS:U/MC:N/MI:N/MA:N
Description: PLEASE READ THIS ENTIRE DESCRIPTION AND THE INCLUDED LINKS BEFORE TAKING ANY ACTION.On March 6th, 2017, Apache released information about a possible remote code execution vulnerability on products using Apache Struts2 in combination with file upload based on Jakarta Multipart. The apache bulletin is available at: https://cwiki.apache.org/confluence/display/WW/S2-045This bug has been filed against the product Cisco Identity Services Engine (ISE) to address the vulnerability/ies known as - Struts2 Jakarta Multipart file upload remote code execution - and identified by CVE: CVE-2017-5638PLEASE EVALUATE YOUR PRODUCT BY COMPLETING THE STEPS AS INDICATED AT:https://psirt.cisco.com/PSIRThot/apache-struts2-march17/Instruction_to_EngineeringThis tool will guide you in the evaluation of these vulnerabilities and will automate the documentation of this bug appropriately.Additional information can be obtained in our hotpage at:https://psirt.cisco.com/PSIRThot/apache-struts2-march17VERY IMPORTANT NOTE ABOUT SEVERITY: The bugs have been raised as *issue_not_a_bug_or_enhancement (Sev7)*, but PLEASE TREAT IT AS A SEV 2 bug. Description: Customer ran a security scan against the Nexus 1000v and the below vulnerabilities were reported.CVE-2017-9789,CVE-2017-9788 - requires Apache of at least 2.2.34, 2.4.27A remote user may be able to trigger a memory access error in 'mod_http2.c' in the closing of multiple HTTP/2 connections to cause denial of service conditions. A remote user can send a specially crafted request to view potentially sensitive information from the previous request.

Title: Nexus5k : Network-operator role can view sensitive configuration
RNE: Symptom:  Cisco Nexus devices contain an information disclosure issue that could allow an authenticated, local attacker to gain access to sensitive information.   The affected devices do not perform sufficient sanitization of configuration files when they are viewed by a user that has been assigned the Network- Operator role.  This could allow an attacker to gain access to the password hashes of locally configured users.    Conditions:  Cisco Nexus devices running an affected version of NXOS software.    Workaround:  Restrict access to trusted users only.    Further Problem Description:  None.  PSIRT Evaluation: The Cisco PSIRT has assigned this bug the following CVSS version 2 score. The Base and Temporal CVSS scores as of the time of evaluation are  4/3.3: http://tools.cisco.com/security/center/cvssCalculator.x?vector=AV:N/AC:L/Au:S/C:P/I:N/A:N/E:F/RL:OF/RC:C&version=2.0  CVE ID CVE-2012-4090 has been assigned to document this issue.  Additional details about the vulnerability described here can be found at: http://tools.cisco.com/security/center/content/CiscoSecurityNotice/CVE-2012-4090  Additional information on Cisco's security vulnerability policy can be found at the following URL: http://www.cisco.com/en/US/products/products_security_vulnerability_policy.html  http://www.cisco.com/en/US/products/products_security_vulnerability_policy.html
Description: Description : A user with network-operator role privileges is allowed to run several commands that can reveal sensitive information, such as password hashes and snmp community strings.The list of commands include:1. show running-config2. show file <filename>      # Depends on content of file, e.g. backup running-configPrivilege escalation is possible since the user can perform offline password cracking of the hashes.Recommend masking sensitive information, such as password hashes and snmp community strings from the network-operator users.Related Bug : CSCti09089Related Info : Nexus 5k :http://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/switches/datacenter/nexus5000/sw/configuration/guide/cli/CLIConfigurationGuide/sec_rbac.html#wp1234362Nexus 7k :http://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/switches/datacenter/sw/6_x/nx-os/security/configuration/guide/b_Cisco_Nexus_7000_NX-OS_Security_Configuration_Guide__Release_6-x/b_Cisco_Nexus_7000_NX-OS_Security_Configuration_Guide__Release_6-x_chapter_01010.html#con_1395000Defect created to reduce privileges of network-operator and vdc-operator roles and not allow these roles to run the show running-config and show startup-config commands.

Title: Key Reinstallation attacks against WPA protocol
RNE: Symptom: The product Cisco Wireless IP Phone 8821 implements a WPA supplicant and as such is affected by the WPA protocol vulnerabilities identified by the following Common Vulnerability and Exposures (CVE) ID:  CVE-2017-13077: reinstallation of the pairwise key in the 4-way handshake CVE-2017-13078: reinstallation of the group key in the 4-way handshake CVE-2017-13079: reinstallation of the integrity group key in the 4-way handshake CVE-2017-13080: reinstallation of the group key in the group key handshake CVE-2017-13081: reinstallation of the integrity group key in the group key handshake  As disclosed in https://tools.cisco.com/security/center/content/CiscoSecurityAdvisory/cisco-sa-20171016-wpa  This product is not affected by the following Common Vulnerability and Exposures (CVE) IDs:  CVE-2017-13082: accepting a retransmitted FT Reassociation Request and reinstalling the pairwise key while processing it CVE-2017-13086: reinstallation of the Tunneled Direct-Link Setup (TDLS) PeerKey (TPK) key in the TDLS handshake CVE-2017-13087: reinstallation of the group key (GTK) when processing a Wireless Network Management (WNM) Sleep Mode Response frame CVE-2017-13088: reinstallation of the integrity group key (IGTK) when processing a Wireless Network Management (WNM) Sleep Mode Response frame   Conditions: Exposure is not configuration dependent.  Workaround: Not available.  Further Problem Description: PSIRT Evaluation: The Cisco PSIRT has assigned this bug the following CVSS version 3 score. The Base CVSS score as of the time of evaluation is 4.3:  https://tools.cisco.com/security/center/cvssCalculator.x?version=3&vector=CVSS:3.0/AV:A/AC:L/PR:N/UI:N/S:U/C:N/I:L/A:N  Additional information on Cisco's security vulnerability policy can be found at the following URL: http://www.cisco.com/en/US/products/products_security_vulnerability_policy.html
Description: Three new vulnerabilities have been identified on the WPA protocol (WPA1 or WPA2) that allow for key re-installation. Two of those vulnerabilities affect wireless devices acting as supplicant/client, while the remaining one affects wireless devices acting as authenticator/server.These vulnerabilities allow (depending on specific device configuration) for packet replaying, packet decryption, and *may allow* for packet forging/packet injection.As these are *protocol* level vulnerabilities (instead of vulnerabilities on a specific implementation of the protocol), there is a high likelihood that any wireless product implementing WPA1 or WPA2, as either supplicant or authenticator, will be affected.The Cisco PSIRT has a draft paper with details on the vulnerabilities, and tools that can be used to help reproduce the vulnerabilities on clients or servers. Due to the sensitive nature of this information, they're NOT attached to the bug but will be provided on an as-needed basis to developers involved on analyzing and fixing this vulnerability on any affected product.This bug has been opened for the development team to investigate the impact of these vulnerabilities against the following product(s): 8821

Title: OpenSSH vulnerability CVE-2012-0814: Debug messages with key info
RNE: Symptom: This bug was opened to address the potential impact on this product of the following vulnerabilities: CVE-2010-5107, CVE-2012-0814, CVE-2011-5000, CVE-2010-4755, CVE-2010-4478  CVE-2010-5107 is tracked by CSCul15845. CVE-2012-0814 is addressed by this bug.  The ASA does not use openssh, but exhibits the symptoms described in this vulnerability.  CVE-2011-5000, CVE-2010-4755, and CVE-2010-4478 do not affect the ASA. The ASA does not use J-PAKE, so it is not vulnerable to CVE-2010-4478  Conditions: CVE-2012-0814: Users with console, telnet, or ssh access, who can enable privileged command  Workaround: The impact of CVE-2012-0814 can be mitigated by limiting console, telnet, and ssh access to authorized users, and also restricting privileged commands to authorized users  Further Problem Description: Additional details about the vulnerabilities listed above can be found at http://cve.mitre.org/cve/cve.html  PSIRT Evaluation: The Cisco PSIRT has assigned this bug the following CVSS version 2 score. The Base and Temporal CVSS scores as of the time of evaluation are 5/4.3: http://tools.cisco.com/security/center/cvssCalculator.x?vector=AV:N/AC:L/Au:N/C:N/I:N/A:P/E:U/RL:U/RC:C&version=2.0 CVE ID CVE-2010-5107, CVE-2012-0814, CVE-2011-5000, CVE-2010-4755, CVE-2010-4478 has been assigned to document this issue. Additional information on Cisco's security vulnerability policy can be found at the following URL: http://www.cisco.com/en/US/products/products_security_vulnerability_policy.html
Description: This bug is to investigate, address and document the impact of the following OpenSSH vulnerabilities:CVE-2010-5107CVE-2012-0814CVE-2011-5000CVE-2010-4755CVE-2010-4478The ASA does not use J-PAKE, so it is not vulnerable to CVE-2010-4478. However, the others must be investigated and addressed, as needed. If the ASA is not affected by these vulnerabilities, please junk the bug and document appropriately.

Title: Cisco ASA-CX TCP Traffic Denial of Service Vulnerability
RNE: Symptoms: A vulnerability in TCP traffic processing on Cisco ASA-CX could allow an unauthenticated, remote attacker to cause a reload of the affected device.   The vulnerability is due to invalid parsing of TCP packet data forwarded to Cisco ASA-CX by the Cisco ASA. An attacker could exploit this vulnerability  by sending specific TCP traffic to be processed by the ASA-CX.   Conditions: Under very specific conditions that require ASA-CX to process traffic forwarded by Cisco ASA, certain TCP packets may cause a reload of the  affected module.   Workaround: None  PSIRT Evaluation: The Cisco PSIRT has assigned this bug the following CVSS version 2 score. The Base and Temporal CVSS scores as of the time of evaluation are  5.4/4: http://tools.cisco.com/security/center/cvssCalculator.x?vector=AV:N/AC:H/Au:N/C:N/I:N/A:C/E:U/RL:OF/RC:C&version=2.0 CVE ID CVE-2013-1203 has been assigned to document this issue.  Additional details about the vulnerability described here can be found at: http://tools.cisco.com/security/center/content/CiscoSecurityNotice/CVE-2013-1203  Additional information on Cisco's security vulnerability policy can be found at the following URL: http://www.cisco.com/en/US/products/products_security_vulnerability_policy.html

Title: IM&P XSS vulnerability
RNE: Symptoms: Cisco IM and Presence Server contains a reflected cross-site scripting (XSS) vulnerability that could allow an unauthenticated, remote attacker to preform an XSS attack on an authenticated user.  The vulnerability exists due to an incomplete user input filter; certain HTML or scripting tags may not be filtered out before use.  An attacker that can convince an authenticated administrator to follow a malicious link or visit an attacker  controlled website could cause arbitrary HTML or script content to be executed within the security context of the affected site on the users browser.  Conditions: Cisco IM and Presence server prior to versions 10.5 MR1 are affected.  Workaround: None.  Further Problem Description:  PSIRT Evaluation: The Cisco PSIRT has assigned this bug the following CVSS version 2 score. The Base and Temporal CVSS scores as of the time of evaluation are 4.3/3.6: http://tools.cisco.com/security/center/cvssCalculator.x?vector=AV:N/AC:M/Au:N/C:N/I:P/A:N/E:F/RL:OF/RC:C&version=2.0  CVE ID CVE-2015-4294 has been assigned to document this issue.  Additional information on Cisco's security vulnerability policy can be found at the following URL: http://www.cisco.com/en/US/products/products_security_vulnerability_policy.html
Description: Please see https://cibu-jira:8443/browse/IMPGUI-112.Customer (Citi) reported the following issue on 10.5H3 (for IM&P) XSS - Cross-site Scripting - URL Based (post-authentication)Description from report: Several products replicate the path component of a request which cannot be served (e.g. no such file). As a result, it is possible to form a malicious link, containing JavaScript code, that will send the site cookies to the attacker. Since the application does not implement input filtering/output escaping at all, the issue is general in the application. The example below is just a sample.Sample exploit: https://<IP_of_server>/cupadmin/topologyNodeView.do?element=vm-ubplab11-cipp00asdf%22%29%3b+confirm%28%27XSS%27%29%3b+//<https://%3cip_of_server%3e/cupadmin/topologyNodeView.do?element=vm-ubplab11-cipp00asdf%22%29%3b+confirm%28%27XSS%27%29%3b+//>[cid:image002.png@01D02439.2501B8B0]This is a Security Vulnerability report from CITI, one of our GET Customers, and we basically need assessment on whether it applies to us and when can this be fixed. If it is indeed an issue, I would think a CDET can be raised, with PSIRT tags.These are high visibility issues & need quick attention.If you have specific question about the details of the vulnerability, you can contact Clarence Nurse (cnurse). We are simply passing the information to you.
PSIRT: PSIRT-owner: chchapma           PSIRT is reviewing this issue for possible inclusion in a Cisco Security  Advisory which could include this DDTs.  Please do not change the  Release-note Enclosure, as PSIRT will modify it appropriately when this  issue is made public.          Should customers request information regarding this DDTs or appear to be running into this DDTs within their network, please bring it to the immediate attention of the Cisco PSIRT at psirt@cisco.com.

Title: ASAv : Evaluation of  CVE-2015-3456 Qemu (VENOM) Vulnerability

Title: [SAML] ASA needs to verify and confirm the polling client and responses returned from IdP
RNE: $$IGNORE-PSIRT  Symptoms: A vulnerability in the implementation for Security Assertion Markup Language (SAML) Single Sign-on  (SSO) authentication for Cisco AnyConnect Secure Mobility Client for Desktop Platforms and the  Adaptive Security Appliance could allow an unauthenticated, remote attacker to hijack an authenticated AnyConnect session through the ASA. The authentication was done by a unsuspecting third party.  The vulnerability exists because there is no mechanism to detect that Identity Provider (IdP) and AnyConnect SAML authenticate request are from the same device. An attacker could exploit  this vulnerabilityby persuading a user to click on a crafted link, which for example was sent via email, and authenticate using the company IdP. A successful exploit could allow the attacker to  hijack an authenticated AnyConnect session throug the ASA.  Conditions: The client is configured for AnyConnect SAML Single Sign-on (SSO) authentication.  Workaround: None.  Further Problem Description: Additional information about Session Fixation attacks and potential mitigations can be found at:  https://www.owasp.org/index.php/Session_fixation  PSIRT Evaluation: The Cisco PSIRT has assigned this bug the following CVSS version 3 score. The Base CVSS score as of the time of evaluation is 6.5: https://tools.cisco.com/security/center/cvssCalculator.x?version=3.0&vector=CVSS:3.0/AV:N/AC:L/PR:N/UI:R/S:U/C:H/I:N/A:N/E:X/RL:X/RC:X  CVE ID  has been assigned to document this issue.  Additional information on Cisco's security vulnerability policy can be found at the following URL: http://www.cisco.com/en/US/products/products_security_vulnerability_policy.html
Description: SYMPTOMS:CWE-384: Session FixationAn attacker is able to force a known session identifier on a user so that, once the user authenticates, the attacker has access to the authenticated session.CONDITIONS:The attacker initiates the AnyConnect SAML authentication.Once AnyConnect launches the web browser with the SAML login URL (which includes the pre-auth session ID hash), they extract it via the SSL proxy and send the link to a Corporate user, probably as part of a phishing attack to make her/him click on the link and potentially authenticate with the IDP (if forced re-authentication is enabled).ASA does not currently have any mechanism in place to detect that the IDP successful authentication notification and the periodic AnyConnect polls (to detect SAML authentication completion) originate from the same machine. Therefore, once the victim authenticates, the attacker has a valid AnyConnect authentication session created on the victim's behalf.

Title: Cisco ASA Webtype ACL By-Pass Vulnerability
RNE: Symptom: On ASA web type access-list''s do not honor case sensitivity and hence it does not allow us to configure two access-list entries as below:  access-list abcd webtype permit url http://cisco/TEST access-list abcd webtype permit url http://cisco/test INFO: Specified entry already exists in access-list ''abcd''  Conditions: ASA Software version 9.1(2)  Workaround: None  PSIRT Evaluation: The Cisco PSIRT has assigned this bug the following CVSS version 2 score. The Base and Temporal CVSS scores as of the time of evaluation are 3.5/3.3: http://tools.cisco.com/security/center/cvssCalculator.x?vector=AV:N/AC:M/Au:S/C:P/I:N/A:N/E:F/RL:U/RC:C&version=2.0 No CVE ID has been assigned to this issue. Additional information on Cisco's security vulnerability policy can be found at the following URL: http://www.cisco.com/en/US/products/products_security_vulnerability_policy.html  Further Problem Description:
Description: Current webtype ACL has following issues:1. RFC compliance: The current webtype ACL behavior is not compliant HTTP RFC for URL comparison. 2. Security issues: The current ASA code does not normalize URL?s while adding an ACE and also while making decision on filtering webvpn traffic. An attacker can encode URL?s and gain access to restricted resources in case of unintentional misconfiguration. Please refer EDCS-1307516 for more details.

Title: Deleted rules are referenced on Vulnerability Details page
RNE: $$IGNORE-PSIRT  CISCO HIGHLY CONFIDENTIAL - CONTROLLED ACCESS  This issue is under review by the Cisco Product Security Incident Response team (PSIRT).  The defect describes a product security vulnerability.  Its contents must be protected from unauthorized disclosure, both internal and external to Cisco.  Do not forward this information to mailing lists or newsgroups.  Documentation writers: it is prohibited to publish this Release-note  Enclosure (RNE) until the content has been approved by PSIRT.  PSIRT may  publish a Security Advisory regarding this defect, and the current text of  this RNE will be replaced with appropriate information.  In the event that  a Security Advisory is not published, PSIRT will replace this text with an  appropriate explanation.  More information on PSIRT is available at http//psirt.cisco.com/.   Cisco's public policy on security vulnerability handling can be reviewed at  http://www.cisco.com/en/US/products/products_security_vulnerability_policy.html. For further information, send a message to psirt@cisco.com.  (jklimarc-10/12/17)$$PREFCS  Symptom:  Conditions:  Workaround:  Further Problem Description:
Description: Build 6.2.2Problem Description:Some of the snort IDs (SIDs), which are listed on Vulnerabilities details page, are actually deleted as per rule_header table. If a rule is marked deleted in rule_header table then it should be removed from rna_reference table as well. The Vulnerability details page displays the data from rna_reference table.This was verified using the following two DB queries.select distinct reference_value from rna_reference where reference_type_id = 1select sid from rule_header where category != 'deleted.rules' and sid = $sidThe results found are as follows:Count1 from reference_value table is 19003Count2 14138 out of 19003 are present (or not deleted) in rule_header tableTotal 4865 rules missing!!Proposed Solution:During VDB or SRU installation, run a post upgrade script to verify if any of the rules are marked deleted. If any rules are marked deleted then remove those SIDs from rna_reference table.

Title: ACS Authorization Bypass
RNE: Symptom: A vulnerability in the Role Based Access Control component of Cisco Access Control Server (ACS) could allow an authenticated, remote attacker to exceed its authorization level. The vulnerability is due to improper privilege validation. An attacker could exploit this vulnerability by sending crafted HTTP request to the ACS server. An exploit could allow the attacker to do Create, Read, Update and Delete operations on any Network Identity Group with privileges limited to a Network Device Administrator.  Conditions: Cisco Secure ACS running release 5.5 without patch 7 or Cisco ACS running release 5.6 without patch 2.  Workaround: There is no workaround for this issue. This only affects system relying on the Network Device Administrator role.  Further Problem Description: None PSIRT Evaluation: The Cisco PSIRT has assigned this bug the following CVSS version 2 score. The Base and Temporal CVSS scores as of the time of evaluation are 6.5/5.4: http://tools.cisco.com/security/center/cvssCalculator.x?vector=AV:N/AC:L/Au:S/C:P/I:P/A:P/E:F/RL:OF/RC:C&version=2.0 CVE ID CVE-2014-8027 has been assigned to document this issue.  Additional details about the vulnerability described here can be found at: http://tools.cisco.com/security/center/content/CiscoSecurityNotice/CVE-2014-8027  Additional information on Cisco's security vulnerability policy can be found at the following URL: http://www.cisco.com/en/US/products/products_security_vulnerability_policy.html

Title: Cisco UCS Central Software Arbitrary File Download Vulnerability
RNE: Symptom: A vulnerability in the web framework of the Cisco UCS Central Software could allow an unauthenticated, remote attacker to download arbitrary files from a targeted device.  The vulnerability is due to improper input validation. An attacker could exploit this vulnerability by sending a crafted HTTP to the targeted device. An exploit could allow the attacker to retrieve sensitive information.  Conditions: Default configuration  Workaround: None  Further Problem Description: This issue was reported to the Cisco PSIRT by Gregory Draperi. We would like to thank Mr. Draperi for reporting this vulnerability to Cisco and working with us towards a coordinated disclosure. Title: Cisco AsyncOS Software for Cisco ESA Filtering Bypass Vulnerability
RNE: Symptom: A vulnerability in the Multipurpose Internet Mail Extensions (MIME) scanner of Cisco AsyncOS Software for Cisco Email Security Appliances (ESA) could allow an unauthenticated, remote attacker to bypass configured user filters on the device.  The vulnerability is due to improper error handling of a malformed MIME header in an email attachment. An attacker could exploit this vulnerability by sending an email with a crafted MIME attachment. For example, a successful exploit could allow the attacker to bypass user filters configured to prevent executable files from being opened. The malformed MIME headers may not be RFC compliant but some mail clients could still allow users to access the attachment, which may not have been properly filtered by the device.  Conditions: This vulnerability affects all releases prior to the first fixed release of Cisco AsyncOS Software for Cisco ESA, both virtual and hardware appliances, that are configured with message or content filters to scan incoming email attachments on the ESA.  Workaround: None.  Further Problem Description: PSIRT Evaluation:  Credit: Cisco would like to thank security researcher Martin Ervius, Handelsbanken SIRT for finding and reporting this vulnerability.  The Cisco PSIRT has assigned this bug the following CVSS version 3 score. The Base CVSS score as of the time of evaluation is 5.8: https://tools.cisco.com/security/center/cvssCalculator.x?version=3.0&vector=CVSS:3.0/AV:N/AC:L/PR:N/UI:N/S:C/C:L/I:N/A:N/E:X/RL:X/RC:X   CVE ID CVE-2017-3827 has been assigned to document this issue.  Additional information on Cisco's security vulnerability policy can be found at the following URL: http://www.cisco.com/en/US/products/products_security_vulnerability_policy.html
Description: Hi, We have discovered that it is possible to bypass attachment policies in the Cisco Ironport product (we are using version 10.0.0.-203). By having multiple Content-type's where one of them is multipart/mixed, Ironport lets mail through, apparently without noticing that an attachment is preset. Our mail client software shows the attachment in a mail received via Ironport. Since the attachment isn't identified as such, it never triggers the Ironport content rules in place (no windows executable policy) and it is therefore possible to deliver any type of file to the recipient this way. Having multiple content types is probably in violation of some MIME/SMTP RFC's so technically Ironport could be correct here by not identifying an attachment but we feel it should then be rejected or at least having the option to block this kind of message. We have tested with two separate mail clients and both display the attachment to the recipient. Here is the the first part of a mail conversation where the executable putty.exe is sent this way (the external Ironport here forwards it to internal servers): (See attachment for Big Description)

Title: CUCM evaluation for CVE-2014-6271, 2014-7169, 2014-6277 and 2014-6278
RNE: Symptom:  This notice only discusses versions which have not reached "End-of-Software-Maintenace". The Cisco Unified Communications Manager (UCM) versions 8, 9, and 10 includes a version of Bash that is affected by the vulnerabilities identified by the Common Vulnerability and Exposures (CVE) IDs:  CVE-2014-6271 CVE-2014-7169 CVE-2014-7186 CVE-2014-7187 CVE-2014-6277  CVE-2014-6278  This bug has been opened to address the potential impact on this product.   Conditions: Exposure is not configuration dependant. Authentication is NOT required to exploit this vulnerability  Workaround: Not available.  Further Problem Description: A COP file, ciscocm.bashupgrade.cop.sgn, has been published to cisco.com that can be used for all FCS releases, SU's or ES's of all Cisco Unified Communications Manager (UCM) versions that have not reached their End of SW Maintenance Releases Date as of Oct 2014.  These releases consist of:      8.5(1)      8.6(2)      9.1(2)      10.0(1)      10.5(1)   In addition to the above mentioned COP file, this fix will also be included in any future software releases that may occur for the listed versions.  The previous statement should not infer that Cisco is planning for any or making any commitments for any future CCO posted SU's for any of these versions.  Additionally, there are no plans to provide fixes or patches for any other version beyond those listed above.  The COP file addresses all bash vulnerabilities that have been reported to date. All other issues reported are NOT security vulnerabilities, but just operational problems.  PSIRT Evaluation: The Cisco PSIRT has assigned this bug the following CVSS version 2 score. The Base and Temporal CVSS scores as of the time of evaluation are  7.5/7.5:  http://tools.cisco.com/security/center/cvssCalculator.x?vector=AV:N/AC:L/Au:N/C:P/I:P/A:P/E:H/RL:U/RC:C&version=2.0  The Cisco PSIRT has assigned this score based on information obtained from multiple sources. This includes the CVSS score assigned by the third-party vendor when available. The CVSS score assigned may not reflect the actual impact on the Cisco Product.  Additional information on Cisco's security vulnerability policy can be found at the following URL:  http://www.cisco.com/web/about/security/psirt/security_vulnerability_policy.html
Description: This fix is now available in a standalone COP file published on CCO, plus in the following CUCM releases:     10.5(1)su1 plus 10.5(1)ES's starting with 10.5(1.11011.1) and higher     10.0(1)ES's starting with 10.0(1.13012.1) and higher     9.1(2)ES's starting with  9.1(2.13060.1) and higher     8.6(2)ES's starting with 8.6(2.26147.1) and higher     8.5(1)ES's starting with 8.5(1.17131.2) and higher PLEASE READ THIS ENTIRE DESCRIPTION AND THE INCLUDED LINKS BEFORE TAKING ANY ACTION.A serious vulnerability has been discovered in the Bash shell widely used in various Cisco products.Additional background information can be found on PSIRT's internal hot page at: https://psirt.cisco.com/PSIRThot/BashSep14 This defect has been created to evaluate the impact to this product.IMMEDIATE ACTION REQUIRED:==========================Please evaluate your product in the next 48 hours and file the DE-Evaluation enclosure per the instructions at:https://psirt.cisco.com/PSIRThot/BashSep14/InstructionsToEngineering

Title: Cisco ASR 5000 Series Denial of Service Vulnerability
RNE: Symptoms: A vulnerability in the Cisco ASR 5000 Series could allow an unauthenticated, adjacent attacker to cause a denial of service (DoS) condition.  The vulnerability is due to the receipt of malformed PCO packets. An attacker could exploit this vulnerability by submitting malformed PCO packets to the device. An exploit could allow the attacker to cause a DoS condition.  Conditions: Device running with default configuration running an affected version of software.  Workaround: None.  Further Problem Description: None.  PSIRT Evaluation: The Cisco PSIRT has assigned this bug the following CVSS version 2 score. The Base and Temporal CVSS scores as of the time of evaluation are 2.9/2.4: http://tools.cisco.com/security/center/cvssCalculator.x?vector=AV:A/AC:M/Au:N/C:N/I:N/A:P/E:F/RL:OF/RC:C&version=2.0 No CVE ID has been assigned to this issue. Title: VCS: XML External Entity Processing / Arbitrary File Read Vulnerability
RNE: Symptom: A vulnerability in the Call Policy Configuration page of the Cisco TelePresence Video Communication Server (VCS) Expressway could allow an authenticated, remote attacker to cause a denial of service (DoS) condition or read arbitrary files on an affected system.  The vulnerability is due to insufficient validation of declared document type definitions (DTD) stored externally. An attacker could exploit this vulnerability by supplying a specially crafted XML file to the targeted system. An exploit could allow the attacker to launch a denial of service or read arbitrary files.  Conditions: Exposure is not configuration dependent  Workaround: None.  Further Problem Description: None.  PSIRT Evaluation: The Cisco PSIRT has assigned this bug the following CVSS version 2 score. The Base and Temporal CVSS scores as of the time of evaluation are 5.5/5.2: http://tools.cisco.com/security/center/cvssCalculator.x?vector=AV:N/AC:L/Au:S/C:P/I:N/A:P/E:F/RL:U/RC:C&version=2.0 CVE ID CVE-2015-4315 has been assigned to document this issue. Additional information on Cisco's security vulnerability policy can be found at the following URL: http://www.cisco.com/en/US/products/products_security_vulnerability_policy.html
Description: Vuln. class: XML External Entity Processing / Arbitrary File ReadCriticality: HighExploitability: Requires authenticationDescription: Authenticated users which have permission to update the Call Policy configuration can supply a specially-crafted XML file which will can lead to entity expansion-style denial of service, or arbitrary file read on the server. As a proof-of-concept, I have created two files, a DTD which has been hosted on one of the Kali machines, and an XML file which triggers the vulnerability to return the contents of /etc/passwd when processed.

Description: CIAM flagged the version of openssl we use in IPICS OS as possibly being vulnerable to CVE-2014-8176:CIAM Alert Title: OpenSSL Datagram Transport Layer Security Invalid Free Memory Corruption VulnerabilityCIAM Alert ID: 39322CIAM CVSS: 7.8CIAM Suggested Severity: 1Note: This CDET will be opened under a lower severity and will be upgraded to the CIAM Suggested Severity after evaluation.http://cve.mitre.org/cgi-bin/cvename.cgi?name=CVE-2014-8176The dtls1_clear_queues function in ssl/d1_lib.c in OpenSSL before0.9.8za, 1.0.0 before 1.0.0m, and 1.0.1 before 1.0.1h frees datastructures without considering that application data can arrive betweena ChangeCipherSpec message and a Finished message, which allows remoteDTLS peers to cause a denial of service (memory corruption andapplication crash) or possibly have unspecified other impact viaunexpected application data.This vulnerability could possibly affect the following Cisco IPICS related products and versions:Cisco IPICS Server	4.10(1)	openssl	0.9.8e.31.el5_11Cisco IPICS Server	4.5(1)	openssl	0.9.8e.12.el5_4.6Cisco IPICS Server	4.7(1)	openssl	0.9.8e.12.el5_4.6Cisco IPICS Server	4.9(2)	openssl	0.9.8e.31.el5_11Cisco PTT Reporter	4.10(1)	openssl	0.9.8e.31.el5_11Cisco PTT Reporter	4.9(2)	openssl	0.9.8e.31.el5_11Cisco Universal Media Server (UMS)	4.10(1)	openssl	0.9.8e.31.el5_11Cisco Universal Media Server (UMS)	4.5(1)	openssl	0.9.8e.12.el5_4.6Cisco Universal Media Server (UMS)	4.9(2)	openssl	0.9.8e.31.el5_11Note: The IPICS OS used in the flagged products is based on RHEL 5.5 (32-bit).<REDHAT_RESPONSE>https://access.redhat.com/security/cve/CVE-2014-8176An invalid-free flaw was found in the way OpenSSL handled certainDTLS handshake messages. A malicious DTLS client or server couldsend a specially crafted message to the peer, which could cause theapplication to crash or potentially result in arbitrary codeex... Title: Edge Server Cert validation not checking Server Cert for a domain
RNE: Symptoms: A vulnerability in certificate validation trusting Fully Qualified Domain Names (FQDNs) within  Cisco Jabber could allow an unauthenticated, remote attacker to trick the application  into trusting a compromised certificate.  The vulnerability is due to how Cisco Jabber retrieves the FQDN contained within the Edge  Server certificate. An attacker could exploit this vulnerability by highjacking the FQDN  lookup by redirecting Cisco Jabber to a rouge Domain Name Server (DNS). An exploit could  allow the attacker to cause Cisco Jabber to trust the Edge Server Certificate because it  contains a trust FQDN which was actually provided by a malicious DNS device.  Conditions: The Cisco Jabber Edge Server is configured with a trusted certificate with a FQDN.  Workaround: None.  Further Problem Description: None.  PSIRT Evaluation: The Cisco PSIRT has assigned this bug the following CVSS version 2 score. The Base and Temporal CVSS scores as of the time of evaluation are 4.3/3.2: http://tools.cisco.com/security/center/cvssCalculator.x?vector=AV:N/AC:M/Au:N/C:N/I:P/A:N/E:U/RL:OF/RC:C&version=2.0 No CVE ID has been assigned to this issue. Additional information on Cisco's security vulnerability policy can be found at the following URL: http://www.cisco.com/en/US/products/products_security_vulnerability_policy.html
Description: Expected Result : ============When verifying the VCSe cert duing a call to get_edge_config, jabber Cert validation will check that1.	The Server Cert contains the FQDN of the edge server we are connecting to  AND2.	The Server Cert contains one of the following :          - The Edge domain         OR         - collab-edge.<edgeDomain>   for collab-edge.<edgeDomain> the prefix is fixed and is used for cases where CA will not issue a cert for just a domain as is too wide a scopeActual Result : ==============If Step 1 succeeds and Step 2 fails, then cert validation will incorrectly return success.Jabber will treat the cert as valid if it contains any one of the following :  - the FQDN - the edgeDomain - collab-edge.edgeDomain

Title: Cisco Unified Communications Manager Directory Traversal Vulnerability
RNE: Symptom: A vulnerability in the web framework of Cisco Unified Communications Manager could allow an authenticated, remote attacker to access arbitrary  files in the context of the web root directory structure on an affected device.  The vulnerability is due to insufficient input validation by the affected software. An attacker could exploit this vulnerability by using directory traversal  techniques to read files in the web root directory structure on the Cisco Unified Communications Manager filesystem.  There are no workarounds that address this vulnerability.  This advisory is available at the following link: https://tools.cisco.com/security/center/content/CiscoSecurityAdvisory/cisco-sa-20170802-ucm1   Conditions: Affects all known versions of CuCM.  Workaround: None.  Further Problem Description: Made public via https://tools.cisco.com/security/center/content/CiscoSecurityAdvisory/cisco-sa-20170802-ucm1  PSIRT Evaluation: The Cisco PSIRT has assigned this bug the following CVSS version 3 score. The Base CVSS score as of the time of evaluation is 4.3: https://tools.cisco.com/security/center/cvssCalculator.x?version=3.0&vector=CVSS:3.0/AV:N/AC:L/PR:L/UI:N/S:U/C:L/I:N/A:N/E:X/RL:X/RC:X  CVE ID CVE-2017-6758 has been assigned to document this issue.  Additional information on Cisco's security vulnerability policy can be found at the following URL: http://www.cisco.com/en/US/products/products_security_vulnerability_policy.html

Title: Cisco IOS and IOS XE Software EnergyWise Denial of Service Vulnerabilities
RNE: Symptoms: Multiple vulnerabilities in the EnergyWise module of Cisco IOS and Cisco IOS XE Software could allow an unauthenticated, remote attacker to cause a buffer overflow condition or a reload of an affected device, leading to a denial of service (DoS) condition.  These vulnerabilities are due to improper parsing of crafted EnergyWise packets destined to an affected device. An attacker could exploit these vulnerabilities by sending crafted EnergyWise packets to be processed by an affected device. An exploit could allow the attacker to cause a buffer overflow condition or a reload of the affected device, leading to a DoS condition.  Cisco has released software updates that address these vulnerabilities. There are no workarounds that address these vulnerabilities.  This advisory is available at the following link:  https://tools.cisco.com/security/center/content/CiscoSecurityAdvisory/cisco-sa-20170419-energywise  Conditions: See published Cisco Security Advisory  Workaround: See published Cisco Security Advisory  Further Problem Description:  PSIRT Evaluation: The Cisco PSIRT has assigned this bug the following CVSS version 3 score. The Base CVSS score as of the time of evaluation is 8.6: https://tools.cisco.com/security/center/cvssCalculator.x?version=3.0&vector=CVSS:3.0/AV:N/AC:L/PR:N/UI:N/S:C/C:N/I:N/A:H/E:X/RL:X/RC:X  CVE ID CVE-2017-3861 has been assigned to document this issue.  Additional information on Cisco's security vulnerability policy can be found at the following URL: http://www.cisco.com/en/US/products/products_security_vulnerability_policy.html

Title: Cisco Security Manager Cross-Site Request Forgery Vulnerability
RNE: Symptom: A vulnerability in the web framework of Cisco Security Manager (CSM) could allow an unauthenticated, remote attacker to perform a cross-site request forgery (CSRF) attack against the web interface.  The vulnerability is due to insufficient CSRF protections. An attacker could exploit this vulnerability by persuading an authenticated user of the affected system to follow a malicious link or visit an attacker-controlled website. A successful exploit could allow the attacker to make changes to CSM on behalf of the user.  Conditions: Device configured with default configuration.  Workaround: Not applicable or available.  Further Problem Description: PSIRT Evaluation: The Cisco PSIRT has assigned this bug the following CVSS version 2 score. The Base and Temporal CVSS scores as of the time of evaluation are 4.3/4.1: http://tools.cisco.com/security/center/cvssCalculator.x?vector=AV:N/AC:M/Au:N/C:N/I:P/A:N/E:F/RL:U/RC:C&version=2.0  CVE ID CVE-2014-3267 has been assigned to document this issue. Additional details about the vulnerability described here can be found at: http://tools.cisco.com/security/center/content/CiscoSecurityNotice/CVE-2014-3267  Additional information on Cisco's security vulnerability policy can be found at the following URL: http://www.cisco.com/en/US/products/products_security_vulnerability_policy.html
Description: Seen on CSM 4.5 and 4.6.0 releases (as on CCO)Confirmed following functions to be vuln to CSRF:1 Modify User Password policy2 Create a new user3 Create a new roleAll above use POST requests to perform respective functions. However, we can change these POST to GETs and perform the same action.CSRF can be exploited since there is no unique token used with any of these pages, nor any confirmation / message box for these functions.Attack steps will be:1. Title: Cisco Wireless LAN Controller (WLC) Ipv6 IAPP WIPS Report Vulnerability
RNE: Symptom: A vulnerability in the Internet Access Point Protocol (IAPP) module of the Cisco Wireless LAN Controller (WLC)  could allow an unauthenticated, remote attacker to cause network traffic to be forwarded to an unexpected  destination network. This traffic is leaked outside the specified Control and Provisioning of Wireless Access  Points Protocol (CAPWAP) Access Points (APs) configured. The interface is configured in IPv6 mode with  Wireless Intrusion Prevention System (wIPS) submode configured.  The vulnerability is due to improper input validation of the IPv6 packet. An attacker could exploit this vulnerability by sending crafted IPv6 packets to the WLC interface. An exploit could allow the attacker to send traffic to an unexpected destination on a remote sub-network.  Conditions: Device running with IPv6 configured interfaces with wIPS submode. WLC running 8.1. This issue does not affect releases 8.0 and older  Workaround: On the AP the features WIPS and Rogue Detection must be disabled.  Further Problem Description: None.  PSIRT Evaluation: The Cisco PSIRT has assigned this bug the following CVSS version 2 score. The Base and Temporal CVSS scores as of the time of evaluation are 5/4.8: http://tools.cisco.com/security/center/cvssCalculator.x?vector=AV:N/AC:L/Au:N/C:P/I:N/A:N/E:F/RL:U/RC:C&version=2.0 CVE ID CVE-2015-6258 has been assigned to document this issue. Additional information on Cisco's security vulnerability policy can be found at the following URL: http://www.cisco.com/en/US/products/products_security_vulnerability_policy.html
Description: AP in ipv6 mode leaking traffic outside capwap trds 32.x.x.x destinationFor AP operating in IPV6 mode, it will leak information outside capwap  (mostly IAPP info)The destination is a 32.x.x.x network, coming from malformed IPV6 parsing using IPv4 address

Title: Cisco IronPort ESA Subject header length DoS Vulnerability
RNE: Symptom: A vulnerability in Subject header length processing on Cisco IronPort ESA could allow an unauthenticated, remote attacker to cause a Denial of  Service (DoS) condition on an affected platform.  The vulnerability is due to a lack of limiting length of Subject Header that the user can generate and send in an email through IronPort ESA  appliance.. An attacker could exploit this vulnerability by sending a number of crafted messages across ESA appliance and observe high CPU  condition and DoS condition eventually.. An exploit could allow the attacker to cause a Denial of Service (DoS) condition on an affected platform  Conditions: Such message causes set of issues (if accepted by the ESA).  1. If such message gets quarantined, then it prevents admin user from normal management of this quarantine.  Each operation in quarantine (each request) is time consuming and takes a lot of resources at the client''s side(browser).  2. An attempt to open(view) such message in quarantine is very expensive operation, because ESA returns full subject and browser renders it on the page.  3. A number of such messages can cause ESA to constantly use 99% CPU. CLI be be unresponsive while these messages are in the workqueue, also ESA can''t accept other messages at this time.  Workaround: None  PSIRT Evaluation: The Cisco PSIRT has assigned this bug the following CVSS version 2 score. The Base and Temporal CVSS scores as of the time of evaluation are  5/4.8: http://tools.cisco.com/security/center/cvssCalculator.x?vector=AV:N/AC:L/Au:N/C:N/I:N/A:P/E:F/RL:U/RC:C&version=2.0 CVE ID CVE-2014-8016 has been assigned to document this issue.  Additional details about the vulnerability described here can be found at: http://tools.cisco.com/security/center/content/CiscoSecurityNotice/CVE-2014-8016  Additional information on Cisco's security vulnerability policy can be found at the following URL: http://www.cisco.com/en/US/products/products_security_vulnerability_policy.html  Further Problem Description:
Description: [CSCub25152] There is no limitation of the Subject header length, possible flaw for DoS attack === Problem ===  There is no limitation of the Subject header length.  (maybe this related not to Subject header only, but this bug is about Subject header)  According to rfc2822  2.1.1. Line Length Limits     There are two limits that this standard places on the number of    characters in a line. Each line of characters MUST be no more than    998 characters, and SHOULD be no more than 78 characters, excluding    the CRLF.   Please refer to rfc2822 2.1. General Description 2.1.1. Line Length Limits 2.2.3. Long Header Fields  By default max message size is ~20M (default mail flow policy for public listener).  A malicious user can construct and inject message with very long Subject header, actually all message size is in the 'Subject' header.  Tried injecting messages with   msg['Subject'] = ;;A;;*10000000 # ~10M msg['Subject'] = ;;A;;*15000000 # ~15M msg['Subject'] = ;;A;;*19000000 # ~19M msg['Subject'] = ;;A;;*90000000 # ~90M, in some cases ESA is configured to accept messages with 100M size  Such message causes set of issues (if accepted by the ESA).  1. If such message gets quarantined, then it prevents admin user from normal management of this quarantine.  This is because ESA sends full Subject to the client and only after that truncates Subject for better output.  Each operation in quarantine (each request) is time consuming and takes a lot of resources at the client's side(browser).  2. An attempt to open(view) such message in quarantine is very expensive operation, because ESA returns full subject and browser renders it on the page.  3. Bunch of such messages (10 messages with 9.5MB size) sent to ESA causes hermes to constantly use 99% CPU. CLI is totally unresponsive while these messages are in the workqueue, also ESA can't accept other messages at this time. Will tr

Title: Cisco IOS and IOS XE Software EnergyWise Denial of Service Vulnerabilities
RNE: Symptoms: Multiple vulnerabilities in the EnergyWise module of Cisco IOS and Cisco IOS XE Software could allow an unauthenticated, remote attacker to cause a buffer overflow condition or a reload of an affected device, leading to a denial of service (DoS) condition.  These vulnerabilities are due to improper parsing of crafted EnergyWise packets destined to an affected device. An attacker could exploit these vulnerabilities by sending crafted EnergyWise packets to be processed by an affected device. An exploit could allow the attacker to cause a buffer overflow condition or a reload of the affected device, leading to a DoS condition.  Cisco has released software updates that address these vulnerabilities. There are no workarounds that address these vulnerabilities.  This advisory is available at the following link:  https://tools.cisco.com/security/center/content/CiscoSecurityAdvisory/cisco-sa-20170419-energywise  Conditions: See published Cisco Security Advisory  Workaround: See published Cisco Security Advisory  Further Problem Description:  PSIRT Evaluation: The Cisco PSIRT has assigned this bug the following CVSS version 3 score. The Base CVSS score as of the time of evaluation is 8.6: https://tools.cisco.com/security/center/cvssCalculator.x?version=3.0&vector=CVSS:3.0/AV:N/AC:L/PR:N/UI:N/S:C/C:N/I:N/A:H/E:X/RL:X/RC:X  CVE ID CVE-2017-3860 has been assigned to document this issue.  Additional information on Cisco's security vulnerability policy can be found at the following URL: http://www.cisco.com/en/US/products/products_security_vulnerability_policy.html
Description: In powernet/include/pnetxml/powernet_types_pnxml.c, the function ew_unpack_string_ptr() passes user-controlled data to malloc() and memcpy() without sufficient validation.  This can result in a Denial-of-Service.  The str_len variable is declared signed instead of unsigned.  A crafted packet can make make malloc allocate a zero-byte buffer and copy INT_MAX worth of data with memcpy().  The relevant lines of code are:========================================================================char *ew_unpack_string_ptr (uchar *buf, uint32_t *num_bytes_read, uint32_t        *num_bytes_left, pn_runtime_error_t *error_code){    ....    int32_t str_len;    ew_unpack_int32(buf_ptr, &str_len, &length, num_bytes_left,            error_code);    ....    if (str_len > (int32_t)*num_bytes_left) {        *error_code = PN_RUNTIME_ERROR_BUFFER_OVERRUN;        return NULL;    }    value = malloc(str_len + 1);    ....    memcpy(value, (char *)buf_ptr, str_len);    ....}========================================================================
PSIRT: PSIRT-owner: srasovic           PSIRT is reviewing this issue for possible inclusion in a Cisco Security  Advisory which could include this DDTs.  Please do not change the  Release-note Enclosure, as PSIRT will modify it appropriately when this  issue is made public.          Should customers request information regarding this DDTs or appear to be running into this DDTs within their network, please bring it to the immediate attention of the Cisco PSIRT at psirt@cisco.com.

Title: Cisco NX-OS Software removes ACL from VTY interface
RNE: Symptom: The customer has an ACL applied on the VTY interface before the a vBrute Force Remote Login Attacks occurs.  After the  attack finishes it is possible that the ACL has been removed from VTY interdface but remains it remains in the global running configuration. This is problem only when Authentication,  Authorization, and Accounting (AAA) is enabled and the ''login block-for'' command is configured.  Please refer to the Cisco Security Advisory  https://tools.cisco.com/security/center/content/CiscoSecurityAdvisory/cisco-sa-20171018-aaavty  for additional information.  Conditions: The ''login block-for'' command is configured when there are a large number of remote connection requests that could trigger the command.  Workaround: For example if the customer had the ACL foo applied before the AAA ACL related to the ''login block-for'' command was installed, to re-apply the ACL you can do:  interface mgmt0 or vty    no ip access-group foo in      ip access-group foo in  Further Problem Description: Please refer to the Cisco Security Advisory https://tools.cisco.com/security/center/content/CiscoSecurityAdvisory/cisco-sa-20171018-aaavty for additional information.  PSIRT Evaluation: The Cisco PSIRT has assigned this bug the following CVSS version 3 score. The Base CVSS score as of the time of evaluation is 5.3: https://tools.cisco.com/security/center/cvssCalculator.x?version=3.0&vector=CVSS:3.0/AV:N/AC:L/PR:N/UI:N/S:U/C:N/I:L/A:N/E:X/RL:X/RC:X  CVE ID CVE-2017-3883 has been assigned to document this issue.  Additional information on Cisco's security vulnerability policy can be found at the following URL: http://www.cisco.com/en/US/products/products_security_vulnerability_policy.html
Description: This security advisory:https://tools.cisco.com/security/center/content/CiscoSecurityAdvisory/cisco-sa-20171018-aaavty. Was for an AAA crash due to a brute force login attack. The fix was the ?login block-for? command. Almost immediately we were contacted by the account teams asking about the fix for CSCvb93995.CSCvb93995 is specific to the ;login block-for; command and if the attack happens the VTY ACL on themgmt interface can be removed completely. This is a known customer issue and almost one year old. Thereare no customer code fixes available.

Title: IKE fails to initialize when minimal data is sent to pub int.
RNE: Symptoms: Sending a low data rate of traffic to the public interface, may cause the IKE daemon to stop responding. This may prevent new IKEv1 and IKEv2 tunnels from being established.  Conditions: None.  Workaround: None.  Further Problem Description:  PSIRT Evaluation: The Cisco PSIRT has assigned this bug the following CVSS version 2 score. The Base and Temporal CVSS scores as of the time of evaluation are 4.3/3.6:  http://tools.cisco.com/security/center/cvssCalculator.x?vector=AAV:N/AC:M/Au:N/C:N/I:N/A:P/E:F/RL:OF/RC:C&version=2.0  CVE ID CVE-2011-0363 has been assigned to document this issue.  Additional information on Cisco's security vulnerability policy can be found at the following URL:  http://www.cisco.com/en/US/products/products_security_vulnerability_policy.html
Description: UPDATE (cg): 8.3.2 also see's this issue, but it seems to be less susceptible than ACmilan. Floodping makes both ACmilan and Broadview experience the issue, but at 5 packets per second Broadview only lost 2 L2L tunnels (out of 10) while ACmilan dropped them all.While recently tasked to specifically test L2L IKEv2 in the latest ACmilan RC3 image, I came across this IKE issue.When sending a low data rate of ICMP traffic (5 packets per second) to the public interface, it appears that IKE daemon stops responding resulting in the inability to bring up any IKEv1 or IKEv2 tunnels.Setup can be broken down to a single L2L sessions as follows:Steps to reproduce:priv1-----asa1-----pub-----linux-----pub-----asa2-----priv2While running a constant ping from priv1 to priv2 to bring up an IKEv1 L2L tunnel, simply send ICMP data (at 5 packets per second) to the public interface of asa1 from Llnux. Now logoff the l2l session with ;vpn-ses log all; and the tunnel will never reestablish.It appears that all the drops show in the asp table as seen here:Flow drop:  Need to start IKE negotiation (need-ike)                                  4366But turning on debugs for crypto shows nothing, like the IKE daemon stopped responding all together.

Title: Cisco Nexus 9000 Series Switches Telnet Login Denial of Service Vulnerability
RNE: Symptom: A vulnerability in the Telnet remote login functionality of Cisco NX-OS Software running on Cisco Nexus 9000 Series Switches could allow an unauthenticated, remote attacker to cause a Telnet process used for login to terminate unexpectedly and the login attempt to fail. There is no impact to user traffic flowing through the device.  The vulnerability is due to incomplete input validation of Telnet packet headers. An attacker could exploit this vulnerability by sending a crafted Telnet packet to an affected system during a remote Telnet login attempt. A successful exploit could allow the attacker to cause the Telnet process on the affected system to restart unexpectedly, resulting in a denial of service (DoS) condition for the Telnet process.  Conditions: The telnet feature must be enabled on the device.  Workaround: None.  Further Problem Description: None.  PSIRT Evaluation: The Cisco PSIRT has assigned this bug the following CVSS version 3 score. The Base CVSS score as of the time of evaluation is 5.3: https://tools.cisco.com/security/center/cvssCalculator.x?version=3.0&vector=CVSS:3.0/AV:N/AC:L/PR:N/UI:N/S:U/C:N/I:N/A:L/E:X/RL:X/RC:X  CVE ID CVE-2017-3878 has been assigned to document this issue.  Additional information on Cisco's security vulnerability policy can be found at the following URL: http://www.cisco.com/en/US/products/products_security_vulnerability_policy.html

Title: Insufficient Authentication in ASA CTL and TFTP Intercept Design
RNE: Symptom: Due to a design limitation of the phone proxy feature of the Cisco Adaptive Security Appliance (ASA), there is insufficient authentication of the trust certificate presented by the ASA to remote phones.  Conditions: ASA configured to support phone proxy.  Workaround: None.  PSIRT Evaluation: The Cisco PSIRT has assigned this bug the following CVSS version 2 score. The Base and Temporal CVSS scores as of the time of evaluation are 4.3/4.1: http://tools.cisco.com/security/center/cvssCalculator.x?vector=AV:N/AC:M/Au:N/C:N/I:P/A:N/E:F/RL:U/RC:C&version=2.0 CVE ID CVE-2014-0738 has been assigned to document this issue.  Additional details about the vulnerability described here can be found at: http://tools.cisco.com/security/center/content/CiscoSecurityNotice/CVE-2014-0738  Additional information on Cisco's security vulnerability policy can be found at the following URL: http://www.cisco.com/en/US/products/products_security_vulnerability_policy.html  Further Problem Description:
Description: Current ASA design for trust delivery (initial CTL file delivered to a phone) is not rooted in well known Cisco Manufacturing certificates which phones have resident and can easily verify. Instead, the design requires a phone to blindly trust an initial list and its signature when a CTL (certificate trust list) file does not exist. Quotes below are from ASA Phone Proxy Software Functional Specification (see EDCS-619684_quotes enclosure).This allows attackers to control the entities that the phone trusts (CUCMs, ASA, etc). This also allows attackers to give the phones configurations that it will blindly trust. It can also be exploited to prevent the phone from upgrading its firmware. In other words, the phone is totally compromised.

Title: Administrator enumeration via /corusersunsecure/findnamesfromemail
RNE: Symptoms: A vulnerability in the forgot password process of the Cisco WebEx Meetings Server could allow an unauthenticated, remote attacker to enumerate a valid admin account.  The vulnerability is due to insufficient validated user input. An attacker could exploit this vulnerability by submitting specially crafted packets to a vulnerable device.  Conditions: Device configured with default configuration.  Workaround: None  Further Problem Description: None  PSIRT Evaluation: The Cisco PSIRT has assigned this bug the following CVSS version 2 score. The Base and Temporal CVSS scores as of the time of evaluation are 5/4.1: http://tools.cisco.com/security/center/cvssCalculator.x?vector=AV:N/AC:L/Au:N/C:P/I:N/A:N/E:F/RL:OF/RC:C&version=2.0 CVE ID CVE-2015-0597 has been assigned to document this issue.  Additional details about the vulnerability described here can be found at: http://tools.cisco.com/security/center/content/CiscoSecurityNotice/CVE-2015-0597  Additional information on Cisco's security vulnerability policy can be found at the following URL: http://www.cisco.com/en/US/products/products_security_vulnerability_policy.html
Description: The /corusersunsecure/findnamesfromemail URL in the Orion administrator interface will provide the name of any administrator when sent thatadministrator's e-mail address. This does not require authentication or a CAPTCHA to confirm that the request comes from an authenticated user or a human.For example:curl -d '{;email;:;jdoe@cisco.com;}' https://{orion-admin}/corusersunsecure/findnamesfromemail=> {;lastName;:;Doe;,;firstName;:;John;}curl -d '{;email;:;invalid@cisco.com;}' https://{orion-admin}/corusersunsecure/findnamesfromemail=> {}An attacker can use this bug to automatically enumerate the administrators ofthe Orion instance, and to find the names of those administrators.  It isunlikely that this feature needs to be available to unauthenticated users, andso authentication should be required on this URL.

Title: CUCM: Tomcat Remote Code Execution / Info Disclosure Vulnerabilities
RNE: Symptom: Cisco Unified Communications Manager and Unified Communications Manager Session Management Edition  includes a version of Apache Tomcat that is affected by the vulnerabilities identified by the  following Common Vulnerability and Exposures (CVE) IDs:  CVE-2017-5647, CVE-2017-5648 and CVE-2017-8745	  This bug was opened to address the potential impact on this product.  Conditions: Device with default configuration.  Workaround: Not currently available.  Further Problem Description: Additional details about the vulnerabilities listed above can be found at http://cve.mitre.org/cve/cve.html.  PSIRT Evaluation: The Cisco PSIRT has assigned this bug the following CVSS version 3 score. The Base CVSS score as of the time of evaluation is 9.1: https://tools.cisco.com/security/center/cvssCalculator.x?version=3.0&vector=CVSS:3.0/AV:N/AC:L/PR:N/UI:N/S:U/C:H/I:H/A:N/E:X/RL:X/RC:X  CVE ID CVE-2017-5647, CVE-2017-5648, CVE-2017-8745 has been assigned to document this issue.  Additional information on Cisco's security vulnerability policy can be found at the following URL: http://www.cisco.com/en/US/products/products_security_vulnerability_policy.html  ***** This fix is superseded by CSCve93018*****
Description: ***** This fix is superseded by CSCve93018*****(1) Important: Information Disclosure CVE-2017-5647A bug in the handling of the pipelined requests when send file was used resulted in the pipelined request being lost when send file processing of the previous request completed. This could result in responses appearing to be sent for the wrong request. For example, a user agent that sent requests A, B and C could see the correct response for request A, the response for request C for request B and no response for request C.Affects: 7.0.0 to 7.0.76Fixed in Apache Tomcat 7.0.77(2) Low: Information Disclosure CVE-2017-5648While investigating bug 60718, it was noticed that some calls to application listeners did not use the appropriate facade object. When running an untrusted application under a SecurityManager, it was therefore possible for that untrusted application to retain a reference to the request or response object and thereby access and/or modify information associated with another web application.Affects: 7.0.0 to 7.0.75Fixed in Apache Tomcat 7.0.76(3) Important: Information Disclosure CVE-2016-8745A bug in the error handling of the send file code for the NIO HTTP connector resulted in the current Processor object being added to the Processor cache multiple times. This in turn meant that the same Processor could be used for concurrent requests. Sharing a Processor can result in information leakage between requests including, but not limited to, session ID and the response body.Affects: 7.0.0 to 7.0.74Fixed in Apache Tomcat 7.0.75

Title: Cisco Firepower Detection Engine SSL Decryption Memory Consumption Denial of Service Vulnerability
RNE: Symptom: A vulnerability in SSL traffic decryption for Cisco Firepower Threat Defense (FTD) Software could allow an unauthenticated, remote attacker to cause depletion of system memory. If this memory leak persists over time, a denial of service (DoS) condition could develop because traffic can cease to be forwarded through the device.  The vulnerability is due to an error in how the Firepower Detection Snort Engine handles SSL traffic decryption and notifications to and from the Adaptive Security Appliance (ASA) handler. An attacker could exploit this vulnerability by sending a steady stream of malicious Secure Sockets Layer (SSL) traffic through the device. An exploit could allow the attacker to cause a DoS condition when the device runs low on system memory.  Cisco has released software updates that address this vulnerability. There are no workarounds that address this vulnerability.  This advisory is available at the following link: https://tools.cisco.com/security/center/content/CiscoSecurityAdvisory/cisco-sa-20171004-ftd  Conditions: Please refer to the Security Advisory.  Workaround: Please refer to the Security Advisory.  Further Problem Description: PSIRT Evaluation: The Cisco PSIRT has assigned this bug the following CVSS version 3 score. The Base CVSS score as of the time of evaluation is 8.6: https://tools.cisco.com/security/center/cvssCalculator.x?version=3.0&vector=CVSS:3.0/AV:N/AC:L/PR:N/UI:N/S:C/C:N/I:N/A:H/E:X/RL:X/RC:X  CVE ID CVE-2017-12245 has been assigned to document this issue.  Additional information on Cisco's security vulnerability policy can be found at the following URL: http://www.cisco.com/en/US/products/products_security_vulnerability_policy.html

Title: Cisco IOS and IOS XE Software Plug-and-Play PKI API Certificate Validation Vulnerability
RNE: Symptom: A vulnerability in the Cisco Network Plug and Play application of Cisco IOS and IOS XE Software could allow an unauthenticated, remote attacker to gain unauthorized access to sensitive data using an invalid certificate.  The vulnerability is due to insufficient certificate validation. An attacker could exploit this vulnerability by supplying a crafted certificate to the affected device. A successful exploit could allow the attacker to conduct man-in-the-middle attacks to decrypt confidential information on user connections.   Cisco has released software updates that address this vulnerability. Workarounds that address this vulnerability are not available. This advisory is available at the following link: https://tools.cisco.com/security/center/content/CiscoSecurityAdvisory/cisco-sa-20170927-pnp  Conditions: Device configured with the Cisco Plug and Play feature enabled and, with the PKI API feature enabled.  Workaround: There are no workarounds that address this vulnerability.  Further Problem Description: None.  PSIRT Evaluation: The Cisco PSIRT has assigned this bug the following CVSS version 3 score. The Base CVSS score as of the time of evaluation is 8.7: https://tools.cisco.com/security/center/cvssCalculator.x?version=3.0&vector=CVSS:3.0/AV:N/AC:H/PR:N/UI:N/S:C/C:H/I:H/A:N/E:X/RL:X/RC:X  CVE ID CVE-2017-12228 has been assigned to document this issue.  Additional information on Cisco's security vulnerability policy can be found at the following URL: http://www.cisco.com/en/US/products/products_security_vulnerability_policy.html     Symptom:Conditions:Workaround:Further Problem Description:
Description: It looks like PKI API is missing this validation to disallow install of any other TP bundle/single certificate other than Cisco signed PKCS7 one. Due to this, when PNP agent on CPE device makes request to ;http://server/ca/trustpool; and server gives fake single certificate (not fake trust pool bundle), with missing validation to prevent this in PKI API,  PKI Infra simply accepted it and installed that on CPE device as a new trust point. This exposes now CPE to MIM and makes it trust that fake server.

Title: Cisco AnyConnect Secure Mobility Client for Windows SBL Privileges Escalation Vulnerability
RNE: Symptoms: A vulnerability in the Start Before Logon (SBL) module of Cisco AnyConnect Secure Mobility Client Software for Windows could allow an unauthenticated, local attacker to open Internet Explorer with the privileges of the SYSTEM user.  The vulnerability is due to insufficient implementation of the access controls. An attacker could exploit this vulnerability by opening the Internet Explorer browser. An exploit could allow the attacker to use Internet Explorer with the privileges of the SYSTEM user. This may allow the attacker to execute privileged commands on the targeted system.   Cisco has released software updates that address this vulnerability. Workarounds that address this vulnerability are not available. This advisory is available at the following link: https://tools.cisco.com/security/center/content/CiscoSecurityAdvisory/cisco-sa-20170208-anyconnect  Conditions: See advisory  Workaround: See advisory  Further Problem Description:  PSIRT Evaluation: The Cisco PSIRT has assigned this bug the following CVSS version 3 score. Title: L4TM fails to block or log connections
RNE: $$IGNORE-PSIRT  CISCO HIGHLY CONFIDENTIAL - CONTROLLED ACCESS  This issue is under review by the Cisco Product Security Incident Response team (PSIRT).  The defect describes a product security vulnerability.  Its contents must be protected from unauthorized disclosure, both internal and external to Cisco.  Do not forward this information to mailing lists or newsgroups.  Documentation writers: it is prohibited to publish this Release-note  Enclosure (RNE) until the content has been approved by PSIRT.  PSIRT may  publish a Security Advisory regarding this defect, and the current text of  this RNE will be replaced with appropriate information.  In the event that  a Security Advisory is not published, PSIRT will replace this text with an  appropriate explanation.  More information on PSIRT is available at http//psirt.cisco.com/.   Cisco's public policy on security vulnerability handling can be reviewed at  http://www.cisco.com/en/US/products/products_security_vulnerability_policy.html. For further information, send a message to psirt@cisco.com.  (tfinn-11/20/17)Symptom: The L4 Traffic Monitor, will fail to block or log connections.  Conditions:  Workaround: None  Further Problem Description:
Description: Customer: CAJA LOS ANDES  BEMS706807 SR 683317811We have a serious defect that L4TM is not working on our 10.5 builds (FreeBSD 10.1). This defect is that its not possible to get the ethernet packets that L4TM is interested in, to be sent over to IPFW to be filtered.   This means that we see none of the DNS packets that we would filter to populate the tables, and we no longer block or log, the IPs that L4TM should be keying off of.   Freebsd 9 has this sysctl setting that would send bridged packets over to L4TM ;net.link.ether.bridge_ipfw: 1;  Freebsd 10 does not, and there appears to be no other way to send the packets we are interested in, over to be filtered.Repro: (Need a WSA wired for L4TM)1) Configure a L4TM rule to block an IP.2) Run a transparent request through your WSA to that IP, it won't get blocked.Our current implementation of L4TM uses the ipfw rule of layer2, to identify any L4TM packets from T1/T2.  With freebsd 10, the ipfw count of any packets matching a layer2 rule will be zero.  It is possible to send layer2 packets over to IPFW, by setting ;net.link.ether.ipfw;  (Enabling this setting will make your WSA network unreachable, unless you modify the ipfw rules first).  This setting is not a global setting, cause it only gets us the layer 2 packets intended for this WSA, not the bridged ones, and the bridged ones are what we need for L4TM to function.

Title: ACS Multiple Reflected Cross- Site Scripting (XSS)
RNE: Symptoms: A vulnerability in the web framework of Cisco Secure Access Control Server (ACS) could allow an unauthenticated, remote attacker to perform multiple cross-site scripting attacks (XSS) against a user of the web interface on the affected system.  The vulnerability is due to insufficient input validation of several parameters passed to the web server. An attacker could exploit this vulnerability by persuading a user to access a malicious link. An exploit could allow the attacker to run arbitrary scripts in the context of the user's browser.  Conditions: ACS server running release 5.5 without patch 7 or later patch.
