Title: With inline IPS and heavy load ASA could drop ICMP or DNS replies
RNE: Symptom:Intermittently, DNS reply packets, or ICMP echo reply packets, might be dropped by the ASA.  Conditions:To encounter this bug, an ASA IPS module must be in-line with the traffic flow. The IPS module must be under heavy processing load.   Additionally, for DNS traffic to be affected, the dns-guard feature must be enabled (it is enabled by default)  For ICMP echo-replies to be affected, the 'inspect icmp' feature must be enabled (it is disabled by default)  Workaround: - Reduce the processing load on the IPS, by reducing the amount of traffic sent to it - Exempt the affected traffic from IPS inspection - Change the IPS processing from 'in-line' to 'promiscuous'  In the case of ICMP echo replies being dropped, disable 'inspect icmp'  In the case of DNS replies being dropped, disable dns-guard. This should be done with caution, since with dns-guard disabled, each DNS connection will remain in the ASA's connection table until the UDP timeout applies to the connection. This could result in a significant amount of additional UDP connections in the ASA's connection table:  ------------------------------------ policy-map type inspect dns preset_dns_map  parameters   message-length maximum client auto   message-length maximum 512   no dns-guard            ----- HERE policy-map global_policy  class inspection_default   inspect dns preset_dns_map    inspect ftp    inspect h323 h225    inspect h323 ras    inspect rsh    inspect rtsp    inspect esmtp    inspect sqlnet    inspect skinny     inspect sunrpc    inspect xdmcp    inspect sip     inspect netbios    inspect tftp    inspect ip-options    inspect icmp   class IPS   ips inline fail-open ! service-policy global_policy global ------------------------------------ More Info:When this problem is encountered, the ASA drops the packet and will increment the following ASP drop counter:  (flow-expired) Expired flow  This can be seen with the output of 'show asp drop' on the ASA:  ASA#show asp drop ...           Expired flow (flow-expired)                          323 Further Problem Description: PSIRT Evaluation: The Cisco PSIRT has assigned this bug the following CVSS version 2 score. The Base and Temporal CVSS scores as of the time of evaluation are 2.6/2.3: http://tools.cisco.com/security/center/cvssCalculator.x?vector=AV:N/AC:H/Au:N/C:N/I:N/A:P/E:ND/RL:OF/RC:C&version=2.0 No CVE ID has been assigned to this issue. Additional information on Cisco's security vulnerability policy can be found at the following URL: http://www.cisco.com/en/US/products/products_security_vulnerability_policy.html
Description: ASA drops AAAA DNS packets, though we cannot see the drops in the IPS events or on the ASA either. It's not every packet but only intermittent drops.Capture the packet in the inbound and outbound interface and also the ASA back plane. The packet crosses the IPS module, but not seen in the outbound interface. There are no asp drops in ASA.But if the traffic is bypassed from IPS, then it works fine.  But we noticed that the traffic crosses the IPS.The packets show up in the asp drop capture like this (note the header information is missing):20: 18:48:25.226703       802.3 encap packet Drop-reason: (flow-expired) Expired flowSee the 'reproduction-steps' enclosure for more details of the problem and the trigger

Title: /tmp/*config files left over when vty exited not cleanly
RNE: Symptom: A vulnerability in Cisco ASR 9000 Series Aggregation Services Routers could allow an authenticated, local attacker to produce excessive tmp/*config files which will cause the system to become unresponsive. The vulnerability is due to user's VTY sessions being closed abruptly (no clean exit) after the commit/end in global configuration mode. An attacker could exploit this vulnerability by using methods to generate excessive tmp/*config files thus causing the affected system memory to be exhausted.  Conditions: Excessive files leaking to /tmp causing memory errors.  Workaround: run cd /tmp find  . -regex '[0-9] \.config$' -mtime  1 -exec rm {} \; exit  Further Problem Description: None.   PSIRT Evaluation: The Cisco PSIRT has assigned this bug the following CVSS version 2 score. The Base and Temporal CVSS scores as of the time of evaluation are 4.6/3.8: http://tools.cisco.com/security/center/cvssCalculator.x?vector=AV:L/AC:L/Au:S/C:N/I:N/A:C/E:F/RL:OF/RC:C&version=2.0 CVE ID CVE-2015-4277 has been assigned to document this issue. Additional information on Cisco's security vulnerability policy can be found at the following URL: http://www.cisco.com/en/US/products/products_security_vulnerability_policy.html
Description: ASR9K 5.1.3 customer router faced various process crashes due to ;nomemory; error message although there was still plenty of free memory.After investigation, it turns out that they have lot of config commitshappening all the time (provisioning robot) and this leaves lot of filesunder /tmp/# cd /tmp# find . -type f -printf '%p\t%k KB\n'./996331845.config      1 KB./996311365.config      1 KB./996290885.config      1 KB./996270405.config      1 KB./996249925.config      1 KBthey're currently 47000 of those /tmp/*.config files.they don't consume much, but when /tmp reaches around 64000 as Isimulated in my lab,no more file can be created anymore and various process/dll willcomplain of no memory and crash !leak of /tmp/*config file is easily reproducible  if the vtysession is closed abruptly (no clean exit) after the commit/end inconfig mode like done by customer script. over time, the number of leaked files grow up to the /tmp limit of 64K files (for my customer, in 3 months)./tmp/<pid>.config file leak still exists in 5.3.0 as tested in labthis is easy to fix on the script side of the customer however this is pretty sever since there's no way to detect this (wdsysmon doesn't monitor number of files in /tmp) and when /tmp reaches around 64k files, plenty of processes and dll will start crashing, leaving no other choice than user to trigger RP reload

Title: Cisco IOS and Cisco IOS XE input queue holding Vulnerability
RNE: Symptom: A vulnerability in the UDP processing code of Cisco IOS and Cisco IOS XE Software could allow an unauthenticated, remote attacker to cause the input queue of an affected system to hold UDP packets, causing an interface queue wedge and a denial of service (DoS) condition. The vulnerability is due to Cisco IOS Software application changes that create UDP sockets and leave the sockets idle without closing them. An attacker could exploit this vulnerability by sending UDP packets with a destination port of 0 to an affected device. A successful exploit could allow the attacker to cause UDP packets to be held in the input interfaces queue, resulting in a DoS condition. The input interface queue will stop holding UDP packets when it receives 250 packets.  There are workarounds that address this vulnerability.   This advisory is available at the following link: https://tools.cisco.com/security/center/content/CiscoSecurityAdvisory/cisco-sa-20170906-ios-udp  Conditions: This issue is addressed via different bugs id, consult the advisory https://tools.cisco.com/security/center/content/CiscoSecurityAdvisory/cisco-sa-20170906-ios-udp for further details.  Device with default configuration.  Below table indicates affected trains and fixed releases.  Cisco IOS Software 15.1GC Train		Vulnerable 15.2GC Train		Vulnerable 15.2GCA Train		Vulnerable 15.4(3)M Train		Vulnerable, first fixed in 15.4(3)M8 15.4(2)T Train		Vulnerable, first fixed in 15.4(2)T3 15.6(2)S4		Vulnerable  No other Cisco IOS Software trains/releases are affected.  Cisco IOS XE Software   3.14S Train:		Vulnerable  3.15S Train:		Vulnerable  3.16S Train:   	Vulnerable, first fixed in 3.16.6S  3.16XB Train:		Vulnerable  3.17S Train:		Vulnerable  3.18S/SP Trains:	Vulnerable   No other Cisco IOS XE Software trains/releases are affected.  Cisco IOS XE 16.x Software  16.1 Train:		Not Vulnerable  16.2 Train:		Vulnerable  16.3 Train:		Vulnerable, first fixed in 16.3.3  16.4 and later trains: Not Vulnerable  Workaround: None.  In the event that the interface has a input hold queue  250, the interface would wedge.  Configure the affected interface with a hold queue greater  than 250.  If the hold queue was originally 75 configure the hold queue for 325 (75   250).  Router(config)#interface fastEthernet 0/0 Router(config-if)#hold-queue 325 in  Further Problem Description: PSIRT Evaluation: The Cisco PSIRT has assigned this bug the following CVSS version 3 score. The Base CVSS score as of the time of evaluation is 5.3: https://tools.cisco.com/security/center/cvssCalculator.x?version=3.0&vector=CVSS:3.0/AV:N/AC:L/PR:N/UI:N/S:U/C:N/I:N/A:L/E:X/RL:X/RC:X  CVE ID CVE-2017-6627 has been assigned to document this issue.  Additional information on Cisco's security vulnerability policy can be found at the following URL: http://www.cisco.com/en/US/products/products_security_vulnerability_policy.html
Description: CSCup10024 specific commit needs to be done to IOS-XE branches. This bug is created for same purpose. Refer CSCup10024 for additional commit specific details.man_infra_server.c makes dummy UDP socket that hijacks msgs to port 0vob/ios/sys/man_infra_server.c creates a ;dummy; UDP socket which actually receives all the messages addressed to UDP port 0.ipsla_isr2-1#sh udpProto        Remote      Port      Local       Port  In Out  Stat TTY OutputIF... 17     0.0.0.0             0 --any--             0   0   0   211   0 ipsla_isr2-1#sh udp detail ...Proto        Remote      Port      Local       Port  In Out  Stat TTY OutputIF 17     0.0.0.0             0 --any--             0   0   0   211   0  Queues: output 0         input  0 (drops 0, max 50, highwater 0)This happens in this code:    /*     * We open a ;dummy; file descriptor in order to force socket_select     * to watch for events OTHER than sockets -- for instance, we can have     * socket_select watch for events coming in on our watched queue. In      * that event, the select will return -1, and errno will be set to      * EINTR.      */    server_context.dummy_fd = manet_infra_socket_open();    if (socket_watch_other_events(watch) == -1) {        if (MANET_INFRA_DEBUG_ERROR) {            buginf(;\n%s: socket_watch_other_events FAILED.;,                     MANET_INFRA_DEBUG_FUNCTION);        }    }

Title: ASA IDFW Susceptible to RADIUS CoA Replay Vulnerability
RNE: Symptom: The Identity Firewall (IDFW) feature of the Cisco Adaptive Security Appliance (ASA) is susceptible to replayed RADIUS Change of Authorization messages. This issue is due to insufficient input validation of received CoA messages.  Conditions: Installation of an affected release of ASA software with IDFW configured.  Workaround: None.  PSIRT Evaluation: The Cisco PSIRT has assigned this bug the following CVSS version 2 score. The Base and Temporal CVSS scores as of the time of evaluation are 4.3/4.1: http://tools.cisco.com/security/center/cvssCalculator.x?vector=AV:N/AC:M/Au:N/C:N/I:P/A:N/E:F/RL:U/RC:C&version=2.0 CVE ID CVE-2014-0655 has been assigned to document this issue.  Additional details about the vulnerability described here can be found at: http://tools.cisco.com/security/center/content/CiscoSecurityNotice/CVE-2014-0655  Additional information on Cisco's security vulnerability policy can be found at the following URL: http://www.cisco.com/en/US/products/products_security_vulnerability_policy.html  Further Problem Description:
Description: Executive SummaryRADIUS Change of Authorization (CoA) packets are normally sent from the AD Agent to the ASA on udp/3799 to alter the Identity Firewall cache on the ASA. The Identity Firewall cache maintains a list of authenticated clients which the ASA uses to make packet filtering decisions. CoA packets can be captured and replayed at will, thereby controlling the ASA's knowledge of authenticated clients and its security policy actions.Technical DetailsIt is not required that the user be present in the ASA Identity Firewall cache at all for the replay to be successful. If the user is not present (neither Inactive nor Login) in the user cache, the user will be added to the cache and set to the Login state. If the user is present in the cache, but in the Inactive state, the user will be changed to the Login state.Attack ScenarioAn attacker could replay a RADIUS CoA, destined for an ASA that has a user or group access-control list configured, that adds a user-to-ip mapping to the ASA for an IP that the attacker obtains or spoofs. This would allow the attacker to bypass Active Directory authentication and the requirement for a user-to-ip mapping to be present in the AD Agent/CDA cache, and obtain unauthorized access through the ASA.

Title: Cisco IOS XE Wireless Controller Manager DoS Vulnerability
RNE: Symptom: A vulnerability in wireless controller manager of Cisco IOS XE could allow an unauthenticated, adjacent attacker to cause a restart of the switch.  The vulnerability is due to insufficient input validation. An attacker could exploit this vulnerability by submitting a crafted association request. An exploit could allow the attacker to cause the switch to restart.  Conditions: An IOS XE device providing wireless network services.  Workaround: None.  Further Problem Description: This is specific to platforms with Wireless LAN Controller (e.g. 3850/3860).  PSIRT Evaluation: The Cisco PSIRT has assigned this bug the following CVSS version 3 score. The Base CVSS score as of the time of evaluation is 7.4: https://tools.cisco.com/security/center/cvssCalculator.x?version=3.0&vector=CVSS:3.0/AV:A/AC:L/PR:N/UI:N/S:C/C:N/I:N/A:H/E:X/RL:X/RC:X  CVE ID CVE-2017-12222 has been assigned to document this issue. Title: UCSE Cisco Integrated Management Controller (CIMC) Remote command execution vulnerability
RNE: Symptoms:  A vulnerability in the web-based GUI of Cisco Integrated Management Controller (IMC) could allow an unauthenticated, remote attacker to perform unauthorized remote command execution on the affected device.  The vulnerability exists because the affected software does not sufficiently sanitize specific values that are received as part of a user-supplied HTTP request. An attacker could exploit this vulnerability by sending a crafted HTTP request to the affected software. Successful exploitation could allow an unauthenticated attacker to execute system commands with root-level privileges.  Conditions: Device configured with default configuration.  Workaround: None.  Further Problem Description: None.  PSIRT Evaluation: The Cisco PSIRT has assigned this bug the following CVSS version 3 score. The Base CVSS score as of the time of evaluation is X: https://tools.cisco.com/security/center/cvssCalculator.x?version=3.0&vector=CVSS:3.0/AV:-/AC:-/PR:-/UI:-/S:-/C:-/I:-/A:-/E:X/RL:X/RC:X  CVE ID CVE-2017-6616 has been assigned to document this issue. Title: ACE A5 Command Injection Vulnerability
RNE: Symptom: Summary A vulnerability in the Device Manager GUI of the Cisco ACE 4710 Application Control Engine could allow an authenticated, remote attacker to execute any CLI command on the ACE with admin user privileges.  The vulnerability is due to insufficient validation on user supplied input. An attacker could exploit this vulnerability by crafting a malicious HTTP POST request with injected CLI commands inside the POST parameters values. An exploit could allow the attacker to bypass the Role Based Access Control (RBAC) restrictions enforced by the ACE Device Manager GUI.  Cisco has released software updates that address this vulnerability. Workarounds that mitigate this vulnerability are available.  This advisory is available at the following link:  http://tools.cisco.com/security/center/content/CiscoSecurityAdvisory/cisco-sa-20160224-ace PSIRT Evaluation: The Cisco PSIRT has assigned this bug the following CVSS version 2 score. The Base and Temporal CVSS scores as of the time of evaluation are 8.5/8.1: http://tools.cisco.com/security/center/cvssCalculator.x?vector=AV:N/AC:M/Au:S/C:C/I:C/A:C/E:F/RL:U/RC:C&version=2.0  CVE ID CVE-2016-1297 has been assigned to document this issue. Additional information on Cisco's security vulnerability policy can be found at the following URL: http://www.cisco.com/en/US/products/products_security_vulnerability_policy.html  Conditions:  Workaround:  Further Problem Description:
Description: The 'trace.vm' and 'device_output.vm' modules allow arbitrary command injection regardless of user rights under superuser privileges.This can be achieved by using the 'cli_command' parameter in device_output.vm and by injecting newlines ;%0a%0d; in the arguments for the ping command in trace.vm as seen in the curl command below where the 'ipAddress' parameter was used.curl -i -s -k  -X 'POST' \    -H 'Content-Type: application/x-www-form-urlencoded' \    -b 'JSESSIONID=secrit;'    --data-binary$'test_id=trace+1&mode=new&new_mode=results&object_id=%2Fdevice%2Fscimitar%2Fmodule%2Ftrinity-001%2FAdmin&object_type=10&view_ids=&command=set%2Cstart&vsm_id=&port_id=&ioport_id=&sessionCount=10&flowCount=127.0.0.1&packetCount=&testName=ping&timeout=5&repeatCount=5&datagramSize=100&probeCount=5&minTTL=100&maxTTL=100&portNumber=3&ipAddressType=IPv4&ipAddress=127.0.0.1%0a%0dshow%20context%0a%0d&flowType=1&anyIp=30&sourceIp=33434&destinationIp=0&anyPort=&sourcePort=&destinationPort=&protocol=&vlan=&filterRaw=&accessList=&bufferSize=&circularBuffer=&menuid=%2Fmonitor%2Fdevices%2Fping&title=Ping'\    'https://ace/trace.vm'This issue was reported by an external entity.Reproduced against A5(2.0) and A5(2.2)
PSIRT: PSIRT-owner: psirt           PSIRT is reviewing this issue for possible inclusion in a Cisco Security  Advisory which could include this DDTs.  Please do not change the  Release-note Enclosure, as PSIRT will modify it appropriately when this  issue is made public.          Should customers request information regarding this DDTs or appear to be running into this DDTs within their network, please bring it to the immediate attention of the Cisco PSIRT at psirt@cisco.com.

Title: Non authenticated HTTP page allows to logout any connected client
RNE: Symptom: A vulnerability in the Web Management GUI of the Wireless Lan Controller (WLC) could allow an unauthenticated, remote attacker to trigger the disconnection of a client.  The vulnerability is due to lack of access control to the WLC Web Management GUI. An attacker could exploit this vulnerability by connecting to the ip address of the WLC (via wired interface) and triggering client disconnections.  Conditions: The attacker needs to be able to reach the WLC management ip address on port 80 or port 443 via its wired interface.  Workaround: Use CPU ACLs to restrict access to the Web Management GUI  Further Problem Description: PSIRT Evaluation: The Cisco PSIRT has assigned this bug the following CVSS version 2 score. The Base and Temporal CVSS scores as of the time of evaluation are 5/4.8: http://tools.cisco.com/security/center/cvssCalculator.x?vector=AV:N/AC:L/Au:N/C:N/I:N/A:P/E:F/RL:U/RC:C&version=2.0 CVE ID CVE-2015-6341 has been assigned to document this issue. Additional information on Cisco's security vulnerability policy can be found at the following URL: http://www.cisco.com/en/US/products/products_security_vulnerability_policy.html
Description: Using URL:http://WLCIP/portal_logout.htmlAnyone with IP access to the WLC can deauthenticate users, if they know the IP addressThere is no provision for brute force attacks, so it is possible to do automated IP scan, and force client disconenctions
PSIRT: PSIRT-owner: psirt           PSIRT is reviewing this issue for possible inclusion in a Cisco Security  Advisory which could include this DDTs. Title: Evaluation of CVE-2015-0235 'GHOST' vulnerability on IEA
RNE: Symptom: Cisco Iron Port Encryption Appliance includes a version of glibC that is affected by the vulnerabilities identified by the following Common Vulnerability and Exposures (CVE) IDs:   CVE-2015-0235  This bug was opened to address the potential impact on this product.  Conditions: Device with default configuration.  Workaround: The Cisco Ironport Encryption Appliance can be updated using the following procedure  Step 1   Use SSH to connect to the appliance. Step 2 At the main menu, enter option x to exit to the Unix command prompt.   Note: The x option is a hidden command and does not appear in the list of menu options Step 3 Verify the current glibc version:   $ rpm -qa | grep glibc Step 4 Run the following command to upgrade glibc    $ sudo yum install glibc glibc-common  Step 5 To verify that the upgrade was properly installed   $ rpm -qa | grep glibc      glibc-common-2.5-123.el5_11.1      glibc-2.5-123.el5_11.1 Step 6 Type exit to return to the main menu for the Cisco IronPort Encryption Appliance and choose option 5    5) Restart Operating System  Further Problem Description: Additional details about the vulnerabilities listed above can be found at http://cve.mitre.org/cve/cve.html  PSIRT Evaluation: The Cisco PSIRT has assigned this bug the following CVSS version 2 score. The Base and Temporal CVSS scores as of the time of evaluation are: 10/7.8  http://tools.cisco.com/security/center/cvssCalculator.x?vector=AV:N/AC:L/Au:N/C:C/I:C/A:C/E:F/RL:OF/RC:C/CDP:ND/TD:ND/CR:ND/IR:ND/AR:ND&version=2.0  The Cisco PSIRT has assigned this score based on information obtained from multiple sources. This includes the CVSS score assigned by the third-party vendor when available. The CVSS score assigned may not reflect the actual impact on the Cisco Product.  Additional information on Cisco's security vulnerability policy can be found at the following URL:  http://www.cisco.com/web/about/security/psirt/security_vulnerability_policy.html
Description: MITRE: http://cve.mitre.org/cgi-bin/cvename.cgi?name=CVE-2015-0235Qualys: https://community.qualys.com/blogs/laws-of-vulnerabilities/2015/01/27/the-ghost-vulnerabilityOpenwall (source of test script): http://www.openwall.com/lists/oss-security/2015/01/27/9RedHat: https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=CVE-2015-0235The IEA product appears to be vulnerable to this according to my own tests.  I will be attaching the output in an enclosure.

Title: Apache Server (2.2.24 and below) Vulnerabilities on UCS Manager
RNE: Symptom: Cisco UCS Manager includes a version of Apache that is affected by the vulnerabilities identified by the following Common Vulnerability and Exposures (CVE) IDs: CVE-2013-1862, CVE-2013-1896 and CVE-2013-2249  Cisco has analyzed these vulnerabilities and concluded that the product is not impacted by either CVE-2013-1896 or CVE-2013-2249.  The fix for this bug will include a fix for the vulnerability described in CVE-2013-1862.  Conditions: Device with default configuration.  The Apache server used with the Cisco UCS manager does not include either the mod_dav.c or the mod_session_dbd modules. Workaround: Not currently available. More Info: Additional details about the vulnerabilities listed above can be found at http://cve.mitre.org/cve/cve.html  PSIRT Evaluation: The Cisco PSIRT has assigned this bug the following CVSS version 2 score. The Base and Temporal CVSS scores as of the time of evaluation are 4.3/3.2: https://https://intellishield.cisco.com/security/alertmanager/cvssCalculator.do?dispatch=1&vector=AV:N/AC:M/Au:N/C:N/I:P/A:N/E:U/RL:OF/RC:C&version=2.0  The Cisco PSIRT has assigned this score based on information obtained from multiple sources. This includes the CVSS score assigned by the third-party vendor when available. The CVSS score assigned may not reflect the actual impact on the Cisco Product.  CVE ID CVE-2013-1862 have been assigned to document this issue.  Additional details about the vulnerability described here can be found at: http://tools.cisco.com/security/center/content/CiscoSecurityNotice/CVE-2013-1862  Confirmation on none affected vulnerabilities described here can be found at: http://tools.cisco.com/security/center/content/CiscoSecurityNotice/CVE-2013-1896 http://tools.cisco.com/security/center/content/CiscoSecurityNotice/CVE-2013-2249  Additional information on Cisco's security vulnerability policy can be found at the following URL: http://www.cisco.com/en/US/products/products_security_vulnerability_policy.html
Description: The Apache Server versions used for UCS firmware 2.1(2a), 2.1(1a) and above, 2.0(3a) and above are all affected since they all use Apache Server 2.2.24 and below.How to Fix:Update the Apache HTTP Server to version 2.4.6, 2.2.25 or later.Exploits:CVE-2013-1862- mod_rewrite.c in the mod_rewrite module in the Apache HTTP Server 2.2.x before 2.2.25 writes data to a log file without sanitizing non-printable characters, which might allow remote attackers to execute arbitrary commands via an HTTP request containing an escape sequence for a terminal emulator.CVE-2013-1896- mod_dav.c in the Apache HTTP Server before 2.2.25 does not properly determine whether DAV is enabled for a URI, which allows remote attackers to cause a denial of service (segmentation fault) via a MERGE request in which the URI is configured for handling by the mod_dav_svn module, but a certain href attribute in XML data refers to a non-DAV URI.CVE-2013-2249- mod_session_dbd.c in the mod_session_dbd module in the Apache HTTP Server before 2.4.5 proceeds with save operations for a session without considering the dirty flag and the requirement for a new session ID, which has unspecified impact and remote attack vectors.IAV:2013-A-0146- Multiple Security Vulnerabilities in Apache HTTP Server- NAVCIRT: 2013-A-0146BugtraqID:59826- Apache HTTP Server Terminal Escape Sequence in Logs Command Injection Vulnerability61129- Apache HTTP Server CVE-2013-1896 Remote Denial of Service Vulnerability61379- Apache HTTP Server CVE-2013-2249 Unspecified Remote Security VulnerabilityFrom FI running UCSM 2.1.2a--------------------------------------# curl  --head <FI_IP_address>HTTP/1.1 200 OKDate: Fri, 19 Jul 2013 08:05:25 GMTServer: Apache/2.2.24 (Unix) mod_ssl/2.2.24 OpenSSL/FIPSLast-Modified: Fri, 19 Jul 2013 07:58:48 GMTAccept-Ranges: bytesContent-Length: 5103Content-Type: text/html------------------------

Title: Arc-CUAC Vulnerability for JMX Interface and RMI service (2015/2016)
RNE: Symptom: Cisco Unified Attendant Console Advanced includes a version of MI service in SolarWinds Virtualization Manager that is affected by the vulnerabilities identified by the following  Common Vulnerability and Exposures (CVE) IDs:  CVE-2015-2342 and CVE-2016-3642  This bug was opened to address the potential impact on this product.  Conditions: Device with default configuration.  Workaround: Not currently available.  Further Problem Description: Additional details about the vulnerabilities listed above can be found at  http://cve.mitre.org/cve/cve.html.  PSIRT Evaluation: The Cisco PSIRT has assigned this bug the following CVSS version 3 score. The Base CVSS score as of the time of evaluation is 9.8: https://tools.cisco.com/security/center/cvssCalculator.x?version=3.0&vector=CVSS:3.0/AV:N/AC:L/PR:N/UI:N/S:U/C:H/I:H/A:H/E:X/RL:X/RC:X  CVE ID CVE-2015-2342, CVE-2016-3642 has been assigned to document this issue.  Additional information on Cisco's security vulnerability policy can be found at the following URL: http://www.cisco.com/en/US/products/products_security_vulnerability_policy.html
Description: Cisco Unified Attendant Console Advanced;Cisco Unified Attendant Console Business Edition;Cisco Unified Attendant Console Department Edition;Cisco Unified Attendant Console Enterprise Edition;Cisco Unified Attendant Console Premium Edition includes a version of Commons Collections library that is affected by the vulnerability identified by the Common Vulnerability and Exposures (CVE) IDs:CVE-2015-2342The JMX RMI service in VMware vCenter Server 5.0 before u3e, 5.1 before u3b, 5.5 before u3, and 6.0 before u1 does not restrict registration of MBeans, which allows remote attackers to execute arbitrary code via the RMI protocol. CVE-2016-3642The RMI service in SolarWinds Virtualization Manager 6.3.1 and earlier allows remote attackers to execute arbitrary commands via a crafted serialized Java object, related to the Apache Commons Collections (ACC) library.This product is affected by the listed CVE id.This defect is to track investigation of the recently reported Apache commons library vulnerability, and its impact on Cisco Unified Attendant Console Advanced;Cisco Unified Attendant Console Business Edition;Cisco Unified Attendant Console Department Edition;Cisco Unified Attendant Console Enterprise Edition;Cisco Unified Attendant Console Premium Edition Sofware product.This bug has been filed against Cisco Unified Attendant Console Advanced;Cisco Unified Attendant Console Business Edition;Cisco Unified Attendant Console Department Edition;Cisco Unified Attendant Console Enterprise Edition;Cisco Unified Attendant Console Premium Edition to address the vulnerability/ies known and identified by CVE(s): CVE-2015-2342 and CVE-2016-3642
PSIRT: There are 2 critical vulnerabilities found on CUAC server by the vulnerability scanner Frontline by Digital Defense Incorporated.  Both vulnerabilities are on the web interface and have to do with the Java implementation.  One is ?Passwordless Java JMX Interface? and the other is ?Java RMI Deserialization Remote Code Execution?.  There are no CVE's published that specifically name the CUAC web interface, but these are listed as references by our vulnerability scanner.     CVE-2015-2342 CVE-2016-3642  CVE-2015-6420 is already addressed in defect CSCux34827 and CSCux34829 however this defect now been raised is to address the above list of two CVEs.

Title: Cisco Wide Area Application Services TCP Fragment Denial of Service Vulnerability
RNE: Symptom: A vulnerability in the ingress processing of fragmented TCP packets by Cisco Wide Area Application Services (WAAS) could allow an unauthenticated, remote attacker to cause the WAASNET process to restart unexpectedly, causing a denial of service (DoS) condition.  The vulnerability is due to incomplete input validation of TCP packets when a packet chain is fragmented. An attacker could exploit this vulnerability by sending a crafted set of TCP fragments through an affected device. An exploit could allow the attacker to cause a DoS condition due to a process restarting unexpectedly. The WAAS could drop traffic during the brief time that the WAASNET process is restarting.  There are no workarounds that address this vulnerability.  This advisory is available at the following link: https://tools.cisco.com/security/center/content/CiscoSecurityAdvisory/cisco-sa-20170621-waas  Conditions: Cisco Wide Area Application Services (WAAS) prior to release 6.2.3c are vulnerable. This vulnerability is  fixed in software version 6.2.3c and later.  Workaround: None.  Further Problem Description: None.  PSIRT Evaluation: The Cisco PSIRT has assigned this bug the following CVSS version 3 score. The Base CVSS score as of the time of evaluation is 5.8: https://tools.cisco.com/security/center/cvssCalculator.x?version=3.0&vector=CVSS:3.0/AV:N/AC:L/PR:N/UI:N/S:C/C:N/I:N/A:L/E:X/RL:X/RC:X  CVE ID CVE-2017-6721 has been assigned to document this issue.  Additional information on Cisco's security vulnerability policy can be found at the following URL: http://www.cisco.com/en/US/products/products_security_vulnerability_policy.html

Title: Cross-site Scripting Vulnerability in the sipua Page
RNE: Symptom: A vulnerability in the web framework code of the Cisco IP Interoperability and Collaboration System (IPICS) could allow an unauthenticated, remote attacker to conduct a Cross-site Scripting (XSS) attack.   The vulnerability is due to insufficient input validation of some parameters passed to the web-server. An attacker could exploit this vulnerability by convincing the user to access a malicious link or by intercepting the user request and injecting the malicious code. An exploit could allow the attacker to execute arbitrary script code in the context of the affected site or allow the attacker to access sensitive browser-based information.  Conditions: Exposure is not configuration dependent.  Workaround: Not applicable or available.  Further Problem Description Additional information about XSS attack and potential mitigations can be found at: https://tools.cisco.com/security/center/content/CiscoAppliedMitigationBulletin/cisco-amb-20060922-understanding-xss  PSIRT Evaluation: The Cisco PSIRT has assigned this bug the following CVSS version 2 score. The Base and Temporal CVSS scores as of the time of evaluation are 4.3/4.1: http://tools.cisco.com/security/center/cvssCalculator.x?vector=AV:N/AC:M/Au:N/C:N/I:P/A:N/E:F/RL:U/RC:C&version=2.0 CVE ID CVE-2016-6429 has been assigned to document this issue. Additional information on Cisco's security vulnerability policy can be found at the following URL: http://www.cisco.com/en/US/products/products_security_vulnerability_policy.html  Further Problem Description:

Title: Cisco Aironet AP CWA FlexConnect Client ACL Bypass Vulnerability
RNE: $$IGNORE-PSIRT  Symptoms: A vulnerability in Central Web Authentication (CWA) with FlexConnect Access Points (APs) for Cisco Aironet 1560, 1810, 1810w, 1815, 1830, 1850, 2800 and 3800 Series APs could allow an unauthenticated, adjacent  attacker to bypass a configured FlexConnect ACL.   The vulnerability is due to the AP ignoring the ACL download from the client during authentication. An  attacker could exploit this vulnerability by connection to the targeted device with a vulnerable configuration.  An exploit could allow the attacker to bypass a configured client FlexConnect ACL.  Conditions: Central Web Authentication with FlexConnect Access Points was an unsupported configuration until until 8.5.100.0.  This vulnerability was fixed as of 8.5.103.0.  Workaround: If the client is forced to re-authenticate a second time the configured ACL is properly applied.  Further Problem Description: None.  PSIRT Evaluation: The Cisco PSIRT has assigned this bug the following CVSS version 3 score. Title: Nexus 7000 BGP Crash When Parsing Malformed AS Path
RNE: $$IGNORE-PSIRT  CISCO HIGHLY CONFIDENTIAL - CONTROLLED ACCESS  This issue is under review by the Cisco Product Security Incident Response team (PSIRT).  The defect describes a product security vulnerability.  Its contents must be protected from unauthorized disclosure, both internal and external to Cisco.  Do not forward this information to mailing lists or newsgroups.  Documentation writers: it is prohibited to publish this Release-note  Enclosure (RNE) until the content has been approved by PSIRT.  PSIRT may  publish a Security Advisory regarding this defect, and the current text of  this RNE will be replaced with appropriate information.  In the event that  a Security Advisory is not published, PSIRT will replace this text with an  appropriate explanation.  More information on PSIRT is available at http//psirt.cisco.com/.   Cisco's public policy on security vulnerability handling can be reviewed at  http://www.cisco.com/en/US/products/products_security_vulnerability_policy.html. For further information, send a message to psirt@cisco.com.  (briandd-06/09/17)   Symptom: A Nexus 7000 switch running 6.2(16) experiences a BGP crash due to signal 11 (Segmentation Fault/Violation) when bringing up a session with a peer that uses 2-byte ASN's.  Conditions: New BGP session is established between N7K and a BGP peer.  Capability negotiation between the peers succeeds, but the peer sends a malformed AS Path.  Workaround: Ensure that both peers use 4-byte ASN's when bringing up BGP sessions.  Further Problem Description:
Description: A Nexus 7K could experience a crash when bringing up a session with a neighbor that uses 2-byte ASN's (AS2).  It appears that the switch tries to parse the AS2's as 4-byte ASN's (AS4's).  This could cause the switch to overrun the AS Path, leading to unpredictable behavior and, in some cases, a seg fault/crash.

Title: Cisco ASA time-range object may have no effect
RNE: Symptom:  The access-list is not effective when configured with a time-range object   Conditions:  Currently this was noticed when the time-range object is configured with the ''periodic'' command and spanning over two or more consecutive days. Example of affected configuration is:  time-range WEEKEND   periodic Saturday 0:00 to Sunday 23:59  An access-list configured with the time-range object above will not have any effect.  To verify if you are affected by this issue, you can use the show time-range command while the time-range should be effective and verify that the command show the rule as inactive:  ciscoasa#show time-range  time-range entry: WEEKEND (inactive)     periodic Saturday 0:00 to Sunday 23:59     used in: IP ACL entry    Workaround:  Configuring the time-range object in a different way, may workaround this issue. Example of working configuration are:  time-range WEEKEND1   periodic Saturday 0:00 to 23:59   periodic Sunday 0:00 to 23:59  or  time-range WEEKEND2   periodic weekend 0:00 to 23:59   Further Problem Description:  A vulnerability in the implementation of the time-range object  could allow an unauthenticated, remote attacker to by-pass access-list that are using the time-range option.  The vulnerability is due to improper implementation of the code for the time-range object, when the periodic command is used. Due to this issue the time-range object will have no effect, thus depending on the access-list statement, (permit or deny), this may allow an attacker to by-pass the access-list statement. An attacker could exploit this vulnerability by sending traffic through the affected system.  PSIRT Evaluation: The Cisco PSIRT has assigned this bug the following CVSS version 2 score. The Base and Temporal CVSS scores as of the time of evaluation are 5/4.5: http://tools.cisco.com/security/center/cvssCalculator.x?vector=AV:N/AC:L/Au:N/C:P/I:N/A:N/E:F/RL:W/RC:C&version=2.0 CVE ID CVE-2013-1195 has been assigned to document this issue.  Additional details about the vulnerability described here can be found at: http://tools.cisco.com/security/center/content/CiscoSecurityNotice/CVE-2013-1195  Additional information on Cisco's security vulnerability policy can be found at the following URL: http://www.cisco.com/en/US/products/products_security_vulnerability_policy.html More Info:
Description: ASA 8.2.5 / 8.4.4.1 (behavior is correct  on 8.0)Configured time range doesn't get active if it is configured as below:time-range WEEKEND  periodic Saturday 0:00 to Sunday 23:59However, it becomes active if it is configured as:time-range WEEKEND1  periodic Saturday 0:00 to 23:59  periodic Sunday 0:00 to 23:59ORtime-range WEEKEND2  periodic weekend 0:00 to 23:59

Title: ISE evaluation for CVE-2014-6271 and CVE-2014-7169 (AKA ShellShock)
RNE: Symptom: The Cisco Identity Services Engine (ISE) includes a version of bash that is affected by the vulnerabilities identified by the Common Vulnerability and Exposures (CVE) IDs:  CVE-2014-6271 CVE-2014-7169 CVE-2014-7186 CVE-2014-7187 CVE-2014-6277 CVE-2014-6278  All shipping versions of ISE are vulnerable to  CVE-2014-6271,  CVE-2014-7169, CVE-2014-7186, CVE-2014-7187, CVE-2014-6277, CVE-2014-6278  (AKA ShellShock bug). That said, the exposure of this bug in ISE is very  limited.  The shellshock vulnerability allows an AUTHENTICATED SSH user  run a generic Linux command.  The key word being 'AUTHENTICATED'.  Hence if an attacker does not have the username and password of an ISE CLI user, they will not be able to exploit this vulnerability on ISE.   If the user DOES have credentials, and would like to exploit the shellshock,  that CLI user would be able to run generic Linux commands on the ISE node  that they would normally not be able to run (Because the ISE CLI does not  expose generic Linux commands).  However those Linux commands will run as the  logged in CLI user account, not as the Linux root user.  Hence, this limits  exposure of the vulnerability in ISE.  An example of an exploit using  shellshock in ISE would be to view Linux system files they would normally  not be able to view.   The workaround to remove the CLI vulnerability would be to disable the SSH daemon via the following CLI, then reload the ISE node to ensure all SSH  sessions have been terminated.  The following CLI demonstrates how to disable SSH service and reload the ISE node.    ---snip ise1/admin# configure terminal ise1/admin(config)# no service sshd enable  ise1/admin(config)# end ise1/admin# reload Save the current ADE-OS running configuration? (yes/no) [yes] ? yes Continue with reboot? [y/n] y ---snip  Note that reloading the node is important to do after disabling SSH because  it ensures all SSH sessions have been disconnected.  Regarding other exposures to the shellshock bug such as through DHCP or  CGI, we believe ISE is not vulnerable to either, with this reasoning: Related to DHCP server optoins vulnerability, an ISE node never acts as a DHCP client. The IPv4 addresses must be configured statically in ISE,  hence the shellshock attack from DHCP server options flag would never  get called by ISE.   Regarding web interface/CGI vulnerability, the shellshock bug affects  mod_cgi/mod_cgid running on Apache. ISE does not use Apache and Apache is not even installed in ISE.  ISE uses tomcat for its web applications.   Furthermore, within the ISE tomcat webapp configuration, for each webapp  there are no servlet-mappings for CGI.  Given this, we believe ISE is not vulnerable to shellshock from the web/CGI interface.  This defect has been fixed in the following versions of ISE: 1.1.3.x patch 12 1.1.4.x patch 12 1.2.0.x patch 12 1.2.1.x patch 3 1.3.0.876 (FCS)  Conditions: ISE nodes are exposed to this vulnerability only if they have ssh service enabled.  If SSH is enabled, a remote user with ISE CLI credentials will be able to exploit the vulnerability and run generic Linux commands.  Workaround: Disable SSH and reload ISE node as follows (until the ISE patch with the fix for CSCur00532 is installed):  ---snip ise1/admin# configure terminal ise1/admin(config)# no service sshd enable  ise1/admin(config)# end ise1/admin# reload Save the current ADE-OS running configuration? (yes/no) [yes] ? yes Continue with reboot? [y/n] y ---snip  Further Problem Description: PSIRT Evaluation: The Cisco PSIRT has assigned this bug the following CVSS version 2 score. The Base and Temporal CVSS scores as of the time of evaluation are  7.5/7.5:  http://tools.cisco.com/security/center/cvssCalculator.x?vector=AV:N/AC:L/Au:N/C:P/I:P/A:P/E:H/RL:U/RC:C&version=2.0  The Cisco PSIRT has assigned this score based on information obtained from multiple sources. This includes the CVSS score assigned by the third-party vendor when available. The CVSS score assigned may not reflect the actual impact on the Cisco Product.  Additional information on Cisco's security vulnerability policy can be found at the following URL:  http://www.cisco.com/web/about/security/psirt/security_vulnerability_policy.html

Title: CWA and TES Client Manager Server Arbitrary File Read Vulnerability

The vulnerability is due to insufficient input validation. An attacker could exploit this vulnerability by sending a crafted URL to the Client Manager Server. An exploit could allow the attacker to retrieve any file of their choosing from the Cisco Workload Automation or Cisco Tidal Enterprise Scheduler Client Manager Server.  Conditions: Default installation of an affected release of the Cisco Workload Automation or Cisco Tidal Enterprise Scheduler Client Manager Server.  Workaround: None. Title: Cisco UCS C-Series Rack Servers TCP Port Denial of Service Vulnerability
RNE: Symptom: A vulnerability in the TCP throttling process of the Cisco UCS C-Series Rack Servers could allow an unauthenticated, remote attacker to cause a denial of service (DoS) condition on an affected device.  The vulnerability is due to insufficient rate limiting protection. An attacker could exploit this vulnerability by sending the affected device a high rate of TCP SYN packets to a specific TCP listening port. An exploit could allow the attacker to cause the a specific TCP listening port to stop accepting new connections.  Conditions: This vulnerability is seen only in local internal releases and fixed in 3.0(1c) and 3.0(3a). At this time vulnerability is not discovered in 2.x and 1.x release trains.  Workaround: None.  Further Problem Description: None.  PSIRT Evaluation: The Cisco PSIRT has assigned this bug the following CVSS version 3 score. The Base CVSS score as of the time of evaluation is 5.8: https://tools.cisco.com/security/center/cvssCalculator.x?version=3.0&vector=CVSS:3.0/AV:N/AC:L/PR:N/UI:N/S:C/C:N/I:N/A:L/E:X/RL:X/RC:X  CVE ID CVE-2017-6633 has been assigned to document this issue.  Additional information on Cisco's security vulnerability policy can be found at the following URL: http://www.cisco.com/en/US/products/products_security_vulnerability_policy.html

Title: Cisco Web Security Appliance Advanced Malware Protection File Bypass Vulnerability
RNE: Symptom: A vulnerability in Advanced Malware Protection (AMP) file filtering feature of Cisco AsyncOS Software for Cisco Web Security Appliance (WSA) could allow an  unauthenticated, remote attacker to bypass a configured AMP file filtering rule. The file types affected are zipped or archived file types.  The vulnerability is due to incorrect and different file hash values when AMP scans the file. An attacker could exploit this vulnerability by sending a crafted email file  attachment through the targeted device. An exploit could allow the attacker to bypass a configured AMP file filter.  There are no workarounds that address this vulnerability.  This advisory is available at the following link: https://tools.cisco.com/security/center/content/CiscoSecurityAdvisory/cisco-sa-20171115-wsa  Conditions: The WSA is configured for AMP and has disabled the other adaptive scanning and AV engines  such as Sophos , McAfee and Webroot.  This vulnerability is present in all previous software version until the first fixed release.  Workaround: None.  Further Problem Description: None.  PSIRT Evaluation: The Cisco PSIRT has assigned this bug the following CVSS version 3 score. Title: Interface oversubscription on active causes standby to disable failover
RNE: Symptom: Interface oversubscription on active causes standby to disable failover  Conditions: A huge amount of traffic may exhaust interface blocks, which in turn may cause firewall to drop failover messages and go to disabled HA state Workaround: None  PSIRT Evaluation: The Cisco PSIRT has assigned this bug the following CVSS version 2 score. The Base and Temporal CVSS scores as of the time of evaluation are 4.3/3.6: http://tools.cisco.com/security/center/cvssCalculator.x?vector=AV:N/AC:M/Au:N/C:N/I:N/A:P/E:F/RL:OF/RC:C&version=2.0 CVE ID CVE-2012-3914 has been assigned to document this issue. Additional information on Cisco's security vulnerability policy can be found at the following URL: http://www.cisco.com/en/US/products/products_security_vulnerability_policy.html
Description: Under no condition should the ASA disable failover completely. It should always monitor the failover interface for failover messages.UPDATE: This requirement is being tracked under CSCud24433    ENH: Do not disable failover in case of progression failure. Syslog enhancements are being tracked under CSCte45874    ENH - Add failover supportability and usability enhancements.***Vistaprint is experiencing several issues with their failover pair of ASA 5585s, triggered by DOS attacked sourced from the internet. I am able to recreate one of their behaviours on the lab. The customer is using Gig0/6 and 0/7 for their LAN and state failover interfaces respectively. If the ASA is under a severe DoS attack where the Internal-Data0/0 interface is oversubscribed, both ASA's will go Active because they lose the ability to talk to each other over the failover LAN interface link. Once in this state (both ASA's are Active), after some time a failover hello message will squeak through that makes the Secondary attempt to synchronize failover with the Primary. In the process of trying to synchronize failover, the Secondary ASA fails and experiences a ;HA State Progression;.Softbank reported an ASA failover issue. When primary ASA is under traffic load, failover on the secondary ASA may flaps or even become disabled:-----flapping:- standby ready -> active -> cold standby -> standby readydisabled:- standby ready -> active -> cold standby -> disabledThis is steadily reproducible on ASA5585 8.4(4)2 in TAC-lab.

RNE: $$IGNORE-PSIRT  CISCO HIGHLY CONFIDENTIAL - CONTROLLED ACCESS  This issue is under review by the Cisco Product Security Incident Response team (PSIRT).  The defect describes a product security vulnerability.  Its contents must be protected from unauthorized disclosure, both internal and external to Cisco. Description: Router crash while processing in IKEv2 process due to context switch with crypto engine

Title: SSHv2 spurious memory access
RNE: The Secure Shell server (SSH) implementation in Cisco IOS contains multiple vulnerabilities that allow unauthenticated users the ability to generate a spurious memory access error or, in certain cases, reload the device.   The IOS SSH server is an optional service that is disabled by default, but its use is highly recommended as a security best practice for management of Cisco IOS devices. SSH can be configured as part of the AutoSecure feature in the initial configuration of IOS devices, AutoSecure run after initial configuration, or manually. Devices that are not configured to accept SSH connections are not affected by these vulnerabilities.  Common Vulnerabilities and Exposures (CVE) identifier CVE-2008-1159 has been assigned to this bug.  The Security Advisory for this issue is posted at http://www.cisco.com/warp/public/707/cisco-sa-20080521-ssh.shtml
Description: A router running 12.4T or 12.4 with SSH enabled (crypto key generate rsa + transport input ssh on a vty) crashes if someone does a ssh session under certain conditions.0x1191810  : doprnt             (+0x15fc)0x118FDD0  : vsnprintf          (+0x60)0x28CC424  : packet_disconnect  (+0x68)0x28D0478  : ssh2_authenticate  (+0x444)0x28BE9E4  : ssh_process        (+0x298)0x6EE660   : process_execute    (+0x168)No valid credentials are required to crash a box remotely.This is a regression introduced by CSCse76056 so all releases >= 012.004(011.002) 12.4(11.02)T are affected.WARNING : The fix in CSCsk42419 is not perfect.  Make sure you have the fix for CSCsk60020 too !

Title: Cisco Email Security Appliance Attachment Filter Bypass Vulnerability
RNE: Symptoms: A vulnerability in the email message scanning of Cisco AsyncOS Software for Cisco Email  Security Appliances (ESA) could allow an unauthenticated, remote attacker to bypass  configured filters on the device.  The vulnerability is due to improper input validation of an email with an attachment and modified Multipurpose Internet Mail Extensions (MIME) header. An attacker could exploit  this vulnerability by sending a malformed email message with an attachment. A successful  exploit could allow the attacker to bypass configured message filters to drop the email. The  email may not be RFC compliant. However, some mail clients could still allow users to read  the email which may not have been properly filtered by the device.  Conditions: This vulnerability affects all releases prior to the first fixed release of Cisco AsyncOS  Software for Cisco Email Security Appliances, both virtual and hardware appliances, if the  software is configured to apply a message filter or content filter to incoming email attachments.  Workaround: None.  Further Problem Description: None.  PSIRT Evaluation: The Cisco PSIRT has assigned this bug the following CVSS version 3 score. The Base CVSS score as of the time of evaluation is 5.8: https://tools.cisco.com/security/center/cvssCalculator.x?version=3.0&vector=CVSS:3.0/AV:N/AC:L/PR:N/UI:N/S:C/C:N/I:L/A:N/E:X/RL:X/RC:X  CVE ID CVE-2017-6671 has been assigned to document this issue.  Additional information on Cisco's security vulnerability policy can be found at the following URL: http://www.cisco.com/en/US/products/products_security_vulnerability_policy.html
Description: Bypass attachment filetype content filter policy with modified Content-Transfer-Encoding header.The smallest change in header Content-Transfer-Encoding value allows to bypass a filter but the proper change allows to bypass the filter and still be properly opened by most MUA's. Review the tac-repro for details.

Title: Expressway: Password Hashes Revealed in Status Snapshot File
RNE: Symptom: A vulnerability in the System Snapshot of the Cisco TelePresence Video Communication Server (VCS) Expressway could allow an authenticated, remote attacker to view sensitive data.  The vulnerability is due to insufficient protection of data at rest. An attacker could exploit this vulnerability by downloading the snapshot file and viewing the password hashes contained. An exploit could allow the attacker to crack the password hashes and use credentials to launch further attacks.  Conditions: Device running with default configuration.  Workaround: None.  PSIRT Evaluation: The Cisco PSIRT has assigned this bug the following CVSS version 2 score. The Base and Temporal CVSS scores as of the time of evaluation are 4/3.8: http://tools.cisco.com/security/center/cvssCalculator.x?vector=AV:N/AC:L/Au:S/C:P/I:N/A:N/E:F/RL:U/RC:C&version=2.0 CVE ID CVE-2015-4314 has been assigned to document this issue. Additional information on Cisco's security vulnerability policy can be found at the following URL: http://www.cisco.com/en/US/products/products_security_vulnerability_policy.html  Further Problem Description:
Description: Status snap shot reveals password hashes ? The read only user can snapshot the status and then download it. One of the files contains the password hashes for all app users. Once cracked the admin user can SSH in with tsh limited shell.

Title: Cisco ASR 5000 Series Aggregation Services Routers Access Control List Security Bypass Vulnerability
RNE: Symptom: A vulnerability in certain filtering mechanisms of access control lists (ACLs) for Cisco ASR 5000 Series Aggregation Services Routers could allow an unauthenticated, remote attacker to bypass ACL rules that have been configured for an affected device.  The vulnerability exists because the affected device fails to inspect and match certain traffic that meets the criteria defined in ACL rules configured for the device. An attacker could exploit this vulnerability by sending crafted HTTP packets to an affected device. A successful exploit could allow the attacker to bypass certain sets of rules defined in ACLs for the affected device.  There are no workarounds that address this vulnerability.  This advisory is available at the following link: https://tools.cisco.com/security/center/content/CiscoSecurityAdvisory/cisco-sa-20170719-asr1  Conditions: Device running an affected version of software.  Workaround: None.  Further Problem Description: For information about vulnerable and not vulnerable software releases, and time frame for fixed software releases, please open a support case with your support organization. PSIRT does not provide or maintain this information for Medium SIR advisories.   This is the best available information on affected/not affected/fixed releases as of May 22, 2017. PSIRT will not maintain this information. For updates, please follow up with the DE assigned to this bug.  PSIRT Evaluation: The Cisco PSIRT has assigned this bug the following CVSS version 3 score. The Base CVSS score as of the time of evaluation is 5.3: https://tools.cisco.com/security/center/cvssCalculator.x?version=3.0&vector=CVSS:3.0/AV:N/AC:L/PR:N/UI:N/S:U/C:L/I:N/A:N/E:X/RL:X/RC:X  CVE ID CVE-2017-6672  has been assigned to this issue.  Additional information on Cisco's security vulnerability policy can be found at the following URL: http://www.cisco.com/en/US/products/products_security_vulnerability_policy.html
Description: The http analyzer error detection include the http version field. Based on http analyzer behavior to not match an http erred packet against any L7 rules - this  it will be also a solution to the http version exploit.HTTP version check and HTTP error flag check should be part of the HTTP analyzer.>>>>They flagged the test # 8 (page 9 in the ppt) has not passed: the GW is not supposed to consider the misspelled request - that contains HDTP/1.1 instead of HTTP/1.1 - as HTTP.In the test the GW matches the malformed request with ruledef 22-MYATT, based on attwifi.com url.See attached the pcaps and the cli/trace corresponding to the tests.

Title: Cisco IOS and Cisco IOS XE Session Initiation Protocol DoS Vulnerability
RNE: Summary A vulnerability in the Session Initiation Protocol (SIP) implementation in Cisco IOS Software and Cisco IOS XE Software could allow an  unauthenticated, remote attacker to cause a reload of an affected device. To exploit this vulnerability, affected devices must be configured to process  SIP messages.  Cisco has released free software updates that address this vulnerability.   There are no workarounds for devices that must run SIP; however, mitigations are available to limit exposure to this vulnerability.  This advisory is available at the following link: http://tools.cisco.com/security/center/content/CiscoSecurityAdvisory/cisco-sa-20140924-sip  PSIRT Evaluation: The Cisco PSIRT has assigned this bug the following CVSS version 2 score. The Base and Temporal CVSS scores as of the time of evaluation are  7.8/6.4: http://tools.cisco.com/security/center/cvssCalculator.x?vector=AV:N/AC:L/Au:N/C:N/I:N/A:C/E:F/RL:OF/RC:C&version=2.0 CVE ID CVE-2014-3360 has been assigned to document this issue. Additional information on Cisco's security vulnerability policy can be found at the following URL: http://www.cisco.com/en/US/products/products_security_vulnerability_policy.html

Title: Cisco Nexus Series Switches CLI Command Injection Vulnerability
RNE: Symptom: A vulnerability in the CLI of Cisco NX-OS System Software running on Nexus Series Switches could allow an authenticated, local attacker to perform a command injection attack.  The vulnerability is due to insufficient input validation of command arguments. An attacker could exploit this vulnerability by injecting crafted command arguments into a vulnerable CLI command. An exploit could allow the attacker to read or write arbitrary files at the user's privilege level outside of the user's path.  Conditions: None  Workaround: None  Further Problem Description: For information about vulnerable and not vulnerable software releases, and time frame for fixed software releases, please open a support case with your support organization. PSIRT does not provide or maintain this information for Medium SIR advisories.  PSIRT Evaluation: The Cisco PSIRT has assigned this bug the following CVSS version 3 score. The Base CVSS score as of the time of evaluation is 4.4: https://tools.cisco.com/security/center/cvssCalculator.x?version=3.0&vector=CVSS:3.0/AV:L/AC:L/PR:L/UI:N/S:U/C:L/I:L/A:N/E:X/RL:X/RC:X  CVE ID CVE-2017-6649 has been assigned to document this issue.  Additional information on Cisco's security vulnerability policy can be found at the following URL: http://www.cisco.com/en/US/products/products_security_vulnerability_policy.html
Description: The ;ssh; command in the local-mgmt shell allows users to manipulate argumentspassed to ssh on the command line. This could allow users to read and write arbitrary files on the system (with the privileges of the logged-in user) by connecting to an attacker-controlled ssh server.For example:Writing arbitrary files:  ssh josconno@10.1.1.100>/tmp/fileThis example is not intended to be exhaustive.To fix these issues, all user input, and especially arguments to shell commands,should be validated to ensure they meet the expected format, preferably with a whitelist. In this case that means validating that the hostname argument specifies a valid hostname.

Title: Cisco Adaptive Security Appliance Authenticated Cross-Site Scripting Vulnerability
RNE: Symptom: A vulnerability in the web-based management interface of Cisco Adaptive Security Appliance (ASA) could allow  an authenticated, remote attacker to conduct a cross-site scripting (XSS)  attack against a user of the web-based management interface of an affected device.   The vulnerability is due to insufficient validation of user-supplied input by the web-based management interface of an affected device. An attacker could exploit this vulnerability by persuading a user of the interface to click a  crafted link. A successful exploit could allow the attacker to execute arbitrary script code in the context of the  interface or allow the attacker to access sensitive browser-based information.   Additional information about XSS attacks and potential mitigations can be found at:      https://tools.cisco.com/security/center/content/CiscoAppliedMitigationBulletin/cisco-amb-20060922-understanding-xss     https://www.owasp.org/index.php/Cross-site_Scripting_(XSS)  There are no workarounds that address this vulnerability.  This advisory is available at the following link: https://tools.cisco.com/security/center/content/CiscoSecurityAdvisory/cisco-sa-20170802-asa  Conditions: Device running with default configuration running an affected version of software.  Workaround: None.  Further Problem Description: Additional information about XSS attacks and potential mitigations can be found at:  http://www.cisco.com/en/US/products/cmb/cisco-amb-20060922-understanding-xss.html https://www.owasp.org/index.php/Cross-site_Scripting_(XSS)  PSIRT Evaluation:  Credit: Cisco would like to thank security researcher Adam Willard from Blue Canopy Group for finding and reporting this vulnerability.  The Cisco PSIRT has assigned this bug the following CVSS version 3 score. The Base CVSS score as of the time of evaluation is 5.4: https://tools.cisco.com/security/center/cvssCalculator.x?version=3.0&vector=CVSS:3.0/AV:N/AC:L/PR:L/UI:R/S:C/C:L/I:L/A:N/E:X/RL:X/RC:X  CVE ID CVE-2017-6764 has been assigned to document this issue.  Additional information on Cisco's security vulnerability policy can be found at the following URL: http://www.cisco.com/en/US/products/products_security_vulnerability_policy.html
Description: XSS - HTML injection in Internet ExplorerReported from an external researcher.Issue observed on Cisco ASA 555X version 9.5(1)Authenticated user can inject HTML code via Internet Explorer. Not reproducible in other browsers (firefox).Log into the the vpn.Paste the url in the browser.This only worked in Internet Explorer. Only tested Firefox and IE. I did not add the site to disable XSS in IE, so, this is html injection as IE will normally block most XSS.The url provided is breaks out of this line.document.write('<param name=;url; value=;' + window.location.href + ';>');Firefox uses %22%3E%27 instead of the characters passed.

Title: Cisco FX-OS and NX-OS System Software CLI Command Injection Vulnerability
RNE: Symptom: A vulnerability in the CLI of Cisco NX-OS System Software could allow an authenticated, local attacker to perform a command injection attack.  The vulnerability is due to insufficient input validation of command arguments to the CLI parser. An attacker could exploit this vulnerability by injecting crafted command arguments into a vulnerable CLI command. An exploit could allow the attacker to execute arbitrary commands at the user?s privilege level.  Note: On products that support multiple Virtual Device Contexts (VDC) this could allow an attacker to execute commands at the user?s privilege level outside of the user?s environment.  Conditions: None  Workaround: There are no workarounds that address this vulnerability.  This advisory is available at the following link: https://tools.cisco.com/security/center/content/CiscoSecurityAdvisory/cisco-sa-20171129-fxnx  Further Problem Description: For information about vulnerable and not vulnerable software releases, and time frame for fixed software releases, please open a support case with your support organization. PSIRT does not provide or maintain this information for Medium SIR advisories.  PSIRT Evaluation: The Cisco PSIRT has assigned this bug the following CVSS version 3 score. The Base CVSS score as of the time of evaluation is 6.3: https://tools.cisco.com/security/center/cvssCalculator.x?version=3.0&vector=CVSS:3.0/AV:L/AC:L/PR:L/UI:N/S:C/C:L/I:L/A:L/E:X/RL:X/RC:X  CVE ID CVE-2017-12329 has been assigned to document this issue.  Additional information on Cisco's security vulnerability policy can be found at the following URL: http://www.cisco.com/en/US/products/products_security_vulnerability_policy.html
Description: The "show snmp internal translate oidorname" CLI command contains a commandinjection vulnerability which allows a low-privileged, authenticated attacker toexecute arbitrary Linux commands as the logged in user.  Furthermore, afterexploiting this vulnerability to gain shell access, an attacker could leverageother known privilege escalation vulnerabilities (CSCvd45820, CSCvd47512) toobtain "root" access and completely control the device.Note that the vulnerable command appears to be accessible to all users,including those at the minimal "priv-0" privilege level.  Furthermore, thiscommand is also accessible to VDC users, and thus the vulnerability allows themto escape the VDC.Consider the following CLI transcript which illustrates the vulnerability.    n7700-vdc-2# show version | grep version    the GNU General Public License (GPL) version 2.0 or the GNU      BIOS:      version 3.1.0      kickstart: version 8.0(1)      system:    version 8.0(1)      System version: 8.0(1)    n7700-vdc-2# # confirm we're a priv-0 user locked in a vdc    n7700-vdc-2# show users    NAME     LINE         TIME         IDLE          PID COMMENT    vdc2-priv0     pts/1        Apr 27 19:37   .         14410 (10.1.1.100) session=ssh *    n7700-vdc-2# show user-account vdc2-priv0    user:vdc2-priv0            this user account has no expiry date            roles:priv-0    n7700-vdc-2# show vdc current-vdc    Current vdc is 2 - vdc-2    n7700-vdc-2# # verify the output file doesn't exist    n7700-vdc-2# show file volatile:out.txt    Couldn't read: (/volatile/vdc_2/out.txt)    n7700-vdc-2# # exploit the command injection vulnerability    n7700-vdc-2# # the CLI output isn't important so just truncate with head    n7700-vdc-2# show snmp internal translate oidorname `/usr/bin/w/volatile/vdc_2/out.txt` | head lines 1    * transferred.    n7700-vdc-2# # prove that the injected Linux command was executed    n7700-vdc-2# show file volatile:out.txt     20:07:28 up  1:20,  3 users,  load average: 1.66, 1.28, 1.19    USER     TTY        LOGIN@   IDLE   JCPU   PCPU WHAT    admin    pts/0     18:56    1:37   1.79s  0.27s /isan/bin/vsh    vdc2-pri pts/1     19:50    5.00s  0.26s  0.25s /isan/bin/vsh    admin    pts/2     19:32   40.00s  0.29s  0.20s /isan/bin/vshThe following code snippet appears to be responsible for this vulnerability.Note that the "param" variable contains user input from the CLI.  This input isinjected into the string stored in "buf" and is executed via the "popen()" call.    COMMON/feature/snmp/libcli/n7k_snmp_cli.c    6049 int32    6050 cli_snmp_server_show(paraminfo_type  *param)    6051 {    ...    6341    case SNMP_SRV_OID_TO_NAME:    ...    6350           snprintf(buf,sizeof(buf),"cat %s | grep -i \"%s\" | awk '{print $1,$2}'",SNMPINFODAT,(char*)GET_PARAM_ARG(param, 1));    6351           fp = popen(buf,"r"); /* Issue the command. */To address this issue, developers must ensure that user-supplied input (such asfile paths) are properly sanitized before being passed to the shell via"system()," "popen()," or other similar functions.As a stronger mitigation, developers should also consider eliminating the use of"system()," "popen()," and other similar functions.  In this example, developerscould replace the offending "popen()" call with code that reads the"snmpinfo.dat" file (to replace "cat"), filters lines (to replace "grep"), andformats the output accordingly (to replace "sed").  With such a fix, the Linuxshell is never invoked, thus eliminating all possibility of a command injectionvulnerability.For additional information about command injection vulnerabilities and availablemitigations, see [1] and [2].References:[1] https://cisco.jiveon.com/docs/DOC-1583666[2] https://www.owasp.org/index.php/Command_Injection[3] http://cwe.mitre.org/data/definitions/78[4] http://cwe.mitre.org/data/definitions/693[5] http://cwe.mitre.org/data/definitions/269
PSIRT: PSIRT-owner: psirt@cisco.com  This issue is being considered for possible inclusion in a Security Advisory even though the Release-note Enclosure is already visible to customers.  Please do not further change the Release-note Enclosure;  PSIRT will modify it appropriately at a later date.          Do not provide customers with any information beyond what is currently contained in the Release-note Enclosure.          Should customers appear to be running into this DDTs within their network,  please bring it to the immediate attention of the Cisco PSIRT  at psirt@cisco.com.

Title: Cisco RF Gateway 1 TCP Connection Denial of Service Vulnerability
RNE: Symptom: A vulnerability in the TCP state machine of Cisco RF Gateway 1 devices could allow an unauthenticated, remote attacker to prevent an affected device from delivering switched digital video (SDV) or video on demand (VoD) streams, resulting in a denial of service (DoS) condition.  The vulnerability is due to a processing error with TCP connections to the affected device. An attacker could exploit this vulnerability by establishing a large number of TCP connections to an affected device and not actively closing those TCP connections. A successful exploit could allow the attacker to prevent the affected device from delivering SDV or VoD streams to set-top boxes.  There are no workarounds that address this vulnerability.  This advisory is available at the following link: https://tools.cisco.com/security/center/content/CiscoSecurityAdvisory/cisco-sa-20171115-rf-gateway-1  Conditions: For information about vulnerable and not vulnerable software releases, and time frame for fixed software releases, please open a support case with your support organization. PSIRT does not provide or maintain this information for Medium SIR advisories.  Workaround: Please refer to the security advisory.  Further Problem Description: Exploitation of this vulnerability affects delivery only of SDV and VoD streams to set-top boxes. It does not affect delivery of Internet data to cable modems or delivery of linear video streams to set-top boxes.  PSIRT Evaluation: The Cisco PSIRT has assigned this bug the following CVSS version 3 score. The Base CVSS score as of the time of evaluation is 5.8: https://tools.cisco.com/security/center/cvssCalculator.x?version=3.0&vector=CVSS:3.0/AV:N/AC:L/PR:N/UI:N/S:C/C:N/I:N/A:L/E:X/RL:X/RC:X  CVE ID CVE-2017-12318 has been assigned to document this issue.  Additional information on Cisco's security vulnerability policy can be found at the following URL: http://www.cisco.com/en/US/products/products_security_vulnerability_policy.html

Title: Telnet connection is permitted inappropriately in some situation
RNE: Symptom: Administrators are able to Telnet to the lowest security level interface inappropriately in some  situation.  Conditions: Some interface become lowest security-level(greater than 0) interface after configuration change.  (A) When  ;failover lan interface name hw_interface_name ; command is  configured, 8.0.5 only does not happen this issue. (B) When  ;failover lan interface name hw_interface_name ; command is  NOT configured, 8.0.x does not happen this issue.  Workaround:  (A) Chenge the security level of relevant interface to zero. (B) Chenge the security level of relevant interface to zero or reload.  PSIRT Evaluation: The Cisco PSIRT has assigned this bug the following CVSS version 2 score. The Base and Temporal CVSS scores as of the time of evaluation are 5/4.5:  http://tools.cisco.com/security/center/cvssCalculator.x?vector=AV:N/AC:L/Au:N/C:P/I:N/A:N/E:F/RL:W/RC:C&version=2.0  CVE ID CVE-2011-0362 has been assigned to document this issue.  Additional information on Cisco's security vulnerability policy can be found at the following URL:  http://www.cisco.com/en/US/products/products_security_vulnerability_policy.html
Description: Users are able to Telnet to the lowest security level interface inappropriately in some situation. This behavior also is different from if "failover lan interface name phy_hw" command is configured or not. This is a potential security issue/concern.--------------add following configuration from initial configinterface gi0/0 nameif test security-level 1 ip address 10.1.1.1 255.255.255.0 no shinterface man0/0 nameif mng security-level 0telnet 10.1.1.0 255.255.255.0 test/failover lan interface fover gi0/2/ --if configure "failover lan interface -"-----telnet for 10.1.1.1 - result is (A)-----add following configurationinterface man0/0 no nameif-----telnet for 10.1.1.1 - result is (B)-----add following configurationwrite memoryreload-----telnet for 10.1.1.1 - result is (C)--------------These test's result is following.OK is telnet success and NG is telnet failed.--------------(A)	not exist "failover lan interface -"	exist "failover lan interface -"8.0.4		OK				OK8.0.5		OK				OK8.2.1		OK				OK8.2.3		OK				OK8.2.4		OK				OK	-----(B)	not exist "failover lan interface -"	 exist "failover lan interface -"8.0.4		NG				OK8.0.5		NG				NG8.2.1		OK				OK8.2.3		OK				OK8.2.4		OK				OK-----(C)	not exist "failover lan interface -" 	 exist "failover lan interface -"8.0.4		NG				OK8.0.5		NG				OK8.2.1		NG				OK8.2.3		NG				OK8.2.4		NG				OK--------------These results should be following matrix.--------------(A)	not exist "failover lan interface -"	exist "failover lan interface -"8.0.4		OK				OK8.0.5		OK				OK8.2.1		OK				OK8.2.3		OK				OK8.2.4		OK				OK	--------------(B)	not exist "failover lan interface -"	 exist "failover lan interface -"8.0.4		NG				NG8.0.5		NG				NG8.2.1		NG				NG8.2.3		NG				NG8.2.4		NG				NG--------------(C)	not exist "failover lan interface -" 	 exist "failover lan interface -"8.0.4		NG				NG8.0.5		NG				NG8.2.1		NG				NG8.2.3		NG				NG8.2.4		NG				NG

Title: Input queue wedge with SSLVPN DTLS Client Hello
RNE: Symptom:   The Input queue of an interface shows 76/75. In show buffers input-interface iinterface/i packet will show UDP packets with the port used by DTLS.  Conditions: This symptom is observed with SSLVPN with DTLS enabled (it is enabled by default, depending on the platform).  Workaround:   You can use the no svc dtls command in the WebVPN group policy configuration mode to disable the DTLS support on the SSL VPN, and reload  the router to clear the interface queue wedge condition.  Embedded Event Manager  A Cisco IOS Embedded Event Manager (EEM) policy that is based on Tool Command Language (Tcl) can be used on vulnerable Cisco IOS devices to  identify and detect an interface queue wedge that is caused by this vulnerability. The policy allows administrators to monitor the interfaces for Cisco IOS  device and detect when the interface input queues are full. When Cisco IOS EEM detects potential exploitation of this vulnerability, the policy can trigger a  response by sending an alert to the network administrator, who could then decide to implement an upgrade, implement suitable mitigations or reload the  device to clear the input queue.  The Tcl script is available for download at the ''Cisco Beyond: Embedded Event Manager (EEM) Scripting Community'' at the following link:  https://supportforums.cisco.com/docs/DOC-19337  Also see the Cisco Security Blog ''Cisco IOS Queue Wedges Explained'' at the following link:  http://blogs.cisco.com/security/cisco_ios_queue_wedges_explained/  PSIRT Evaluation: The Cisco PSIRT has assigned this bug the following CVSS version 2 score. The Base and Temporal CVSS scores as of the time of evaluation are  6.8/5.6: http://tools.cisco.com/security/center/cvssCalculator.x?vector=AV:N/AC:L/Au:S/C:N/I:N/A:C/E:F/RL:OF/RC:C&version=2.0  CVE ID CVE-2013-6686 has been assigned to document this issue.  Additional details about the vulnerability described here can be found at: http://tools.cisco.com/security/center/content/CiscoSecurityNotice/CVE-2013-6686   Additional information on Cisco's security vulnerability policy can be found at the following URL: http://www.cisco.com/en/US/products/products_security_vulnerability_policy.html  Further Problem Description:
Description: Topology :OpenConnect ---------- IOS-SSLVPN 15.2(4)M2 or 15.3(1)TSymptom :Input queue wedge on interface used for SSLVPN :barge#sh int vlan 1Vlan1 is up, line protocol is up  Hardware is EtherSVI, address is 001e.7a29.9cd2 (bia 001e.7a29.9cd2)  Internet address is 10.48.77.208/24  MTU 1500 bytes, BW 100000 Kbit/sec, DLY 100 usec,     reliability 255/255, txload 1/255, rxload 1/255  Encapsulation ARPA, loopback not set  Keepalive not supported  ARP type: ARPA, ARP Timeout 04:00:00  Last input 00:00:17, output never, output hang never  Last clearing of "show interface" counters never  Input queue: 76/75/15/0 (size/max/drops/flushes); Total output drops: 0 ------ 76 = WEDGED !  Queueing strategy: fifo  Output queue: 0/40 (size/max)  5 minute input rate 0 bits/sec, 0 packets/sec  5 minute output rate 0 bits/sec, 0 packets/sec     30719 packets input, 3540772 bytes, 0 no buffer     Received 14907 broadcasts (2 IP multicasts)     0 runts, 0 giants, 8545 throttles     0 input errors, 0 CRC, 0 frame, 0 overrun, 0 ignored     20186 packets output, 1868335 bytes, 0 underruns     0 output errors, 1 interface resets     2264 unknown protocol drops     0 output buffer failures, 0 output buffers swapped outSteps to reproduce :Connect to IOS-SSLVPN using OpenConnect client and let the session time out.See attached logs :- barge-buffers.txt = show buffer input-interface Vlan1 packet- barge-show-tech.txt = show tech collected during the problem- openconnect-logs.txt = logs from the client- barge-dtls.pcap = pcap made from the buffer dump with the following command :perl buffout.pl --in barge-buffers.txt --noheader --nodump --expr 't2pcap($datagramstart, $datagramsize)' | text2pcap -e 0x800 -u 10000,1443 - barge-dtls.pcapDon't look at the Ethernet/IP/UDP headers because they are all fake. The only valid information in the pcap is the DTLS payload.See http://tac-wiki.cisco.com/Buffout_-_tool_for_IOS_buffer_dump_processing if you're interested by that tool.
